Comprehensive Rules

1. Game Concepts

100. General

100.1. These Magic rules apply to any Magic game with two or more players, including two-player games and multiplayer games.

100.1a. A two-player game is a game that begins with only two players.

100.1b. A multiplayer game is a game that begins with more than two players. See section 8, „Multiplayer Rules.”

100.2. To play, each player needs their own deck of traditional Magic cards, small items to represent any tokens and counters, and some way to clearly track life totals.

100.2a. In`constructed <#constructed>`__ play <#play>`__(a way of playing in which each`player creates theirown deck ahead of time), each`deck <#deck>`__ has a minimum decksize of 60`cards <#card>`__. A`constructed <#constructed>`__ deck <#deck>`__may contain any number of `basic <#basic>`__`land cards and no morethan four of any card with aparticular English name other than`basic <#basic>`__ land cards.

100.2b. In limited <#limited>`__`play (a way of playing in which each`player <#player>`__ gets the same quantity ofunopened Magic product such as boosterpacks and`creates <#create>`__ their own deck <#deck>`__using only this product and `basic <#basic>`__`land cards), each`deck <#deck>`__ has a minimum decksize of 40`cards <#card>`__. A limited <#limited>`__`deck may contain as many duplicatesof a card as are included with theproduct.

100.2c. Commander <#commander>`__`decks are subject to additionaldeckbuilding restrictions and`requirements <#requirement>`__. See rule`903 <#R903>`__, „Commander,”for details.

100.3. Some casual`variants <#variant>`__ require additionalitems, such as specially designated`cards <#card>`__, nontraditional Magiccards, and dice.See section 9, „Casual`Variants <#variant>`__.”

100.4. Each player mayalso have a sideboard, which isa group of additional cards the`player <#player>`__ may use to modify their`deck <#deck>`__ between games of a`match <#match>`__.

100.4a. In`constructed <#constructed>`__ play,a sideboard may contain no morethan fifteen cards. Thefour-card limit (see rule`100.2a <#R1002a>`__) applies to the combined`deck <#deck>`__ and sideboard.

100.4b. In limited <#limited>`__`play involving individual`players <#player>`__, all cards ina player’s cardpool not included in their`deck <#deck>`__ are in that`player <#player>`__’s`sideboard <#sideboard>`__.

100.4c. In limited <#limited>`__`play involving the Two-Headed Giantmultiplayer variant, all`cards <#card>`__ in a team’s cardpool but not in either`player <#player>`__’s deck are inthat team’s`sideboard <#sideboard>`__.

100.4d. In limited <#limited>`__`play involving other multiplayer`team <#team>`__ variants, each`card <#card>`__ in a team’s cardpool but not in any`player <#player>`__’s deck isassigned to the sideboard ofone of those players. Each`player <#player>`__ has their own`sideboard <#sideboard>`__; cards <#card>`__may not be transferred between`players.

100.5. If a deck mustcontain at least a certain number of`cards <#card>`__, that number is referred to asa minimum deck size.There is no maximum deck size fornon-Commander <#commander>`__`decks.

100.6. Most Magic`tournaments <#tournament>`__ (organized`play <#play>`__ activities where`players <#player>`__ compete against other`players <#player>`__ to win prizes) haveadditional rules covered in the Magic: TheGathering TournamentRules (found atWPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents).These rules may limit the use of some`cards <#card>`__, including barring all`cards <#card>`__ from some older sets.

100.6a. Tournaments <#tournament>`__usually consist of a series of`matches. A two-player <#player>`__`match usually involves playinguntil one player has won twogames. A multiplayer match usuallyconsists of only one game.

100.6b. Players can usethe Magic Store & Event Locator atWizards.com/Locator to find`tournaments <#tournament>`__ in their area.

100.7. Certain promotional`cards <#card>`__ and cards in theUnglued, Unhinged, and Unstable sets are printedwith a silver border. These cards <#card>`__are intended for casual `play and mayhave features and text that aren’t covered bythese rules.

101. The Magic Golden Rules

101.1. Whenever a card’stext directly contradicts these rules, the`card <#card>`__ takes precedence. The`card <#card>`__ overrides only the rule thatapplies to that specific situation. The onlyexception is that a player can`concede <#concede>`__ the game at any time (seerule 104.3a).

101.2. When a rule or`effect <#effect>`__ allows or directs somethingto happen, and another effect <#effect>`__states that it can’t happen, the „can’t”`effect takes precedence. Example:If oneeffectreads”Youmayplayanadditionallandthis turn” andanother reads”Youcan’tplaylandsthisturn,” theeffectthatprecludesyoufromplayinglandswins.

101.2a. Adding abilities <#ability>`__to `objects and removing`abilities <#ability>`__ from`objects <#object>`__ don’t fall under thisrule. (See rule 113.10.)

101.3. Any part of an instructionthat’s impossible to perform is ignored. (Inmany cases the card will specifyconsequences for this; if it doesn’t, there’s no`effect <#effect>`__.)

101.4. If multiple`players <#player>`__ would make choices and/ortake actions at the same time, the activeplayer (the`player <#player>`__ whose turn it is) makes anychoices required, then the next`player <#player>`__ in turn order (usually the`player <#player>`__ seated to the activeplayer’s left) makes anychoices required, followed by the remainingnonactive players in turn order.Then the actions happen simultaneously. Thisrule is often referred to as the „ActivePlayer, Nonactive`Player <#player>`__ (APNAP) order” rule.*Example: A*cardreads”Eachplayersacrificesacreature.”First, theactiveplayerchoosesacreaturetheycontrol.Then each of thenonactiveplayers, in turnorder, choosesacreaturetheycontrol.Then allcreatureschosenthis way are sacrificed simultaneously.

101.4a. If an effect haseach player choose a`card <#card>`__ in a hiddenzone, such as their`hand <#hand>`__ or library,those cards may remain facedown as they’re chosen. However,each player must clearly indicatewhich face-down card they arechoosing.

101.4b. A player knowsthe choices made by the previous`players <#player>`__ when making their choice,except as specified in 101.4a.

101.4c. If a player wouldmake more than one choice at the same time, the`player <#player>`__ makes the choices in theorder specified. If no order is specified, the`player <#player>`__ chooses the order.

101.4d. If a choice made by a nonactive`player <#player>`__ causes the activeplayer, or a differentnonactive player earlier in theturn order, to have to make a choice, APNAPorder is restarted for alloutstanding choices.

101.4e. If multiple`players <#player>`__ would make choices or takeactions while starting the game, the startingplayer is considered the`active player <#active_player>`__ and eachother player is considered anonactive player.

102. Players

102.1. A player is one ofthe people in the game. The activeplayer is the`player <#player>`__ whose turn it is. The other`players <#player>`__ are nonactive`players <#player>`__.

102.2. In a two-player <#player>`__game, a `player’s`opponent <#opponent>`__ is the other`player <#player>`__.

102.3. In a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, a player’s`teammates <#teammate>`__ are the other`players <#player>`__ on their team,and the player’s`opponents <#opponent>`__ are all`players <#player>`__ not on their`team <#team>`__.

102.4. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ may use the term”your team” asshorthand for „you and/or`your <#you_your>`__ teammates.”In a game that isn’t a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, „your <#you_your>`__`team” means the same thing as”you.”

103. Starting the Game

103.1. At the start of a game, the`players <#player>`__ determine which one ofthem will choose who takes the first turn. Inthe first game of a match <#match>`__(including a single-game `match),the players may use any mutuallyagreeable method (flipping acoin, rolling dice, etc.)to do so. In a match of severalgames, the loser of the previous game chooseswho takes the first turn. If the previous gamewas a draw, the player <#player>`__who made the choice in that game makes thechoice in this game. The `player <#player>`__chosen to take the first turn is the `startingplayer. The game’s defaultturn order begins with the startingplayer and proceedsclockwise.

103.1a. In a game using the sharedteam turnsoption, there isa starting team rather thana starting player.

103.1b. In an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game, these methodsaren’t used to determine who takes the firstturn. Rather, the `archenemy <#archenemy>`__takes the first turn.

103.1c. One card <#card>`__(`Power Play) statesthat its controller isthe starting player. This`effect <#effect>`__ applies after thisdetermination has happened and supersedes thesemethods.

103.2. After the startingplayer has beendetermined, each player <#player>`__`shuffles their deck <#deck>`__so that the `cards are in a randomorder. Each player may then`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ or cut their`opponents <#opponent>`__» decks.The players» decks <#deck>`__`become their`libraries <#library>`__.

103.2a. If a player isusing a sideboard (see rule`100.4 <#R1004>`__) or cards beingrepresented by substitutecards (see rule`713 <#R713>`__), those cards are`set aside <#set_aside>`__ before shuffling.

103.2b. If a player <#player>`__wishes to `reveal a`card <#card>`__ with a`companion <#companion>`__`ability <#ability>`__ that they own from`outside the game <#outside_the_game>`__, theymay do so after setting aside their`sideboard <#sideboard>`__. A`player <#player>`__ may reveal nomore than one card this way, andthey may do so only if their deck <#deck>`__fulfills the condition of that`card’s companion <#companion>`__`ability. (See rule`702.138 <#R702138>`__,”Companion.”)

103.2c. In a Commander <#commander>`__game, each `player puts their`commander <#commander>`__ from their`deck <#deck>`__ face up into the`command <#command>`__ zone afterhaving the opportunity to reveal a`card <#card>`__ with a`companion <#companion>`__`ability <#ability>`__ and before shuffling. Seerule 903.6.

103.2d. In a ConspiracyDraft game, each`player <#player>`__ puts any number of`conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__ cards <#card>`__from their `sideboard into the`command <#command>`__ zone beforeshuffling. See rule 905.4.

103.3. Each player beginsthe game with a starting lifetotal of 20. Some`variant <#variant>`__ games have different`starting life totals <#starting_life_total>`__.

103.3a. In a Two-Headed Giant game,each team’s starting lifetotal is 30.

103.3b. In a Vanguard <#vanguard>`__game, each `player’s starting lifetotal is 20 plus orminus the life modifier oftheir vanguard card.

103.3c. In a Commander <#commander>`__game, each `player’s starting lifetotal is 40.

103.3d. In a two-player <#player>`__`Brawl game, each`player <#player>`__’s starting lifetotal is 25. In amultiplayer Brawl game, each`player <#player>`__’s starting lifetotal is 30.

103.3e. In an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game, the`archenemy <#archenemy>`__’s starting lifetotal is 40.

103.4. Each player <#player>`__`draws a number of cards <#card>`__equal to their `starting handsize, which is normallyseven. (Some effects can modify a`player <#player>`__’s starting handsize.) A`player <#player>`__ who is dissatisfied withtheir initial hand may take a`mulligan <#mulligan>`__. First, the startingplayer declares whetherthey will take a mulligan. Theneach other player in turn orderdoes the same. Once each player <#player>`__has made a declaration, all`players who decided to take`mulligans <#mulligan>`__ do so at the sametime. To take a mulligan, a`player <#player>`__ shuffles the`cards <#card>`__ in their hand backinto their library,`draws <#draw>`__ a new hand of`cards <#card>`__ equal to their starting handsize, then puts anumber of those cards equal to thenumber of times that player hastaken a mulligan on the bottomof their library in any order.Once a player chooses not to takea mulligan, the remaining`cards <#card>`__ become that`player <#player>`__’s openinghand, and that`player <#player>`__ may not take any further`mulligans <#mulligan>`__. This process is thenrepeated until no player takes a`mulligan <#mulligan>`__. A player <#player>`__can take `mulligans until their`opening hand <#opening_hand>`__ would be zero`cards <#card>`__, after which they may not takefurther mulligans.

103.4a. In a Vanguard <#vanguard>`__game, each `player’s starting handsize is seven plus orminus the hand modifier oftheir vanguard card.

103.4b. If an effect <#effect>`__allows a `player to perform anaction „any time [that player]could mulligan,” the`player <#player>`__ may perform that action ata time they would declare whether they will takea mulligan. This need not be inthe first round of mulligans.Other players may have alreadymade their mulligan declarationsby the time the player has the`option <#option>`__ to perform this action. Ifthe player performs the action,they then declare whether they will take a`mulligan <#mulligan>`__.

103.4c. In a multiplayergame and in any`Brawl <#brawl>`__ game, the first`mulligan <#mulligan>`__ a player <#player>`__takes doesn’t count toward the number of`cards that player willput on the bottom of their`library <#library>`__ or the number of`mulligans <#mulligan>`__ that`player <#player>`__ may take. Subsequent`mulligans <#mulligan>`__ are counted towardthese numbers as normal.

103.4d. In a multiplayergame using the sharedteam turnsoption, firsteach player on the startingteam declares whether that`player <#player>`__ will take a`mulligan <#mulligan>`__, then the`players <#player>`__ on each other`team <#team>`__ in turn order do the same.`Teammates <#teammate>`__ may consult whilemaking their decisions. Then all`mulligans <#mulligan>`__ are taken at the sametime. A player may take a`mulligan <#mulligan>`__ even after a`teammate <#teammate>`__ has decided to keeptheir opening hand.

103.5. Some cards allow a`player <#player>`__ to take actions with themfrom their opening hand.Once the mulligan process (seerule 103.4) is complete, the`starting player <#starting_player>`__ may takeany such actions in any order. Then each other`player <#player>`__ in turn order may do thesame.

103.5a. If a card allows a`player <#player>`__ to begin the game with that`card <#card>`__ on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, the`player <#player>`__ taking this action putsthat card onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__.

103.5b. If a card allows a`player <#player>`__ to reveal itfrom their opening hand, the`player <#player>`__ taking this action does so.The card remains revealed until thefirst turn begins. Each card may berevealed this way only once.

103.5c. In a multiplayergame using the sharedteam turnsoption, firsteach player on the startingteam, in whatever order that`team <#team>`__ likes, may take such actions.`Teammates <#teammate>`__ may consult whilemaking their decisions. Then each`player <#player>`__ on each other`team <#team>`__ in turn order does the same.

103.6. In a`Planechase <#planechase>`__ game, the startingplayer moves <#move>`__the top `card of their planardeck off that planardeck and turns it faceup. If it’s a`phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__ card,the player puts that`card <#card>`__ on the bottom of their planardeck and repeats this processuntil a plane card isturned face up. The face-up`plane <#plane>`__ card <#card>`__`becomes the starting`plane <#plane>`__. (See rule 901,”Planechase.”)

103.7. The startingplayer takes their firstturn.

103.7a. In a two-player <#player>`__game, the `player who plays first`skips <#skip>`__ the draw step <#draw_step>`__(see rule `504, „DrawStep”) of their first turn.

103.7b. In a Two-Headed Giant game, the`team <#team>`__ who plays first`skips <#skip>`__ the `draw step <#draw_step>`__of their first turn.

103.7c. In all other multiplayergames, no`player <#player>`__ skips the drawstep of their first turn.

104. Ending the Game

104.1. A game ends immediately when a`player <#player>`__ wins, when the game is a`draw <#draw>`__, or when the game is restarted.

104.2. There are several ways to winthe game.

104.2a. A player still inthe game wins the game if that`player <#player>`__’s opponents <#opponent>`__have all left the game. This happens immediatelyand overrides all `effects thatwould preclude that player fromwinning the game.

104.2b. An effect maystate that a player wins the game.

104.2c. In a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, a team with atleast one player still in the gamewins the game if all other teams <#team>`__have left the game. Each `player onthe winning team wins the game, evenif one or more of those `players <#player>`__had previously lost that game.

104.2d. In an Emperor <#emperor>`__game, a `team wins the game if its`emperor <#emperor>`__ wins the game. (See rule`809.5 <#R8095>`__.)

104.3. There are several ways to losethe game.

104.3a. A player can`concede <#concede>`__ the game at any time. A`player <#player>`__ who concedes <#concede>`__leaves the game immediately. That`player loses the game.

104.3b. If a player’s`life total <#life_life_total>`__ is 0 or less,that player loses the game thenext time a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__. (This is a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704.)

104.3c. If a player isrequired to draw more`cards <#card>`__ than are left in their`library <#library>`__, they draw <#draw>`__the remaining `cards and then losethe game the next time a`player <#player>`__ would receive`priority <#priority>`__. (This is a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704.)

104.3d. If a player hasten or more poisoncounters, that`player <#player>`__ loses the game the nexttime a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__. (This is a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704.)

104.3e. An effect maystate that a player loses thegame.

104.3f. If a player wouldboth win and lose the game <#lose_the_game>`__simultaneously, that `player losesthe game.

104.3g. In a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, a team loses thegame if all players on that`team <#team>`__ have lost the game.

104.3h. In a multiplayergame using the limitedrange ofinfluence <#limited_range_of_influence>`__`option (see rule 801),an effect that states that a`player <#player>`__ wins the game`instead <#instead>`__ causes all of that`player <#player>`__’s opponents <#opponent>`__within the `player’s range ofinfluence to lose thegame. This may not cause thegame to end.

104.3i. In an Emperor <#emperor>`__game, a `team loses the game if its`emperor <#emperor>`__ loses the game. (See rule`809.5 <#R8095>`__.)

104.3j. In a Commander <#commander>`__game, a `player that’s been dealt21 or more combat damage bythe same commander over thecourse of the game loses the game. (This is a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704. See also rule`903.10 <#R90310>`__.)

104.3k. In a`tournament <#tournament>`__, a`player <#player>`__ may lose thegame as a result of apenalty given by a judge. See rule`100.6 <#R1006>`__.

104.4. There are several ways for thegame to be a draw.

104.4a. If all the`players <#player>`__ remaining in a game losesimultaneously, the game is a draw.

104.4b. If a game that’s not using the`limited range ofinfluence <#limited_range_of_influence>`__`option <#option>`__ (including atwo-player game) somehow enters a”loop” of mandatory actions,repeating a sequence of events withno way to stop, the game is a draw.`Loops <#loop>`__ that contain an optionalaction don’t result in a draw.

104.4c. An effect maystate that the game is a draw.

104.4d. In a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, the game is a`draw <#draw>`__ if all remaining`teams <#team>`__ lose simultaneously.

104.4e. In a multiplayergame using the limitedrange ofinfluence <#limited_range_of_influence>`__`option, the effect <#effect>`__of a `spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that states that the gameis a draw causes the game to be a`draw <#draw>`__ for that spell or`ability <#ability>`__’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ and all`players <#player>`__ within their range ofinfluence. Only those`players <#player>`__ leave the game; the gamecontinues for all other players.

104.4f. In a multiplayergame using the limitedrange ofinfluence <#limited_range_of_influence>`__`option, if the game somehow entersa „loop” of mandatory actions,repeating a sequence of events withno way to stop, the game is a draw <#draw>`__for each `player who`controls <#control_controller>`__ an`object <#object>`__ that’s involved in that`loop <#loop>`__, as well as for each`player <#player>`__ within the range ofinfluence of any ofthose players. Only those`players <#player>`__ leave the game; the gamecontinues for all other players.

104.4g. In a multiplayergame between`teams <#team>`__, the game is a`draw <#draw>`__ for a team if thegame is a draw for all remaining`players <#player>`__ on that team.

104.4h. In the Emperorvariant, the game is a`draw <#draw>`__ for a team if thegame is a draw for its`emperor <#emperor>`__. (See rule`809.5 <#R8095>`__.)

104.4i. In a`tournament <#tournament>`__, all`players <#player>`__ in the game may agree toan intentional draw. See rule`100.6 <#R1006>`__.

104.5. If a player losesthe game, that player leaves thegame. If the game is a draw for a`player <#player>`__, that player <#player>`__leaves the game. The multiplayer rules handlewhat happens when a `player leavesthe game; see rule 800.4.

104.6. One card (KarnLiberated) restarts the game. All`players <#player>`__ still in the game when itrestarts then immediately begin a new game. Seerule 719, „Restarting the Game.”

105. Colors

105.1. There are five`colors <#color>`__ in the Magic game: white,blue, black, red, and green.

105.2. An object can beone or more of the five colors, orit can be no color at all. An`object <#object>`__ is the color <#color>`__or `colors of the manasymbols in its manacost, regardless of the`color <#color>`__ of its frame. An`object <#object>`__’s color or`colors <#color>`__ may also be defined by a`color indicator <#color_indicator>`__ or a`characteristic-definingability <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__.See rule 202.2.

105.2a. A`monocolored <#monocolored>`__`object <#object>`__ is exactly one of the five`colors <#color>`__.

105.2b. A`multicolored <#multicolored>`__`object <#object>`__ is two or more of the five`colors <#color>`__.

105.2c. A colorless <#colorless>`__`object has no color.

105.3. Effects may changean object’s color orgive a color to a`colorless <#colorless>`__ object.If an effect gives an`object <#object>`__ a new color,the new color replaces all previous`colors <#color>`__ the object had(unless the effect <#effect>`__said the `object became that`color <#color>`__ „in addition” to its other`colors <#color>`__). Effects mayalso make a colored object <#object>`__`become <#becomes>`__`colorless.

105.4. If a player isasked to choose a color, they mustchoose one of the five colors.”Multicolored” is not a`color <#color>`__. Neither is”colorless.”

105.5. If an effect <#effect>`__refers to a `color pair, it meansexactly two of the five colors.There are ten color pairs: whiteand blue, white and black, blue and black, blueand red, black and red, black and green, red andgreen, red and white, green and white, and greenand blue.

106. Mana

106.1. Mana is the primaryresource in the game. Players <#player>`__spend `mana to pay <#pay>`__`costs, usually when casting`spells <#spell>`__ and activating`abilities <#ability>`__.

106.1a. There are five`colors <#color>`__ of mana: white,blue, black, red, and green.

106.1b. There are six types <#type>`__of `mana: white, blue, black, red,green, and colorless.

106.2. Mana is representedby mana symbols (see rule`107.4 <#R1074>`__). Manasymbols also represent manacosts (see rule`202 <#R202>`__).

106.3. Mana is produced bythe effects of manaabilities (see rule`605 <#R605>`__). It may also be produced by the`effects <#effect>`__ of spells, aswell as by the effects of`abilities <#ability>`__ that aren’t manaabilities. A`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__that produces `mana instructs a`player <#player>`__ to add that`mana <#mana>`__. If mana isproduced by a spell, the source ofthat mana is that`spell <#spell>`__. If mana isproduced by an ability, thesource of that mana is the source ofthat ability (see rule`113.7 <#R1137>`__).

106.4. When an effect <#effect>`__instructs a `player to add`mana <#mana>`__, that mana goesinto a player’s manapool. From there, it can be usedto pay costs immediately,or it can stay in the player’s`mana pool <#mana_pool>`__ as unspent`mana <#mana>`__. Each player’s`mana pool <#mana_pool>`__ empties at the end ofeach step and phase,and the player is said to losethis mana. Cards with`abilities <#ability>`__ that produce`mana <#mana>`__ or refer to unspent`mana <#mana>`__ have received errata in the`Oracle <#oracle>`__ (tm) card <#card>`__reference to no longer explicitly refer to the`mana pool.

106.4a. If any mana remainsin a player’s manapool after mana isspent to pay a cost, that`player <#player>`__ announces what`mana <#mana>`__ is still there.

106.4b. If a player <#player>`__`passes priority (seerule 117) while there is`mana <#mana>`__ in their manapool, that player <#player>`__announces what `mana is there.

106.5. If an ability <#ability>`__would produce one or more `mana of anundefined type, it produces no`mana <#mana>`__ instead.*Example: Meteor Crater hasthe*ability„{T}: Chooseacolorofapermanentyoucontrol.Add onemanaofthatcolor.”Ifyoucontrolnocoloredpermanents,activating Meteor Crater’smanaabilityproducesnomana.

106.6. Some spells or`abilities <#ability>`__ that produce`mana <#mana>`__ restrict how that`mana <#mana>`__ can be spent, have anadditional effect that affects the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__that `mana is spent on, or`create <#create>`__ a delayed triggeredability (seerule 603.7a) that`triggers <#trigger>`__ when that`mana <#mana>`__ is spent. This doesn’t affectthe mana’s type.*Example: A*player«smanapoolcontains {R}{G} which canbe spent onlytocastcreaturespells.ThatplayeractivatesDoublingCube’sability, which reads”{3}, {T}: Double the amount ofeachtypeofunspentmanayouhave.”Theplayer«smanapoolnow has {R}{R}{G}{G} init, {R}{G} of which can be spent on anything.

106.6a. Some replacementeffects increase theamount of mana produced by a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability. Inthese cases, any restrictions <#restriction>`__or additional `effects created bythe spell or ability <#ability>`__will apply to all `mana produced. Ifthe spell or ability <#ability>`__`creates a delayed triggeredability that`triggers <#trigger>`__ when the`mana <#mana>`__ is spent, a separate delayedtriggeredability iscreated for each mana produced. Ifthe spell or ability <#ability>`__`creates a continuouseffect or replacementeffect if the`mana <#mana>`__ is spent, a separate`effect <#effect>`__ is created once for each`mana <#mana>`__ produced.

106.7. Some abilities <#ability>`__produce `mana based on the`type <#type>`__ of mana another`permanent <#permanent>`__ or`permanents <#permanent>`__ „could produce.” The`type <#type>`__ of mana a`permanent <#permanent>`__ could produce at anytime includes any type of`mana <#mana>`__ that an ability <#ability>`__of that `permanent would produceif the ability were to`resolve <#resolve>`__ at that time, taking intoaccount any applicable replacementeffects in any possibleorder. Ignore whether any costs ofthe ability could or could not bepaid. If that permanent <#permanent>`__wouldn’t produce any `mana underthese conditions, or no type of`mana <#mana>`__ can be defined this way,there’s no type of mana <#mana>`__it could produce. *Example: Exotic Orchard hasthe*`ability„{T}: Addonemanaofanycolorthatalandanopponentcontrolscouldproduce.”Ifyouropponentcontrolsnolands,activating Exotic Orchard’smanaabilitywill producenomana. The same is trueifyouandyouropponenteachcontrolnolandsotherthan Exotic Orchards. However,ifyoucontrolaForestandan Exotic Orchard,andyouropponentcontrolsanExotic Orchard, then each Exotic Orchard couldproduce {G}.

106.8. If an effect wouldadd mana represented by a hybridmana symbol to a`player <#player>`__’s manapool, that player <#player>`__chooses one half of that symbol. If a coloredhalf is chosen, one `mana of that`color <#color>`__ is added to that`player <#player>`__’s manapool. If a generic half ischosen, an amount of colorless <#colorless>`__`mana represented by that half’snumber is added to that player’s`mana pool <#mana_pool>`__.

106.9. If an effect wouldadd mana represented by a Phyrexianmana symbol to a`player <#player>`__’s manapool, one mana ofthe color of that symbol is addedto that player’s manapool.

106.10. If an effect <#effect>`__would add `mana represented by a`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__ symbol to a`player <#player>`__’s manapool, that much`colorless <#colorless>`__ mana isadded to that player’s manapool.

106.11. If an effect <#effect>`__would add `mana represented by one ormore snow mana symbols <#snow_mana_symbol>`__to a `player’s manapool, that much`colorless <#colorless>`__ mana isadded to that player’s manapool.

106.12. To „tap [a`permanent <#permanent>`__] for`mana <#mana>`__” is to activate <#activate>`__a `mana ability of that`permanent <#permanent>`__ that includes the {T}symbol in its activationcost. See rule`605 <#R605>`__, „ManaAbilities.”

106.12a. An ability that`triggers <#trigger>`__ whenever a`permanent <#permanent>`__ „is`tapped <#tapped>`__ for mana” or is`tapped <#tapped>`__ for mana of aspecified type <#type>`__`triggers whenever such a manaability <#mana_ability>`__`resolves and produces`mana <#mana>`__ or the specified`type <#type>`__ of mana.

106.12b. A replacementeffect that applies ifa permanent „is`tapped <#tapped>`__ for mana” or`tapped <#tapped>`__ for mana of aspecific type and/or amount modifiesthe mana production`event <#event>`__ while such an`ability <#ability>`__ is resolving andproducing mana or the specified`type <#type>`__ and/or amount of`mana <#mana>`__.

106.13. One card (Drain`Power <#power>`__) causes one`player <#player>`__ to lose unspent`mana <#mana>`__ and another to add „the`mana <#mana>`__ lost this way.” (Note thatthese may be the same player.)This empties the former player’s`mana pool <#mana_pool>`__ and causes the`mana <#mana>`__ emptied this way to be put intothe latter player’s manapool. Which`permanents <#permanent>`__,`spells <#spell>`__, and/or`abilities <#ability>`__ produced that`mana <#mana>`__ are unchanged, as are any`restrictions <#restriction>`__ or additional`effects <#effect>`__ associated with any ofthat mana.

107. Numbers and Symbols

107.1. The only numbers the Magic gameuses are integers.

107.1a. You can’tchoose a fractional number, deal <#deal>`__fractional `damage, gain fractional`life <#life_life_total>`__, and so on. If a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__could generate a fractional number, the`spell or ability <#ability>`__will tell `you whether to roundup or down.

107.1b. Most of the time, the Magicgame uses only positive numbers and zero.`You <#you_your>`__ can’t choose a negativenumber, deal negative`damage <#damage>`__, gain negative`life <#life_life_total>`__, and so on. However,it’s possible for a game value, such as a`creature <#creature>`__’s power,to be less than zero. If a calculation orcomparison needs to use a negative value, itdoes so. If a calculation that would determinethe result of an effect yields anegative number, zero is used`instead <#instead>`__, unless <#unless>`__that `effect doubles or sets to aspecific value a player’s lifetotal or the`power <#power>`__ and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ of a`creature <#creature>`__ or`creature <#creature>`__ card.*Example: If a3/4*creaturegets -5/-0,it’s a -2/4creature. Itdoesn’t assigndamageincombat. Itstotalpowerandtoughnessis2. Giving it +3/+0 would raiseitspowerto 1. Example:Viridian Joiner is a1/2creaturewiththeability„{T}: Add anamount of {G} equal to ViridianJoiner’spower.”Aneffectgives it -2/-0, thenitsabilityis activated.Theabilityaddsnomanatoyourmanapool. Example: ChameleonColossus is a4/4creaturewiththeability„{2}{G}{G}:Chameleon Colossus gets+*`X <#x>`__*/+*`X <#x>`__*until endof turn, whereXisitspower.”Aneffectgives it -6/-0, thenitsabilityis activated. Itremains a -2/4creature. Itdoesn’tbecome-4/2.

107.1c. If a rule or`ability <#ability>`__ instructs a`player <#player>`__ to choose „any number,”that player may choose anypositive number or zero.

107.2. If anything needs to use anumber that can’t be determined, either as aresult or in a calculation, it uses 0`instead <#instead>`__.

107.3. Many objects usethe letter X as a placeholder for anumber that needs to be determined. Some`objects <#object>`__ have`abilities <#ability>`__ that define the valueof X; the rest let their`controller <#control_controller>`__ choose thevalue of X.

107.3a. If a spell or`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ has a`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__, alternativecost, additionalcost, and/or activationcost with an {X},[-X], or X in it, and thevalue of X isn’t defined by the text ofthat spell or`ability <#ability>`__, the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__chooses and announces the value of `X aspart of casting the spell oractivating the ability. (See rule`601 <#R601>`__, „Casting Spells.”)While a spell is on the`stack <#stack>`__, any X in its manacost or in any alternativecost or additionalcost it has equals theannounced value. While an activatedability is on the`stack <#stack>`__, any X in its`activation cost <#activation_cost>`__ equalsthe announced value.

107.3b. If a player iscasting a spell that has an{X} in its mana cost,the value of X isn’t defined by thetext of that spell, and an`effect <#effect>`__ lets that`player <#player>`__ cast that`spell <#spell>`__ while paying neither its`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__ nor an alternativecost that includes`X <#x>`__, then the only legal choice for`X <#x>`__ is 0. This doesn’t apply to`effects <#effect>`__ that only reduce a`cost <#cost>`__, even if they reduce it tozero. See rule 601, „Casting`Spells <#spell>`__.”

107.3c. If a spell or`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ hasan {X}, [-X], or X inits cost and/or its text, and thevalue of X is defined by the text ofthat spell or`ability <#ability>`__, then that’s the value of`X <#x>`__ while that spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is on the`stack <#stack>`__. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__doesn’t get to choose the value. Note that thevalue of `X may change while that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability ison the stack.

107.3d. If a cost <#cost>`__associated with a `specialaction, such as a`suspend <#suspend>`__ cost or a`morph <#morph>`__ cost, has an{X} or an X in it, the valueof X is chosen by the`player <#player>`__ taking the specialaction immediately beforethey pay that cost.

107.3e. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ refers to the{X} or X in the manacost, alternativecost, additionalcost, or activationcost of another`object <#object>`__, any X in that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability’stext uses the value of X chosen ordefined for the other object.

107.3f. Sometimes X appears inthe text of a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ but not in a manacost, alternativecost, additionalcost, or activationcost. If the value of`X <#x>`__ isn’t defined, the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__chooses the value of `X at theappropriate time (either as it’s put on the`stack <#stack>`__ or as it`resolves <#resolve>`__).

107.3g. If a card in any`zone <#zone>`__ other than the`stack <#stack>`__ has an {X} in its`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__, the value of{X} is treated as 0, even if the valueof X is defined somewhere within itstext.

107.3h. If an effect <#effect>`__instructs a `player to`pay <#pay>`__ an object’s manacost that includes {X},the value of X is treated as 0`unless <#unless>`__ the object isa spell on the stack.In that case, the value of X is thevalue chosen or determined for it as the`spell <#spell>`__ was cast.

107.3i. Normally, all instances of`X <#x>`__ on an object have thesame value at any given time.

107.3j. If an object <#object>`__gains an `ability, the value of`X <#x>`__ within that ability isthe value defined by that`ability <#ability>`__, or 0 if that`ability <#ability>`__ doesn’t define a value of`X <#x>`__. This is an exception to rule`107.3i <#R1073i>`__. This may occur with`ability <#ability>`__-adding`effects <#effect>`__, text-changingeffects, or`copy <#copy>`__ effects.

107.3k. If an object’s`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ hasan {X}, [-X], or X inits activation cost, thevalue of X for that`ability <#ability>`__ is`independent <#independent>`__ of any othervalues of X chosen for that`object <#object>`__ or for other instances of`abilities <#ability>`__ of that`object <#object>`__. This is an exception torule 107.3i.

107.3m. If an object’senters-the-battlefield <#battlefield>`__`triggered ability or`replacement effect <#replacement_effect>`__refers to X, and the spell <#spell>`__that became that `object as itresolved had a value of X chosen forany of its costs, the value of`X <#x>`__ for that ability isthe same as the value of X for that`spell <#spell>`__, although the value of`X <#x>`__ for that permanent <#permanent>`__is 0. This is an exception to rule`107.3i.

107.3n. Some objects usethe letter Y in addition to the letter`X <#x>`__. Y follows the same rules as`X <#x>`__.

107.4. The manasymbols are {W}, {U}, {B},{R}, {G}, and {C}; the numerical symbols {0},{1}, {2}, {3}, {4}, and so on; the variablesymbol {X}; the hybrid symbols {W/U},{W/B}, {U/B}, {U/R}, {B/R}, {B/G}, {R/G}, {R/W},{G/W}, and {G/U}; the`monocolored <#monocolored>`__ hybrid symbols{2/W}, {2/U}, {2/B}, {2/R}, and {2/G}; the`Phyrexian manasymbols <#phyrexian_mana_symbol>`__ {W/P},{U/P}, {B/P}, {R/P}, and {G/P}; and the snowmana symbol {S}.

107.4a. There are five primary colored`mana symbols <#mana_symbol>`__: {W} is white,{U} blue, {B} black, {R} red, and {G} green.These symbols are used to represent colored`mana <#mana>`__, and also to represent colored`mana <#mana>`__ in costs. Colored`mana <#mana>`__ in costs can bepaid only with the appropriate`color <#color>`__ of mana. See rule`202 <#R202>`__, „Mana Cost and`Color <#color>`__.”

107.4b. Numerical symbols (such as {1})and variable symbols (such as {X})represent generic mana in`costs <#cost>`__. Genericmana in costs canbe paid with any type of`mana <#mana>`__. For more information about{X}, see rule 107.3.

107.4c. The colorless <#colorless>`__`mana symbol {C} is used torepresent one colorless <#colorless>`__`mana, and also to represent a`cost <#cost>`__ that can be paid only with one`colorless <#colorless>`__ mana.

107.4d. The symbol {0} represents zero`mana <#mana>`__ and is used as a placeholderfor a cost that can be paid with noresources. (See rule 118.5.)

107.4e. Hybrid manasymbols are alsocolored mana symbols. Eachone represents a cost that can bepaid in one of two ways, as represented by thetwo halves of the symbol. A hybrid symbol suchas {W/U} can be paid with either white or blue`mana <#mana>`__, and a`monocolored <#monocolored>`__ hybrid symbolsuch as {2/B} can be paid with either one black`mana <#mana>`__ or two mana of any`type <#type>`__. A hybrid manasymbol is all of itscomponent colors. Example:{G/W}{G/W} can be paid by spending {G}{G},{G}{W}, or {W}{W}.

107.4f. Phyrexian manasymbols are colored`mana symbols <#mana_symbol>`__: {W/P} is white,{U/P} is blue, {B/P} is black, {R/P} is red, and{G/P} is green. A Phyrexian manasymbol represents a`cost <#cost>`__ that can be paid either withone mana of its color <#color>`__or by paying 2 `life.*Example: {W/P}{W/P} can be paid by spending{W}{W}, by spending {W} and paying2*life, or by paying4life.

107.4g. In rulestext, the Phyrexiansymbol {P} with nocolored background means any of the five`Phyrexian manasymbols <#phyrexian_mana_symbol>`__.

107.4h. When used in a`cost <#cost>`__, the snow manasymbol {S} represents a`cost <#cost>`__ that can be paid with one`mana <#mana>`__ of any type <#type>`__produced by a `snow source (see rule`106.3 <#R1063>`__). Effects thatreduce the amount of genericmana you <#you_your>`__`pay don’t affect {S}`costs <#cost>`__. The {S} symbol can also beused to refer to mana of any`type <#type>`__ produced by a snow <#snow>`__source spent to `pay a`cost <#cost>`__. Snow is neither a`color <#color>`__ nor a type of`mana <#mana>`__.

107.5. The tap symbol <#tap_symbol>`__is {T}. The `tap symbol in an`activation cost <#activation_cost>`__ means”Tap this`permanent <#permanent>`__.” A`permanent <#permanent>`__ that’s already`tapped <#tapped>`__ can’t be`tapped <#tapped>`__ again to pay the`cost <#cost>`__. A creature’s`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ withthe tap symbol in its`activation cost <#activation_cost>`__ can’t beactivated unless the`creature <#creature>`__ has been under its`controller <#control_controller>`__’s`control <#control_controller>`__ continuouslysince their most recent turn began. See rule`302.6 <#R3026>`__.

107.6. The untapsymbol is {Q}. The untapsymbol in an activationcost means”Untap this`permanent <#permanent>`__.” A`permanent <#permanent>`__ that’s already`untapped <#untapped>`__ can’t be`untapped <#untapped>`__ again to pay <#pay>`__the `cost. A`creature <#creature>`__’s activatedability with the untapsymbol in its activationcost can’t be activated`unless <#unless>`__ the`creature <#creature>`__ has been under its`controller <#control_controller>`__’s`control <#control_controller>`__ continuouslysince their most recent turn began. See rule`302.6 <#R3026>`__.

107.7. Each activatedability of a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ has a`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ symbol in its`cost <#cost>`__. Positive`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ symbols point upward andfeature a plus sign followed by a number.Negative loyalty symbols pointdownward and feature a minus sign followed by anumber or an X. Neutral`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ symbols don’t point ineither direction and feature a 0. [+N] means”Put N loyalty <#loyalty>`__`counters on this`permanent <#permanent>`__,” [-N] means „RemoveN loyalty counters <#counter>`__from this `permanent,” and [0]means „Put zero loyalty <#loyalty>`__`counters on this`permanent <#permanent>`__.”

107.8. The text box ofa leveler card contains two`level symbols <#level_symbol>`__, each of whichis a keyword ability thatrepresents a staticability. The levelsymbol includes either arange of numbers, indicated here as „N1-N2,” ora single number followed by a plus sign,indicated here as „N3+.” Any`abilities <#ability>`__ printed within the same`text box <#text_box>`__ striation as a levelsymbol are part of its`static ability <#static_ability>`__. The sameis true of the`power <#power>`__/toughness <#toughness>`__box printed within that striation, indicatedhere as „[P/T].” See rule `710,”Leveler Cards.”

107.8a. „{LEVEL N1-N2}[Abilities] [P/T]” means „As longas this creature has at least N1level counters on it, but no morethan N2 level counters on it, ithas base power <#base_power_base_toughness>`__and `toughness [P/T] and has[abilities].”

107.8b. „{LEVEL N3+}[Abilities] [P/T]” means „As longas this creature has N3 or morelevel counters on it, it has`base power <#base_power_base_toughness>`__ and`toughness <#toughness>`__ [P/T] and has[abilities].”

107.9. A tombstoneicon appears to the left ofthe name of many Odyssey (tm)`block <#block>`__ cards with`abilities <#ability>`__ that are relevant in a`player <#player>`__’s`graveyard <#graveyard>`__. The purpose of theicon is to make those cards standout when they’re in a`graveyard <#graveyard>`__. This icon has no`effect <#effect>`__ on game play.

107.10. A type icon <#type_icon>`__appears in the upper left corner of each`card from the Future Sight(r) setprinted with an alternate „timeshifted” frame.If the card has a single cardtype, this icon indicates whatit is: claw marks for creature,a flame for sorcery, a lightningbolt for instant, a sunrise for`enchantment <#enchantment>`__, a chalice for`artifact <#artifact>`__, and a pair of`mountain <#mountain>`__ peaks for`land <#land>`__. If the card hasmultiple card types, that’sindicated by a black and white cross. This iconhas no effect on game`play <#play>`__.

107.11. The Planeswalkersymbol is {PW}. Itappears on one face of the planardie used in the`Planechase <#planechase>`__ casual`variant <#variant>`__. See rule`901 <#R901>`__, „Planechase.”

107.12. The chaossymbol is {CHAOS}. It appearson one face of the planar die <#planar_die>`__used in the `Planechase casual`variant <#variant>`__, as well as in`abilities <#ability>`__ that refer to theresults of rolling the planardie. See rule 901,”Planechase.”

107.13. A colorindicator is a circularsymbol that appears to the left of the typeline on some cards.The color of the symbol defines the`card <#card>`__’s color or`colors <#color>`__. See rule 202,”Mana Cost and`Color <#color>`__.”

107.14. The energysymbol is {E}. It representsone energy counter. To`pay <#pay>`__ {E}, a player <#player>`__removes one energy `counter fromthemselves.

107.15. The text box ofa Saga card containschapter symbols, each of which is a keywordability that represents a`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__. Achapter symbol includes a Roman numeral,indicated here as „rN”. The text printed in the`text box <#text_box>`__ striation to the rightof a chapter symbol is the effect <#effect>`__of the `triggeredability it represents.See rule 714, „Saga <#saga>`__`Cards.”

107.15a. „{rN}–[Effect]”means „When one or more lore`counters <#counter>`__ are put onto this`Saga <#saga>`__, if the number of lore`counters <#counter>`__ on it was less than Nand became at least N, [effect].”

107.15b. „{rN1},{rN2}–[Effect]” is the same as”{rN1}–[Effect]” and”{rN2}–[Effect].”

108. Cards

108.1. Use the Oracle <#oracle>`__`card reference when determining a`card <#card>`__’s wording. A card’s`Oracle <#oracle>`__ text can be found using theGatherer card database at`Gatherer.Wizards.com <http://gatherer.wizards.com/>`__.

108.2. When a rule or text on a`card <#card>`__ refers to a „card,”it means only a Magic card or an`object <#object>`__ represented by a Magic`card <#card>`__.

108.2a. Most Magic games use only`traditional Magiccards <#traditional_magic_card>`__, whichmeasure approximately 2.5 inches (6.3 cm) by 3.5inches (8.8 cm). Certain formats also use`nontraditional Magiccards <#nontraditional_magic_card>`__, oversized`cards <#card>`__ that may have different backs.

108.2b. Tokens aren’tconsidered cards–even a`card <#card>`__-sized game supplement thatrepresents a token isn’t considereda card for rules purposes.

108.3. The owner of a`card <#card>`__ in the game is the`player <#player>`__ who started the game withit in their deck. If a`card <#card>`__ is brought into the game from`outside the game <#outside_the_game>`__ ratherthan starting in a player’s`deck <#deck>`__, its owner is the`player <#player>`__ who brought it into thegame. If a card starts the game inthe command zone, its`owner <#owner>`__ is the player <#player>`__who put it into the `command <#command>`__`zone to start the game. Legalownership of a card in the game isirrelevant to the game rules except for therules for ante. (See rule`407. <#R407>`__)

108.3a. In a`Planechase <#planechase>`__ game using thesingle planar deck <#planar_deck>`__`option, the planar`controller <#control_controller>`__ isconsidered to be the owner of all`cards <#card>`__ in the planardeck. See rule`901.6 <#R9016>`__.

108.3b. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ allow a`player <#player>`__ to take cards <#card>`__they own from `outside thegame and bring them intothe game. (See rule 400.11b.) Ifa card outside that game is involvedin a Magic game, its owner isdetermined as described in rule`108.3 <#R1083>`__. If a card <#card>`__outside that game is in the`sideboard of a Magic game (seerule 100.4), its owner <#owner>`__is considered to be the `player whostarted the game with it in their`sideboard <#sideboard>`__. In all other cases,the owner of a card <#card>`__`outside the game is itslegal owner.

108.4. A card doesn’t havea controller <#control_controller>`__`unless that card <#card>`__represents a `permanent or`spell <#spell>`__; in those cases, its`controller <#control_controller>`__ isdetermined by the rules for`permanents <#permanent>`__ or`spells <#spell>`__. See rules`110.2 <#R1102>`__ and 112.2.

108.4a. If anything asks for the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`card <#card>`__ that doesn’t have one (becauseit’s not a permanent or`spell <#spell>`__), use its owner <#owner>`__`instead.

108.5. Nontraditional Magiccards can’tstart the game in any zone otherthan the command zone <#zone>`__(see rule `408). If an`effect <#effect>`__ would bring a`nontraditional Magiccard <#nontraditional_magic_card>`__ into thegame from outside thegame, it doesn’t; that`card <#card>`__ remains outside thegame.

108.6. For more information about`cards <#card>`__, see section 2,”Parts of a Card.”

109. Objects

109.1. An object is an`ability <#ability>`__ on the`stack <#stack>`__, a card, a`copy <#copy>`__ of a card, a`token <#token>`__, a spell, a`permanent <#permanent>`__, or an`emblem <#emblem>`__.

109.2. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ uses a description of an`object <#object>`__ that includes a cardtype or subtype,but doesn’t include the word „card,””spell,” „source,” or”scheme,” it means a`permanent <#permanent>`__ of that cardtype or subtype <#subtype>`__on the `battlefield.

109.2a. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ uses a description of an`object <#object>`__ that includes the word”card” and the name of a`zone <#zone>`__, it means a card <#card>`__matching that description in the stated`zone.

109.2b. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ uses a description of an`object <#object>`__ that includes the word”spell,” it means a`spell <#spell>`__ matching that description onthe stack.

109.2c. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ uses a description of an`object <#object>`__ that includes the word”source,” it means a source matching thatdescription–a source of anability, of`damage <#damage>`__, or of mana–inany zone. See rules`113.7 <#R1137>`__ and 609.7.

109.2d. If an ability ofa scheme card includesthe text „this scheme,” it meansthe scheme card in the`command <#command>`__ zone on whichthat ability is printed.

109.3. An object’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ are`name <#name>`__, mana cost,`color <#color>`__, colorindicator, cardtype, subtype,`supertype <#supertype>`__, rulestext, abilities,`power <#power>`__, toughness,`loyalty <#loyalty>`__, handmodifier, and lifemodifier.`Objects <#object>`__ can have some or all ofthese characteristics.Any other information about an`object <#object>`__ isn’t a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__. Forexample, characteristics <#characteristics>`__don’t include whether a`permanent is`tapped <#tapped>`__, a spell’s`target <#target>`__, an object’s`owner <#owner>`__ or`controller <#control_controller>`__, what an`Aura <#aura>`__ enchants, and soon.

109.4. Only objects onthe stack or on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ have a`controller <#control_controller>`__.`Objects <#object>`__ that are neither on the`stack <#stack>`__ nor on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ aren’t controlledby any player. See rule`108.4 <#R1084>`__. There are six exceptions tothis rule:

109.4a. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a manaability is determined asthough it were on the`stack <#stack>`__. See rule 605,”Mana Abilities.”

109.4b. An emblem iscontrolled by the player that putsit into the command <#command>`__`zone. See rule 114,”Emblems.”

109.4c. In a`Planechase <#planechase>`__ game, a face-up`plane <#plane>`__ or`phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__ card iscontrolled by the player <#player>`__designated as the planar`controller. This isusually the active player.See rule 901.6.

109.4d. In a Vanguard <#vanguard>`__game, each `vanguard <#vanguard>`__`card is controlled by its`owner <#owner>`__. See rule 902.6.

109.4e. In an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game, each`scheme <#scheme>`__ card iscontrolled by its owner. See rule`904.7 <#R9047>`__.

109.4f. In a ConspiracyDraft game, each`conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__ card iscontrolled by its owner. See rule`905.5 <#R9055>`__.

109.5. The words „you”and „your” on an`object <#object>`__ refer to the`object <#object>`__’s`controller <#control_controller>`__, itswould-be controller <#control_controller>`__(if a `player is attempting to`play <#play>`__, cast, or`activate <#activate>`__ it), or its`owner <#owner>`__ (if it has no`controller <#control_controller>`__). For a`static ability <#static_ability>`__, this isthe current controller <#control_controller>`__of the `object it’s on. For an`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__, thisis the player who activated the`ability <#ability>`__. For a triggeredability, this is the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`object <#object>`__ when the`ability <#ability>`__ triggered,`unless <#unless>`__ it’s a delayed triggeredability. Todetermine the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`delayed triggeredability <#delayed_triggered_ability>`__, seerules 603.7d-f.

110. Permanents

110.1. A permanent isa card or token on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. A`permanent <#permanent>`__ remains on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ indefinitely. A`card <#card>`__ or token <#token>`__`becomes a`permanent <#permanent>`__ as it enters thebattlefield and itstops being a permanent as it’smoved to another zone by an`effect <#effect>`__ or rule.

110.2. A permanent’s`owner <#owner>`__ is the same as the`owner <#owner>`__ of the card thatrepresents it (unless it’s a`token <#token>`__; see rule`111.2 <#R1112>`__). A`permanent <#permanent>`__’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ is, bydefault, the player under whose`control <#control_controller>`__ it entered the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. Every`permanent <#permanent>`__ has a`controller <#control_controller>`__.

110.2a. If an effect <#effect>`__instructs a `player to put an`object <#object>`__ onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, that`object <#object>`__ enters thebattlefield underthat player’s`control <#control_controller>`__`unless <#unless>`__ the `effect <#effect>`__states otherwise.

110.2b. If an effect <#effect>`__causes a `player to gain`control <#control_controller>`__ of another`player <#player>`__’s permanentspell, the first`player <#player>`__`controls <#control_controller>`__ the`permanent <#permanent>`__ that`spell <#spell>`__ becomes, butthe permanent’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ by defaultis the player who put that`spell <#spell>`__ onto the stack.(This distinction is relevant in multiplayergames; see rule`800.4c <#R8004c>`__.)

110.3. A nontoken`permanent <#permanent>`__’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ are thesame as those printed on its card,as modified by any continuouseffects. See rule`613 <#R613>`__, „Interaction of ContinuousEffects.”

110.4. There are five`permanent <#permanent>`__ types:artifact,`creature <#creature>`__,`enchantment <#enchantment>`__,`land <#land>`__, and`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__.`Instant <#instant>`__ and`sorcery <#sorcery>`__ cards can’tenter the battlefield andthus can’t be permanents. Some`tribal <#tribal>`__ cards can enterthe battlefield and somecan’t, depending on their other cardtypes. See section 3,”Card Types.”

110.4a. The term „permanentcard” is used to refer to a`card <#card>`__ that could be put onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. Specifically, itmeans an artifact,`creature <#creature>`__,`enchantment <#enchantment>`__,`land <#land>`__, or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__`card <#card>`__.

110.4b. The term „permanentspell” is used to refer toa spell that will enter the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ as a`permanent <#permanent>`__ as part of itsresolution. Specifically, it means an`artifact <#artifact>`__,`creature <#creature>`__,`enchantment <#enchantment>`__, or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__`spell <#spell>`__.

110.4c. If a permanent <#permanent>`__somehow loses all its `permanent <#permanent>`__`types, it remains on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. It’s still a`permanent <#permanent>`__.

110.5. A permanent’s`status <#status>`__ is its physical state.There are four status categories,each of which has two possible values:tapped/untapped,`flipped <#flipped>`__/unflipped,`face up <#face_up>`__/facedown, and phasedin/phasedout. Each`permanent <#permanent>`__ always has one ofthese values for each of these categories.

110.5a. Status is not a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__, though itmay affect a permanent’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__.

110.5b. Permanents <#permanent>`__enter the `battlefield <#battlefield>`__`untapped,`unflipped <#unflipped>`__, faceup, and phasedin <#phased_in_phased_out>`__`unless a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ says otherwise.

110.5c. A permanent <#permanent>`__retains its `status until a`spell <#spell>`__, ability, or`turn-based action <#turn-based_actions>`__changes it, even if that status isnot relevant to it. Example: Dimir Doppelgangersays”{1}{U}{B}:Exiletargetcreaturecardfromagraveyard. DimirDoppelgangerbecomesacopyofthatcardand gainsthisability.”ItbecomesacopyofJushi Apprentice, aflipcard. Through use of JushiApprentice’sability,thiscreatureflips, makingit acopyof Tomoya the Revealerwith the DimirDoppelgangerability. IfthispermanentthenbecomesacopyofRuneclaw Bear, it will retainitsflippedstatuseventhough that has no relevance to Runeclaw Bear.Ifitscopyabilityisactivated again, this time targeting a NezumiShortfangcard(anotherflipcard),thispermanent«sflippedstatusmeansit will havethecharacteristicsofStabwhisker the Odious(theflippedversion ofNezumi Shortfang) with the DimirDoppelgangerability.

110.5d. Only`permanents <#permanent>`__ have`status <#status>`__. Cards not onthe battlefield do not.Although an exiled card may be facedown, this has no correlation tothe face-down status of a`permanent <#permanent>`__. Similarly,`cards <#card>`__ not on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ are neither`tapped <#tapped>`__ nor`untapped <#untapped>`__, regardless of theirphysical state.

111. Tokens

111.1. Some effects put`tokens <#token>`__ onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. A`token <#token>`__ is a marker used to representany permanent that isn’trepresented by a card.

111.2. The player who`creates <#create>`__ a token isits owner. The token <#token>`__`enters thebattlefield underthat player’s`control <#control_controller>`__.

111.3. The spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that`creates <#create>`__ a token maydefine the values of any number of`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ for the`token <#token>`__. This becomes <#becomes>`__the `token’s „text.” The`characteristic <#characteristics>`__ valuesdefined this way are functionally equivalent tothe characteristic valuesthat are printed on a card; forexample, they define the token’s`copiable values <#copiable_values>`__. A`token <#token>`__ doesn’t have any`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ notdefined by the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that created it.*Example: Jade Mage hasthe*ability„{2}{G}:Createa1/1 greenSaprolingcreaturetoken.”The resultingtokenhasnomanacost,supertypes,rulestext,orabilities.

111.4. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that`creates <#create>`__ a token setsboth its name and its`subtype <#subtype>`__(s). If the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__doesn’t specify the `name of the`token <#token>`__, its name is thesame as its subtype(s). A”Goblin Scout creature <#creature>`__`token,” for example, is named”Goblin Scout” and has the`creature <#creature>`__ subtypes <#subtype>`__Goblin and Scout. Once a `token ison the battlefield, changingits name doesn’t change its`subtype <#subtype>`__, and vice versa.

111.5. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ would`create <#create>`__ a token, but arule or effect states that a`permanent <#permanent>`__ with one or more ofthat token’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ can’tenter the battlefield, the`token <#token>`__ is not created.

111.6. A token is subjectto anything that affects`permanents <#permanent>`__ in`general <#general>`__ or that affects the`token <#token>`__’s card type <#card_type>`__or `subtype. A token <#token>`__isn’t a `card (even if represented bya card that has a Magic back or thatcame from a Magic boosterpack).

111.7. A token that’s in a`zone <#zone>`__ other than the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ ceases to exist.This is a state-basedaction; see rule`704. <#R704>`__ (Note that if a`token <#token>`__ changes zones,applicable triggeredabilities will`trigger <#trigger>`__ before the`token <#token>`__ ceases to exist.)

111.8. A token that hasleft the battlefield can’t`move <#move>`__ to another zone orcome back onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. If such a`token <#token>`__ would change`zones <#zone>`__, it remains in its current`zone <#zone>`__ instead. Itceases to exist the next time state-basedactions are checked;see rule 704.

111.9. Some effects <#effect>`__instruct a `player to`create <#create>`__ a`legendary <#legendary>`__ token.These may be written „create <#create>`__[`name], a …” and list`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ for the`token <#token>`__. This is the same as aninstruction to create a`token <#token>`__ with the listed`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ that hasthe given name.

111.10. Some effects <#effect>`__instruct a `player to`create <#create>`__ a predefined`token <#token>`__. These effects <#effect>`__use the definition below to determine the`characteristics the`token <#token>`__ is created with. The`effect <#effect>`__ that creates <#create>`__a predefined `token may also modifyor add to the predefined`characteristics <#characteristics>`__.

111.10a. A Treasuretoken is a`colorless <#colorless>`__ Treasure`artifact <#artifact>`__ token with”{T}, Sacrifice this`artifact <#artifact>`__: Add one`mana <#mana>`__ of any color.”

111.10b. A Food token <#food_token>`__is a `colorless Food`artifact <#artifact>`__ token with”{2}, {T}, Sacrifice this`artifact <#artifact>`__: You <#you_your>`__gain 3 `life.”

111.10c. A Gold token <#gold_token>`__is a `colorless Gold`artifact <#artifact>`__ token with”Sacrifice this`artifact <#artifact>`__: Add one`mana <#mana>`__ of any color.”

111.10d. A Walkertoken is a 2/2 black Zombie`creature <#creature>`__ `token <#token>`__named Walker.

111.10e. A Shardtoken is a`colorless <#colorless>`__`enchantment <#enchantment>`__`token <#token>`__ with „{2},`Sacrifice <#sacrifice>`__ this`enchantment <#enchantment>`__: Scry <#scry>`__1, then `draw a card.”

111.11. A copy of a`permanent spell <#permanent_spell>`__`becomes <#becomes>`__ a token asit resolves. The`token <#token>`__ has the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ of the`spell <#spell>`__ that became that`token <#token>`__. The token isnot „created” for the purposes of any`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__ or`triggered abilities <#triggered_ability>`__that refer to creating a token.

112. Spells

112.1. A spell is a`card <#card>`__ on the stack. Asthe first step of being`cast <#cast>`__ (see rule 601,”Casting Spells”), the`card <#card>`__ becomes a`spell <#spell>`__ and is moved to the top ofthe stack from the zone <#zone>`__it was in, which is usually its`owner’s hand. (See rule`405 <#R405>`__, „Stack.”) A`spell <#spell>`__ remains on the`stack <#stack>`__ as a spell untilit resolves (see rule`608 <#R608>`__, „Resolving Spells <#spell>`__and `Abilities”), is countered(see rule 701.5), or otherwiseleaves the stack. For moreinformation, see section 6,”Spells, Abilities,and Effects.”

112.1a. A copy of a`spell <#spell>`__ is also a spell,even if it has no card associatedwith it. See rule 706.10.

112.1b. Some effects <#effect>`__allow a `player to cast <#cast>`__a `copy of a card; if the`player <#player>`__ does, that copy <#copy>`__is a `spell as well. See rule`706.12 <#R70612>`__.

112.2. A spell’s`owner <#owner>`__ is the same as the`owner <#owner>`__ of the card thatrepresents it, unless it’s a`copy <#copy>`__. In that case, the`owner <#owner>`__ of the spell isthe player under whose`control <#control_controller>`__ it was put onthe stack. A spell’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ is, bydefault, the player who put it onthe stack. Every spell <#spell>`__has a `controller.

112.3. A noncopy spell’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ are thesame as those printed on its card,as modified by any continuouseffects. See rule`613 <#R613>`__, „Interaction of ContinuousEffects.”

112.4. If an effect <#effect>`__changes any`characteristics of a`permanent spell <#permanent_spell>`__, the`effect <#effect>`__ continues to apply to the`permanent <#permanent>`__ when the`spell <#spell>`__ resolves. Seerule 400.7. Example: Ifaneffectchanges ablackcreaturespelltowhite, thecreatureis whitewhen itenters thebattlefieldandremains white for the duration oftheeffectchangingitscolor.

113. Abilities

113.1. An ability can beone of three things:

113.1a. An ability canbe a characteristic an`object <#object>`__ has that lets it affect thegame. An object’s`abilities <#ability>`__ are defined by its`rules text <#rules_text>`__ or by the`effect <#effect>`__ that created it.`Abilities <#ability>`__ can also be granted to`objects <#object>`__ by rules or`effects <#effect>`__. (Effects <#effect>`__that grant `abilities usually usethe words „has,” „have,” „gains,” or „gain.”)`Abilities <#ability>`__ generate`effects <#effect>`__. (See rule`609 <#R609>`__, „Effects.”)

113.1b. An ability canbe something that a player hasthat changes how the game affects the`player <#player>`__. A player <#player>`__normally has no `abilities <#ability>`__`unless granted to that`player <#player>`__ by effects.

113.1c. An ability canbe an activated or triggeredability on the`stack <#stack>`__. This kind of`ability <#ability>`__ is an`object <#object>`__. (See section 6,”Spells, Abilities,and Effects.”)

113.2. Abilities canaffect the objects they’re on.They can also affect other objects <#object>`__and/or `players.

113.2a. Abilities can bebeneficial or detrimental. Example:”[Thiscreature]can’tblock” isanability.

113.2b. An additionalcost or alternativecost to cast <#cast>`__a `card is an ability <#ability>`__of the `card.

113.2c. An object mayhave multiple abilities. If the`object <#object>`__ is represented by a`card <#card>`__, then aside from certaindefined abilities that may bestrung together on a single line (see rule`702 <#R702>`__, „KeywordAbilities”), eachparagraph break in a card’s textmarks a separate ability. If the`object <#object>`__ is not represented by a`card <#card>`__, the effect thatcreated it may have given it multiple`abilities <#ability>`__. An`object <#object>`__ may also be grantedadditional abilities by a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability. Ifan object has multiple instancesof the same ability, eachinstance functions independently. This may ormay not produce more effects thana single instance; refer to the specific`ability <#ability>`__ for more information.

113.2d. Abilities cangenerate one-shot effects <#one-shot_effect>`__or `continuous effects.Some continuous effects <#continuous_effect>`__are `replacementeffects or preventioneffects. See rule`609 <#R609>`__, „Effects.”

113.3. There are four`general <#general>`__ categories of`abilities <#ability>`__:

113.3a. Spellabilities are`abilities <#ability>`__ that are followed asinstructions while an instant or`sorcery <#sorcery>`__ spell isresolving. Any text on an instant <#instant>`__or `sorcery spell isa spell ability <#spell_ability>`__`unless it’s an activatedability, a triggeredability, or a staticability that fits thecriteria described in rule 113.6.

113.3b. Activatedabilities have a`cost <#cost>`__ and an effect.They are written as „[Cost]:[Effect.] [Activation instructions(if any).]” A player may`activate <#activate>`__ such an`ability <#ability>`__ whenever they have`priority <#priority>`__. Doing so puts it onthe stack, where it remains untilit’s countered, it resolves, orit otherwise leaves the stack. Seerule 602, „Activating ActivatedAbilities.”

113.3c. Triggeredabilities have a`trigger condition <#trigger_condition>`__ andan effect. They are written as”[Trigger condition],[effect],” and include (andusually begin with) the word „when,” „whenever,”or „at.” Whenever the triggerevent occurs, the`ability <#ability>`__ is put on the`stack <#stack>`__ the next time a`player <#player>`__ would receive`priority <#priority>`__ and stays there untilit’s countered, it resolves, orit otherwise leaves the stack. Seerule 603, „Handling TriggeredAbilities.”

113.3d. Staticabilities are written asstatements. They’re simply true. Staticabilities <#static_ability>`__`create continuouseffects which are activewhile the permanent with the`ability <#ability>`__ is on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ and has the`ability <#ability>`__, or while the`object <#object>`__ with the`ability <#ability>`__ is in the appropriate`zone <#zone>`__. See rule 604,”Handling StaticAbilities.”

113.4. Some activatedabilities and some`triggered abilities <#triggered_ability>`__ are`mana abilities <#mana_ability>`__. Manaabilities follow specialrules: They don’t use the stack,and, under certain circumstances, a`player <#player>`__ can`activate <#activate>`__ manaabilities even if they don’thave priority. See rule`605 <#R605>`__, „ManaAbilities.”

113.5. Some activatedabilities are loyaltyabilities. Loyaltyabilities follow specialrules: A player may`activate <#activate>`__ a loyaltyability of a`permanent <#permanent>`__ they`control <#control_controller>`__ any time theyhave priority and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty during <#during>`__a `main phase of their turn,but only if no player haspreviously activated a loyaltyability of that`permanent <#permanent>`__ that turn. See rule`606 <#R606>`__, „LoyaltyAbilities.”

113.6. Abilities of an`instant <#instant>`__ or sorcery <#sorcery>`__`spell usually function only whilethat object is on the`stack <#stack>`__. Abilities ofall other objects usually functiononly while that object is on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. The exceptionsare as follows:

113.6a. Characteristic-definingabilities <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__function everywhere, even `outside thegame. (See rule`604.3 <#R6043>`__.)

113.6b. An ability thatstates which zones it functions infunctions only from those zones.

113.6c. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that allows a`player <#player>`__ to pay an`alternative cost <#alternative_cost>`__ ratherthan its mana cost or otherwisemodifies what that particular`object <#object>`__ costs to`cast <#cast>`__ functions on the`stack <#stack>`__.

113.6d. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that restricts ormodifies how that particular`object <#object>`__ can be played or`cast <#cast>`__ functions in any`zone <#zone>`__ from which it could be playedor cast and also on the`stack <#stack>`__. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that grants it another`ability <#ability>`__ that restricts ormodifies how that particular`object <#object>`__ can be played or`cast <#cast>`__ functions only on the`stack <#stack>`__.

113.6e. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that restricts ormodifies what zones that particular`object <#object>`__ can be played or`cast <#cast>`__ from functions everywhere, even`outside the game <#outside_the_game>`__.

113.6f. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that states it can’t becountered functions on the stack.

113.6g. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that modifies how thatparticular object enters thebattlefield <#enters_the_battlefield>`__functions as that `object isentering the battlefield. Seerule 614.12.

113.6h. An object’s`ability <#ability>`__ that states`counters <#counter>`__ can’t be put on that`object <#object>`__ functions as that`object <#object>`__ is entering the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ in addition tofunctioning while that object ison the battlefield.

113.6i. An object’s`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ thathas a cost that can’t be paid whilethe object is on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ functions fromany zone in which its`cost <#cost>`__ can be paid.

113.6j. A triggercondition that can’t`trigger <#trigger>`__ from the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ functions in all`zones <#zone>`__ it can trigger <#trigger>`__from. Other `triggerconditions of the same`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__ mayfunction in different zones.*Example: Absolver Thrull hasthe*ability„When AbsolverThrullenters thebattlefieldorthecreatureithauntsdies,destroytargetenchantment.”The firsttriggerconditionfunctionsfrom thebattlefieldandthe secondtriggerconditionfunctionsfromtheexilezone.(See rule702.54,”Haunt.”)

113.6k. An ability whose`cost <#cost>`__ or effect <#effect>`__specifies that it `moves the`object <#object>`__ it’s on out of a particular`zone <#zone>`__ functions only in that`zone <#zone>`__, unless its`trigger condition <#trigger_condition>`__ or aprevious part of its cost or`effect <#effect>`__ specifies that the`object <#object>`__ is put into that`zone <#zone>`__ or, if the object <#object>`__is an `Aura, that the`object <#object>`__ it enchants <#enchant>`__`leaves thebattlefield. Thesame is true if the effect of that`ability <#ability>`__ creates a`delayed triggeredability <#delayed_triggered_ability>`__ whose`effect <#effect>`__ moves the`object <#object>`__ out of a particular`zone <#zone>`__. Example: ReassemblingSkeleton says „{1}{B}: Return ReassemblingSkeletonfromyourgraveyardtothebattlefieldtapped.”Aplayermayactivatethisabilityonlyif Reassembling Skeleton is intheirgraveyard.

113.6m. An ability thatmodifies the rules for deck <#deck>`__construction functions before the game begins.Such an `ability modifies not justthe Comprehensive Rules, but also the Magic: TheGathering TournamentRules and any otherdocuments that set the deck <#deck>`__construction rules for a specific format.However, such an `ability can’taffect the format legality of a`card <#card>`__, including whether it’s bannedor restricted. The current Magic: The Gathering`Tournament Rules <#tournament_rules>`__ can befound atWPN.Wizards.com/en/resources/rules-documents.

113.6n. Abilities of`emblems <#emblem>`__, plane <#plane>`__`cards, vanguard <#vanguard>`__`cards, scheme <#scheme>`__`cards, and`conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__ cards <#card>`__function in the `command <#command>`__`zone. See rule 114,”Emblems”; rule 901,”Planechase”; rule`902 <#R902>`__, „Vanguard”;rule 904,”Archenemy”; and rule`905 <#R905>`__, „ConspiracyDraft.”

113.7. The source of anability is the`object <#object>`__ that generated it. Thesource of an activatedability on the`stack <#stack>`__ is the object <#object>`__whose `ability was activated. Thesource of a triggeredability (other than a`delayed triggeredability <#delayed_triggered_ability>`__) on the`stack <#stack>`__, or one that has triggeredand is waiting to be put on the`stack <#stack>`__, is the object <#object>`__whose `ability triggered. Todetermine the source of a delayed triggeredability, seerules 603.7d-f.

113.7a. Once activated or triggered, an`ability <#ability>`__ exists on the`stack <#stack>`__ independently of its source.Destruction or removal of the source after thattime won’t affect the ability.Note that some abilities cause asource to do something (for example, „ProdigalPyromancer deals 1`damage <#damage>`__ to anytarget”) rather than the`ability <#ability>`__ doing anything directly.In these cases, any activated or triggeredability that referencesinformation about the source for use whileannouncing an activatedability or putting a`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__ onthe stack checks that informationwhen the ability is put onto the`stack <#stack>`__. Otherwise, it will checkthat information when it`resolves <#resolve>`__. In both instances, ifthe source is no longer in the `zone <#zone>`__it’s expected to be in at that time, its `lastknown information <#last_known_information>`__is used. The source can still perform the actioneven though it no longer exists.

113.8. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of an`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ onthe stack is the`player <#player>`__ who activated it. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__ onthe stack (other than a delayedtriggeredability) is the`player <#player>`__ who controlled the`ability <#ability>`__’s source when ittriggered, or, if it had no`controller <#control_controller>`__, the`player <#player>`__ who owned the`ability <#ability>`__’s source when ittriggered. To determine the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`delayed triggeredability <#delayed_triggered_ability>`__, seerules 603.7d-f.

113.9. Activated and triggeredabilities on the`stack <#stack>`__ aren’t spells,and therefore can’t be countered by anythingthat counters only`spells <#spell>`__. Activated and triggeredabilities on the`stack <#stack>`__ can be countered by`effects <#effect>`__ that specifically`counter <#counter>`__ abilities.`Static abilities <#static_ability>`__ don’t usethe stack and thus can’t becountered at all.

113.10. Effects can addor remove abilities of`objects <#object>`__. An effect <#effect>`__that adds an `ability will statethat the object „gains” or „has”that ability, or similar. An`effect <#effect>`__ that removes an`ability <#ability>`__ will state that the`object <#object>`__ „loses” that`ability <#ability>`__.

113.10a. An effect thatadds an activatedability may includeactivation instructions for that`ability <#ability>`__. These instructions`become <#becomes>`__ part of the`ability <#ability>`__ that’s added to the`object <#object>`__.

113.10b. Effects thatremove an ability remove allinstances of it.

113.10c. If two or more`effects <#effect>`__ add and remove the same`ability <#ability>`__, in`general <#general>`__ the most recent oneprevails. See rule 613 for moreinformation about the interaction of continuouseffects.

113.11. Effects can stopan object from having a specified`ability <#ability>`__. These`effects <#effect>`__ say that the`object <#object>`__ „can’t have” that`ability <#ability>`__. If the`object <#object>`__ has that`ability <#ability>`__, it loses it. It’s alsoimpossible for an effect or`keyword counter <#keyword_counter>`__ to addthat ability to the`object <#object>`__. If a resolving`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__`creates a continuouseffect that would addthe specified ability to such an`object <#object>`__, that part of that`continuous effect <#continuous_effect>`__ doesnot apply; however, other parts of that`continuous effect <#continuous_effect>`__ willstill apply, and that resolving`spell <#spell>`__ or ability canstill create other continuouseffects. Continuouseffects created by`static abilities <#static_ability>`__ thatwould add the specified ability <#ability>`__won’t apply to that `object.

113.12. An effect thatsets an object’s`characteristic <#characteristics>`__, or simplystates a quality of that object,is different from an ability <#ability>`__granted by an `effect. When an`object <#object>`__ „gains” or „has” an`ability <#ability>`__, that`ability <#ability>`__ can be`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__by another effect. If an`effect <#effect>`__ defines a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__ of the`object <#object>`__(„[permanent] is[characteristic value]”),it’s not granting an ability.(See rule 604.3.) Similarly, if an`effect <#effect>`__ states a quality of that`object <#object>`__(„[creature] can’t be blocked,”for example), it’s neither granting an`ability <#ability>`__ nor setting a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__.
