Example:Muraganda Petroglyphs reads,”Creatureswithnoabilitiesget +2/+2.” ARuneclaw Bear(acreaturewithnoabilities) enchanted byanAurathat says”Enchantedcreaturehasflying„would not get +2/+2. A Runeclaw Bear enchantedby anAurathat says”Enchantedcreatureis red”or „Enchantedcreaturecan’tbe blocked” would get +2/+2.

114. Emblems

114.1. Some effects put`emblems <#emblem>`__ into the`command <#command>`__ zone. An`emblem <#emblem>`__ is a marker used torepresent an object that has oneor more abilities, but no other`characteristics <#characteristics>`__.

114.2. An effect that`creates <#create>`__ an emblem iswritten „[Player] gets an`emblem <#emblem>`__ with[ability].” This means that[player] puts an`emblem <#emblem>`__ with[ability] into the`command <#command>`__ zone. The`emblem <#emblem>`__ is both owned andcontrolled by that player.

114.3. An emblem has no`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ otherthan the abilities defined by the`effect <#effect>`__ that created it. Inparticular, an emblem has no`name <#name>`__, no types, no manacost, and no color.

114.4. Abilities of`emblems <#emblem>`__ function in the`command <#command>`__ zone.

114.5. An emblem isneither a card nor a`permanent <#permanent>`__. Emblem <#emblem>`__isn’t a `card type.

115. Targets

115.1. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ require their`controller <#control_controller>`__ to chooseone or more targets for them. The`targets <#target>`__ are`object <#object>`__(s) and/or`player <#player>`__(s) the spell <#spell>`__or `ability will affect. These`targets <#target>`__ are declared as part ofthe process of putting the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ on the`stack <#stack>`__. The targets <#target>`__can’t be changed except by another`spell or `ability <#ability>`__that explicitly says it can do so.

115.1a. An instant or`sorcery <#sorcery>`__ spell istargeted if its spellability identifies somethingit will affect by using the phrase”target [something],” where the”something” is a phrase that describes an`object <#object>`__ and/or`player <#player>`__. The`target <#target>`__(s) are chosen as the`spell <#spell>`__ is cast; see rule`601.2c <#R6012c>`__. (If an activated or`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__ of an`instant <#instant>`__ or sorcery <#sorcery>`__uses the word `target, that`ability <#ability>`__ is targeted, but the`spell <#spell>`__ is not.) Example:Asorcerycardhastheability„Whenyoucyclethiscard,targetcreaturegets-1/-1 until end of turn.” Thistriggeredabilityis targeted,but that doesn’t makethecardit’s on targeted.

115.1b. Aura <#aura>`__`spells are always targeted. An`Aura <#aura>`__’s target isspecified by its enchant keywordability (see rule`702.5 <#R7025>`__, „Enchant”).The target is chosen as the`spell <#spell>`__ is cast; see rule`601.2c <#R6012c>`__. An Aura <#aura>`__`permanent doesn’t`target <#target>`__ anything; only the`spell <#spell>`__ is targeted. (An activated or`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__ of an`Aura <#aura>`__ permanent canalso be targeted.)

115.1c. An activatedability is targeted ifit identifies something it will affect by usingthe phrase „target [something],”where the „something” is a phrase that describesan object and/or`player <#player>`__. The`target <#target>`__(s) are chosen as the`ability <#ability>`__ is activated; see rule`602.2b <#R6022b>`__.

115.1d. A triggeredability is targeted ifit identifies something it will affect by usingthe phrase „target [something],”where the „something” is a phrase that describesan object and/or`player <#player>`__. The`target <#target>`__(s) are chosen as the`ability <#ability>`__ is put on the`stack <#stack>`__; see rule`603.3d <#R6033d>`__.

115.1e. Some keywordabilities, such as`equip <#equip>`__ and modular,represent targeted activated or triggeredabilities, and some`keyword abilities <#keyword_ability>`__, suchas mutate, cause`spells <#spell>`__ to have`targets <#target>`__. In those cases, thephrase „target [something]”appears in the rule for that keywordability rather than in the`ability <#ability>`__ itself. (The keyword’s`reminder text <#reminder_text>`__ will oftencontain the word „target.”) Seerule 702, „KeywordAbilities.”

115.2. Only permanents <#permanent>`__are legal `targets for`spells <#spell>`__ and`abilities <#ability>`__, unless a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability (a)specifies that it can target an`object <#object>`__ in another zone <#zone>`__or a `player, or (b)`targets <#target>`__ an object <#object>`__that can’t exist on the`battlefield, such as a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability.See also rule 115.4.

115.3. The same target <#target>`__can’t be chosen multiple times for any oneinstance of the word „`target” on a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability. Ifthe spell or ability <#ability>`__uses the word „`target” in multipleplaces, the same object or`player <#player>`__ can be chosen once for eachinstance of the word „target” (aslong as it fits the targeting criteria). Thisrule applies both when choosing`targets <#target>`__ for a spell <#spell>`__or `ability and when changing`targets <#target>`__ or choosing new`targets <#target>`__ for a spell <#spell>`__or `ability (see rule`115.7 <#R1157>`__).

115.4. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ that refer to`damage <#damage>`__ require „anytarget,” „another`target <#target>`__,” „two`targets <#target>`__,” or similar rather than”target [something].” These`targets <#target>`__ may be`creatures <#creature>`__,`players <#player>`__, or`planeswalkers <#planeswalker>`__. Other game`objects <#object>`__, such as noncreature`artifacts <#artifact>`__ or`spells <#spell>`__, can’t be chosen.

115.5. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ on the stack <#stack>`__is an `illegal target foritself.

115.6. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that requires`targets <#target>`__ may allow zero`targets <#target>`__ to be chosen. Such a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability isstill said to require targets, butthat spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is targeted only if oneor more targets have been chosenfor it.

115.7. Some effects allowa player to change the`target <#target>`__(s) of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability,and other effects allow a`player <#player>`__ to choose new`targets <#target>`__ for a spell <#spell>`__or `ability.

115.7a. If an effect <#effect>`__allows a `player to „change the`target <#target>`__(s)” of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability,each target can be changed only toanother legal target. If a`target <#target>`__ can’t be changed to anotherlegal target, the original`target <#target>`__ is unchanged, even if theoriginal target is itself illegalby then. If all the targets aren’tchanged to other legal targets,none of them are changed.

115.7b. If an effect <#effect>`__allows a `player to „change atarget” of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability,the process described in rule`115.7a <#R1157a>`__ is followed, except thatonly one of those targets may bechanged (rather than all of them or none ofthem).

115.7c. If an effect <#effect>`__allows a `player to „change anytargets” of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability,the process described in rule`115.7a <#R1157a>`__ is followed, except thatany number of those targets may bechanged (rather than all of them or none ofthem).

115.7d. If an effect <#effect>`__allows a `player to „choose new`targets <#target>`__” for a spell <#spell>`__or `ability, the`player <#player>`__ may leave any number of the`targets <#target>`__ unchanged, even if those`targets <#target>`__ would be illegal. If the`player <#player>`__ chooses to change some orall of the targets, the new`targets <#target>`__ must be legal and must notcause any unchanged targets to`become <#becomes>`__ illegal.

115.7e. When changing`targets <#target>`__ or choosing new`targets <#target>`__ for a spell <#spell>`__or `ability, only the final set of`targets <#target>`__ is evaluated to determinewhether the change is legal. Example: Arc Trailis asorcerythat reads „ArcTraildeals2damagetoanytargetand1damagetoanothertarget.” Thecurrenttargetsof Arc Trailare Runeclaw Bear and Llanowar Elves, in thatorder.YoucastRedirect,aninstantthat reads”Youmay choosenewtargetsfortargetspell,”targeting Arc Trail.Youcanchange the firsttargettoLlanowar Elves and change thesecondtargetto RuneclawBear.

115.7f. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ may „divide” or”distribute” an effect (such as`damage <#damage>`__ or counters)among one or more targets. Whenchanging targets or choosing new`targets <#target>`__ for that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability,the original division can’t be changed.

115.8. Modal <#modal_mode>`__`spells and abilities <#ability>`__may have different targeting`requirements for each`mode <#modal_mode>`__. An effect <#effect>`__that allows a `player to change the`target <#target>`__(s) of a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ spell or`ability <#ability>`__, or to choose new`targets <#target>`__ for a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ spell or`ability <#ability>`__, doesn’t allow that`player <#player>`__ to change its`mode <#modal_mode>`__. (See rule`700.2 <#R7002>`__.)

115.9. Some objects checkwhat another spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is targeting. Dependingon the wording, these may check the currentstate of the targets, the state ofthe targets at the time they wereselected, or both.

115.9a. An object thatlooks for a „[spell or`ability <#ability>`__] with a single`target <#target>`__” checks the number of timesany object or player <#player>`__was chosen as the `target of that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__when it was put on the `stack, notthe number of its targets that arecurrently legal. If the same`object <#object>`__ or player <#player>`__became a `target more than once,each of those instances is counted separately.

115.9b. An object thatlooks for a „[spell or`ability <#ability>`__] that`targets <#target>`__ [something]” checks thecurrent state of that spell or`ability <#ability>`__’s targets.If an object it`targets <#target>`__ is still in the`zone <#zone>`__ it’s expected to be in or a`player <#player>`__ it targets isstill in the game, that target’scurrent information is used, even if it’s notcurrently legal for that spell or`ability <#ability>`__. If an`object <#object>`__ it targets isno longer in the zone it’s expectedto be in or a player it`targets <#target>`__ is no longer in the game,that target is ignored; its `lastknown information <#last_known_information>`__is not used.

115.9c. An object thatlooks for a „[spell or`ability <#ability>`__] that`targets <#target>`__ only [something]” checksthe number of different objects or`players <#player>`__ that were chosen as`targets <#target>`__ of that spell <#spell>`__or `ability when it was put on the`stack <#stack>`__ (as modified by`effects <#effect>`__ that changed those`targets <#target>`__), not the number of those`objects <#object>`__ or players <#player>`__that are currently legal `targets.If that number is one (even if the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__`targets that object <#object>`__or `player multiple times), thecurrent state of that spell or`ability <#ability>`__’s target ischecked as described in rule`115.9b <#R1159b>`__.

115.10. Spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ can affect`objects <#object>`__ and players <#player>`__they don’t `target. In`general <#general>`__, those`objects <#object>`__ and players <#player>`__aren’t chosen until the `spell or`ability <#ability>`__ resolves.See rule 608, „Resolving`Spells <#spell>`__ and`Abilities <#ability>`__.”

115.10a. Just because an`object <#object>`__ or player isbeing affected by a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ doesn’t make that`object <#object>`__ or player a`target <#target>`__ of that spell <#spell>`__or `ability. Unless <#unless>`__that `object or`player <#player>`__ is identified by the word”target” in the text of that`spell <#spell>`__ or ability, orthe rule for that keywordability, it’s not a`target <#target>`__.

115.10b. In particular, the word”you” in an`object <#object>`__’s text doesn’t indicate a`target <#target>`__.

116. SpecialActions

116.1. Specialactions are actions a`player <#player>`__ may take when they have`priority <#priority>`__ that don’t use the`stack <#stack>`__. These are not to be confusedwith turn-basedactions and`state-based actions <#state-based_actions>`__,which the game generates automatically. (Seerule 703, „Turn-BasedActions,” and rule`704 <#R704>`__, „State-BasedActions.”)

116.2. There are ten specialactions:

116.2a. Playing a land is a`special action <#special_action>`__. To`play <#play>`__ a land, a`player <#player>`__ puts that land <#land>`__onto the `battlefield from the`zone <#zone>`__ it was in (usually that`player <#player>`__’s hand). Bydefault, a player can take thisaction only once during each oftheir turns. A player can takethis action any time they have`priority <#priority>`__ and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty during <#during>`__a `main phase of their turn.See rule 305, „Lands.”

116.2b. Turning a face-down`creature <#creature>`__ face up <#face_up>`__is a `special action. A`player <#player>`__ can take this action anytime they have priority. Seerule 707, „Face-Down`Spells <#spell>`__ and`Permanents <#permanent>`__.”

116.2c. Some effects <#effect>`__allow a `player to take an actionat a later time, usually to end a continuouseffect or to stop a`delayed triggeredability <#delayed_triggered_ability>`__ fromtriggering. Doing so is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ can take such an action anytime they have priority,`unless <#unless>`__ that effect <#effect>`__specifies another timing`restriction, for as long asthe effect allows it.

116.2d. Some effects from`static abilities <#static_ability>`__ allow a`player <#player>`__ to take an action to ignorethe effect from that`ability <#ability>`__ for a duration. Doing sois a special action. A`player <#player>`__ can take such an action anytime they have priority.

116.2e. One card (CirclingVultures) has the ability”You may discard <#discard>`__Circling Vultures any time `you <#you_your>`__could `cast an`instant <#instant>`__.” Doing so is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ can take such an action anytime they have priority.

116.2f. A player who hasa card with suspend <#suspend>`__in their `hand may exile <#exile>`__that `card. This is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ can take this action anytime they have priority, butonly if they could begin to cast <#cast>`__that `card by putting it onto the`stack <#stack>`__. See rule`702.61 <#R70261>`__, „Suspend.”

116.2g. A player who haschosen a companion may`pay <#pay>`__ {3} to put that card <#card>`__from `outside the game <#outside_the_game>`__into their `hand. This is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ can take this action anytime they have priority and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty during <#during>`__a `main phase of their turn,but only if they haven’t done so yet this game.(See rule 702.138,”Companion.”)

116.2h. A player who hasa card with foretell <#foretell>`__in their `hand may pay {2}and exile that card <#card>`__`face down. This is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ may take this action anytime they have priority <#priority>`__`during their turn. See rule`702.142 <#R702142>`__,”Foretell.”

116.2i. In a`Planechase <#planechase>`__ game, rolling the`planar die <#planar_die>`__ is a specialaction. A`player <#player>`__ can take this action anytime they have priority and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty during <#during>`__a `main phase of their turn.Taking this action costs a`player <#player>`__ an amount of`mana <#mana>`__ equal to the number of timesthey have previously taken this action on thatturn. Note that this number won’t be equal tothe number of times the player hasrolled the planar die thatturn if an effect has caused the`player <#player>`__ to roll the planardie that turn. See rule`901 <#R901>`__, „Planechase.”

116.2j. In a ConspiracyDraft game, turning aface-down conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__`card in the command <#command>`__`zone face up is a`special action <#special_action>`__. A`player <#player>`__ can take this action anytime they have priority. Seerule 905.4a.

116.3. If a player takesa special action, that`player <#player>`__ receives`priority <#priority>`__ afterward.

117. Timing and`Priority <#priority>`__

117.1. Unless a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability isinstructing a player to take anaction, which player can takeactions at any given time is determined by asystem of priority. The`player <#player>`__ with`priority <#priority>`__ may cast <#cast>`__`spells, activate <#activate>`__`abilities, and take specialactions.

117.1a. A player may`cast <#cast>`__ an instant <#instant>`__`spell any time they have`priority <#priority>`__. A player <#player>`__may `cast a noninstant`spell <#spell>`__ during their`main phase <#main_phase>`__ any time they have`priority <#priority>`__ and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty.

117.1b. A player may`activate <#activate>`__ an activatedability any time theyhave priority.

117.1c. A player may takesome special actions anytime they have priority. A`player <#player>`__ may take other specialactions <#special_action>`__`during their mainphase any time they have`priority <#priority>`__ and the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty. See rule`116 <#R116>`__, „SpecialActions.”

117.1d. A player may`activate <#activate>`__ a manaability whenever they have`priority <#priority>`__, whenever they arecasting a spell or activating an`ability <#ability>`__ that requires a`mana <#mana>`__ payment, or whenever a rule or`effect <#effect>`__ asks for a mana <#mana>`__payment (even in the middle of casting orresolving a `spell or activating orresolving an ability).

117.2. Other kinds of`abilities <#ability>`__ and actions areautomatically generated or performed by the gamerules, or are performed by players <#player>`__without receiving `priority.

117.2a. Triggeredabilities can`trigger <#trigger>`__ at any time, includingwhile a spell is being`cast <#cast>`__, an ability isbeing activated, or a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is resolving. (See rule`603 <#R603>`__, „Handling TriggeredAbilities.”) However,nothing actually happens at the time an`ability <#ability>`__ triggers.Each time a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__, each`ability <#ability>`__ that has triggered buthasn’t yet been put on the stack isput on the stack. See rule`117.5 <#R1175>`__.

117.2b. Staticabilities continuouslyaffect the game. Priority <#priority>`__doesn’t apply to them. (See rule`604, „Handling StaticAbilities,” and rule`611 <#R611>`__, „ContinuousEffects.”)

117.2c. Turn-basedactions happenautomatically when certain steps or`phases <#phase>`__ begin. They’re dealt withbefore a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__. See rule`117.3a <#R1173a>`__. Turn-basedactions also happenautomatically when each step and`phase <#phase>`__ ends; no player <#player>`__receives `priority afterward. Seerule 703, „Turn-BasedActions.”

117.2d. State-basedactions happenautomatically when certain conditions are met.See rule 704. They’re dealt withbefore a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__. See rule`117.5 <#R1175>`__.

117.2e. Resolving spells <#spell>`__and `abilities may instruct`players <#player>`__ to make choices or takeactions, or may allow players to`activate <#activate>`__ manaabilities. Even if a`player <#player>`__ is doing so, no`player <#player>`__ has`priority <#priority>`__ while a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability isresolving. See rule 608, „Resolving`Spells <#spell>`__ and`Abilities <#ability>`__.”

117.3. Which player has`priority <#priority>`__ is determined by thefollowing rules:

117.3a. The activeplayer receives`priority <#priority>`__ at the beginning ofmost steps and phases,after any turn-basedactions (such asdrawing a card during <#during>`__the `draw step; see rule`703 <#R703>`__) have been dealt with and`abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ at the beginning of that`phase <#phase>`__ or step have beenput on the stack. No`player <#player>`__ receives`priority <#priority>`__ during <#during>`__the `untap step.`Players <#player>`__ usually don’t get`priority <#priority>`__ during <#during>`__the `cleanup step (see rule`514.3 <#R5143>`__).

117.3b. The activeplayer receives`priority <#priority>`__ after a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__(other than a `mana ability)`resolves <#resolve>`__.

117.3c. If a player has`priority <#priority>`__ when they`cast <#cast>`__ a spell,`activate <#activate>`__ an`ability <#ability>`__, or take a specialaction, that`player <#player>`__ receives`priority <#priority>`__ afterward.

117.3d. If a player has`priority <#priority>`__ and chooses not to takeany actions, that player <#player>`__`passes. If any mana isin that player’s manapool, they announce what`mana <#mana>`__ is there. Then the next`player <#player>`__ in turn order receives`priority <#priority>`__.

117.4. If all players <#player>`__`pass in succession <#pass_in_succession>`__(that is, if all `players <#player>`__`pass without taking any actions inbetween passing), the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ on top of the`stack <#stack>`__ resolves or,if the stack is empty, the`phase <#phase>`__ or step ends.

117.5. Each time a player <#player>`__would get `priority, the gamefirst performs all applicable state-basedactions as a single`event <#event>`__ (see rule 704,”State-BasedActions”), thenrepeats this process until no state-basedactions are performed.Then triggeredabilities are put on the`stack <#stack>`__ (see rule 603,”Handling TriggeredAbilities”). These`steps <#step>`__ repeat in order until nofurther state-basedactions are performedand no abilities <#ability>`__`trigger. Then the`player <#player>`__ who would have received`priority <#priority>`__ does so.

117.6. In a multiplayergame using the sharedteam turnsoption,`teams <#team>`__ rather than individual`players <#player>`__ have`priority <#priority>`__. See rule`805 <#R805>`__, „Shared Team TurnsOption.”

117.7. If a player with`priority <#priority>`__ casts a`spell <#spell>`__ or activates <#activate>`__an `activated ability <#activated_ability>`__while another `spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is already on the`stack <#stack>`__, the new spell <#spell>`__or `ability has been`cast <#cast>`__ or activated „in responseto” the earlier`spell <#spell>`__ or ability.The new spell or`ability <#ability>`__ will`resolve <#resolve>`__ first. See rule`608 <#R608>`__, „Resolving Spells <#spell>`__and `Abilities.”

118. Costs

118.1. A cost is an actionor payment necessary to take another action orto stop another action from taking place. To`pay <#pay>`__ a cost, a`player <#player>`__ carries out theinstructions specified by the`spell <#spell>`__, ability, or`effect <#effect>`__ that contains that`cost <#cost>`__.

118.2. If a cost includes a`mana <#mana>`__ payment, the`player <#player>`__ paying the cost <#cost>`__has a chance to `activate manaabilities. Paying the`cost <#cost>`__ to cast a`spell <#spell>`__ or activate <#activate>`__an `activated ability <#activated_ability>`__follows the `steps in rules`601.2f <#R6012f>`__-h.

118.3. A player can’t`pay <#pay>`__ a cost without havingthe necessary resources to pay itfully. For example, a player withonly 1 life can’t`pay <#pay>`__ a cost of 2`life <#life_life_total>`__, and a`permanent <#permanent>`__ that’s already`tapped <#tapped>`__ can’t be`tapped <#tapped>`__ to pay a`cost <#cost>`__. See rule 202,”Mana Cost and`Color <#color>`__,” and rule 602,”Activating ActivatedAbilities.”

118.3a. Paying mana is doneby removing the indicated mana froma player’s manapool. (Players canalways pay 0 mana.) Ifexcess mana remains in that`player <#player>`__’s manapool after making that payment,the player announces what`mana <#mana>`__ is still there.

118.3b. Paying`life <#life_life_total>`__ is done bysubtracting the indicated amount of`life <#life_life_total>`__ from a`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal.(Players can always pay <#pay>`__0 `life.)

118.3c. Activating manaabilities is not mandatory,even if paying a cost is. Example:AplayercontrolsLodestoneGolem, which says”Nonartifactspellscost{1}more tocast.”Anotherplayerremoves thelast timecounterfrom asuspendedsorcerycard.Thatplayermustcastthatspellifable, but doing socosts{1}.Theplayeris forcedtopaythatcostifenoughmanais in theirmanapool, buttheplayerisn’t forcedtoactivateamanaabilityto producethatmana. If they don’t,thecardsimply remains exiled.

118.4. Some costs includean {X} or an X. See rule`107.3 <#R1073>`__.

118.5. Some costs arerepresented by {0}, or are reduced to {0}. Theaction necessary for a player to`pay <#pay>`__ such a cost is the`player <#player>`__’s acknowledgment that theyare paying it. Even though such a`cost <#cost>`__ requires no resources, it’s notautomatically paid.

118.5a. A spell whose`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__ is {0} must still be`cast <#cast>`__ the same way as one with a`cost <#cost>`__ greater than zero; it won’t`cast <#cast>`__ itself automatically. The sameis true for an activatedability whose`cost <#cost>`__ is {0}.

118.6. Some objects haveno mana cost. This representsan unpayable cost. An`ability <#ability>`__ can also have anunpayable cost if its`cost <#cost>`__ is based on the manacost of an object <#object>`__with no `mana cost. Attemptingto cast a spell or`activate <#activate>`__ an`ability <#ability>`__ that has an unpayable`cost <#cost>`__ is a legal action. However,attempting to pay an unpayable`cost <#cost>`__ is an illegalaction.

118.6a. If an unpayable`cost <#cost>`__ is increased by an`effect <#effect>`__ or an additionalcost is imposed, the`cost <#cost>`__ is still unpayable. If an`alternative cost <#alternative_cost>`__ isapplied to an unpayable cost,including an effect that allows a`player <#player>`__ to cast a`spell <#spell>`__ without paying its manacost, the alternativecost may be paid.

118.7. What a player <#player>`__actually needs to do to `pay a`cost <#cost>`__ may be changed or reduced by`effects <#effect>`__. If the mana <#mana>`__component of a `cost is reduced tonothing by cost reduction`effects <#effect>`__, it’s considered to be{0}. Paying a cost changed orreduced by an effect countsas paying the original`cost <#cost>`__.

118.7a. Effects thatreduce a cost by an amount of`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__ affect only the`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__ component ofthat cost. They can’t affect thecolored or colorless <#colorless>`__`mana components of that`cost <#cost>`__.

118.7b. If a cost isreduced by an amount of colored or`colorless <#colorless>`__ mana, butthe cost doesn’t require`mana <#mana>`__ of that type, the`cost <#cost>`__ is reduced by that amount of`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__.

118.7c. If a cost isreduced by an amount of colored mana <#mana>`__that exceeds its `mana component ofthat color, the cost’s`mana <#mana>`__ component of that`color <#color>`__ is reduced to nothing and the`cost <#cost>`__’s genericmana component is reduced bythe difference.

118.7d. If a cost isreduced by an amount of`colorless <#colorless>`__ mana thatexceeds its colorless <#colorless>`__`mana component, the`cost <#cost>`__’s colorless <#colorless>`__`mana component is reduced to nothingand the cost’s genericmana component is reduced bythe difference.

118.7e. If a cost isreduced by an amount of mana <#mana>`__represented by a `hybrid manasymbol, the`player <#player>`__ paying that`cost <#cost>`__ chooses one half of that symbolat the time the cost reduction isapplied (see rule 601.2f). If acolored half is chosen, the cost isreduced by one mana of that`color <#color>`__. If a generic half is chosen,the cost is reduced by an amount of`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__ equal to thathalf’s number.

118.7f. If a cost isreduced by an amount of mana <#mana>`__represented by a `Phyrexian manasymbol, the`cost <#cost>`__ is reduced by one`mana <#mana>`__ of that symbol’s`color <#color>`__.

118.7g. If a cost isreduced by an amount of mana <#mana>`__represented by one or more `snow manasymbols, the`cost <#cost>`__ is reduced by that much`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__.

118.8. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ have additionalcosts. An additionalcost is a cost <#cost>`__listed in a `spell’s rulestext, or applied to a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__from another `effect, that its`controller <#control_controller>`__ must`pay <#pay>`__ at the same time they`pay <#pay>`__ the spell’s manacost or the`ability <#ability>`__’s activationcost. Note that some`additional costs <#additional_cost>`__ arelisted in keywords; see rule 702.

118.8a. Any number of additionalcosts may be applied to a`spell <#spell>`__ as it’s being`cast <#cast>`__ or to an ability <#ability>`__as it’s being activated. The`controller of the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__announces their intentions to `pay anyor all of those costs as describedin rule 601.2b.

118.8b. Some additionalcosts are optional.

118.8c. If an effect <#effect>`__instructs a `player to`cast <#cast>`__ a spell „if able,”and that spell has a mandatory`additional cost <#additional_cost>`__ thatincludes actions involving cards <#card>`__with a stated quality in a `hiddenzone, the player <#player>`__isn’t required to `cast that`spell <#spell>`__, even if those`cards <#card>`__ are present in that`zone <#zone>`__.

118.8d. Additionalcosts don’t change a`spell <#spell>`__’s mana cost,only what its`controller <#control_controller>`__ has to`pay <#pay>`__ to cast it.`Spells <#spell>`__ and abilities <#ability>`__that ask for that `spell’s manacost still see the originalvalue.

118.9. Some spells have`alternative costs <#alternative_cost>`__. An`alternative cost <#alternative_cost>`__ is a`cost <#cost>`__ listed in a`spell <#spell>`__’s text, or applied to it fromanother effect, that its`controller <#control_controller>`__ may`pay <#pay>`__ rather than paying the`spell <#spell>`__’s mana cost.`Alternative costs <#alternative_cost>`__ areusually phrased, „You may[action] rather than pay [this`object <#object>`__’s] manacost,” or „You <#you_your>`__may `cast [this object]without paying its mana cost.”Note that some alternativecosts are listed inkeywords; see rule 702.

118.9a. Only one alternativecost can be applied toany one spell as it’s being`cast <#cast>`__. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`spell <#spell>`__ announces their intentions to`pay <#pay>`__ that cost asdescribed in rule 601.2b.

118.9b. Alternativecosts are generallyoptional. An effect that allows`you <#you_your>`__ to cast a`spell <#spell>`__ may require a certain`alternative cost <#alternative_cost>`__ to bepaid.

118.9c. An alternativecost doesn’t change a`spell <#spell>`__’s mana cost,only what its`controller <#control_controller>`__ has to`pay <#pay>`__ to cast it.`Spells <#spell>`__ and abilities <#ability>`__that ask for that `spell’s manacost still see the originalvalue.

118.9d. If an alternativecost is being paid to`cast <#cast>`__ a spell, any`additional costs <#additional_cost>`__,`cost <#cost>`__ increases, and cost <#cost>`__reductions that affect that `spell <#spell>`__are applied to that `alternativecost. (See rule`601.2f <#R6012f>`__.)

118.10. Each payment of a`cost <#cost>`__ applies to only one`spell <#spell>`__, ability, or`effect <#effect>`__. For example, a`player <#player>`__ can’t`sacrifice <#sacrifice>`__ just one`creature <#creature>`__ to`activate <#activate>`__ the activatedabilities of two`permanents <#permanent>`__ that each requiresacrificing a creature as a`cost <#cost>`__. Also, the resolution of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__doesn’t `pay another`spell <#spell>`__ or ability’s`cost <#cost>`__, even if part of its`effect <#effect>`__ is doing the same thing theother cost asks for.

118.11. The actions performed whenpaying a cost may be modified by`effects <#effect>`__. Even if they are, meaningthe actions that are performed don’t`match <#match>`__ the actions that are calledfor, the cost has still been paid.*Example:A*playercontrolsPsychicVortex,anenchantmentwithacumulativeupkeepcostof”Drawacard,”and Obstinate Familiar,acreaturethat says”Ifyouwoulddrawacard,youmayskipthatdrawinstead.”Theplayermay decidetopayPsychicVortex’scumulativeupkeepcostandthendrawnocardsinsteadofdrawing the appropriate amount.Thecumulativeupkeepcosthasstill been paid.

118.12. Some spells,`activated abilities <#activated_ability>`__,and triggered abilities <#triggered_ability>`__read, „[Do something]. If [a`player] [does, doesn’t, or can’t],[effect].” or „[A`player <#player>`__] may [do something]. If[that player] [does, doesn’t, orcan’t], [effect].” The action [dosomething] is a cost, paid when the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__`resolves. The „If [a`player <#player>`__] [does, doesn’t, or can’t]”clause checks whether the player <#player>`__chose to `pay an optional`cost <#cost>`__ or started to pay amandatory cost, regardless of what`events <#event>`__ actually occurred.*Example:`You <#you_your>`__`control <#control_controller>`__*Standstill,anenchantmentthat says”Whenaplayercastsaspell,sacrificeStandstill.Ifyoudo, each ofthatplayer«sopponentsdrawsthreecards.”Aspelliscast,causingStandstill’sabilitytotrigger.Then anabilityis activatedthatexilesStandstill. WhenStandstill’sabilityresolves,you«reunable topaythe”sacrificeStandstill”cost.Noplayerwilldrawcards.**Example:YouropponenthascastGatherSpecimens, aspellthat says”If acreaturewould enterthebattlefieldunderanopponent«scontrolthisturn, itenters thebattlefieldunderyourcontrolinstead.”Youcontrolaface-down Dermoplasm,acreaturewithmorphthatsays „When Dermoplasm is turnedfaceup,youmayputacreaturecardwithmorphfromyourhandontothebattlefieldfaceup.Ifyoudo, return Dermoplasmtoitsowner«shand.”YouturnDermoplasmface up,andyouchoose to putacreaturecardwithmorphfromyourhandontothebattlefield. Due toGather Specimens, itenters thebattlefieldunderyouropponent«scontrolinsteadofyours.However, sinceyouchosetopaythecost,Dermoplasm is still returned toitsowner«shand.

118.12a. Some spells,`activated abilities <#activated_ability>`__,and triggered abilities <#triggered_ability>`__read, „[Do something] `unless [a`player <#player>`__ does something else].” Thismeans the same thing as „[A player <#player>`__may do something else]. If [that`player doesn’t], [do something].”

118.12b. Some effects <#effect>`__offer a `player a choice to`search <#search>`__ a zone and takeadditional actions with the cards <#card>`__found in that `zone, followed by an”If [a player] does” clause. Thisclause checks whether the player <#player>`__chose to `search, not whether the`player <#player>`__ took any of the additionalactions.

118.13. Some costs contain`mana symbols <#mana_symbol>`__ that can be paidin multiple ways. These include hybrid manasymbols and Phyrexianmana symbols.

118.13a. If the manacost of a spell orthe activation cost of an`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__contains a mana symbol thatcan be paid in multiple ways, the choice of howto pay for that symbol is made as its`controller <#control_controller>`__ proposesthat spell or`ability <#ability>`__ (see rule`601.2b <#R6012b>`__).

118.13b. If a cost paid`during <#during>`__ the resolution of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__contains a `mana symbol thatcan be paid in multiple ways, the`player <#player>`__ paying that`cost <#cost>`__ chooses how to pay <#pay>`__for that symbol immediately before they`pay that cost.

118.13c. If the cost <#cost>`__associated with a `specialaction contains a manasymbol that can be paid inmultiple ways, the player takingthe special action chooseshow to pay for that symbolimmediately before they pay that`cost <#cost>`__.

119. Life

119.1. Each player beginsthe game with a starting lifetotal of 20. Some`variant <#variant>`__ games have different`starting life totals <#starting_life_total>`__.

119.1a. In a Two-Headed Giant game,each team’s starting lifetotal is 30. See rule`810 <#R810>`__, „Two-Headed GiantVariant.”

119.1b. In a Vanguard <#vanguard>`__game, each `player’s starting lifetotal is 20 plus orminus the life modifier oftheir vanguard card.See rule 902,”Vanguard.”

119.1c. In a Commander <#commander>`__game, each `player’s starting lifetotal is 40. See rule`903 <#R903>`__, „Commander.”

119.1d. In a two-player <#player>`__`Brawl game, each`player <#player>`__’s starting lifetotal is 25. In amultiplayer Brawl game, each`player <#player>`__’s starting lifetotal is 30. See rule`903.12 <#R90312>`__, „Brawl <#brawl>`__`Option.”

119.1e. In an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game, the`archenemy <#archenemy>`__’s starting lifetotal is 40. See rule`904 <#R904>`__, „Archenemy.”

119.2. Damage dealt to a`player <#player>`__ normally causes that`player <#player>`__ to lose that much`life <#life_life_total>`__. See rule`120.3 <#R1203>`__.

119.3. If an effect <#effect>`__causes a `player to gain`life <#life_life_total>`__ or lose`life <#life_life_total>`__, that`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal is adjustedaccordingly.

119.4. If a cost or`effect <#effect>`__ allows a`player <#player>`__ to pay an amountof life greater than 0,the player may do so only if their`life total <#life_life_total>`__ is greaterthan or equal to the amount of the payment. If a`player <#player>`__ pays`life <#life_life_total>`__, the payment issubtracted from their lifetotal; in other words, the`player <#player>`__ loses that much`life <#life_life_total>`__.

119.4a. If a cost or`effect <#effect>`__ allows a`player <#player>`__ to pay an amountof life greater than 0 ina Two-Headed Giant game, the`player <#player>`__ may do so only if their`team <#team>`__’s lifetotal is greater than orequal to the total amount of`life <#life_life_total>`__ both`team <#team>`__ members are paying for that`cost <#cost>`__ or effect. If a`player <#player>`__ pays`life <#life_life_total>`__, the payment issubtracted from their team’s lifetotal.

119.4b. Players canalways pay 0`life <#life_life_total>`__, no matter whattheir (or their team’s) lifetotal is, and even if an`effect <#effect>`__ says players <#player>`__can’t `pay <#pay>`__`life.

119.5. If an effect setsa player’s lifetotal to a specificnumber, the player gains or losesthe necessary amount of`life <#life_life_total>`__ to end up with thenew total.

119.6. If a player has 0or less life, that`player <#player>`__ loses the game as a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704.

119.7. If an effect saysthat a player can’t gain`life <#life_life_total>`__, that`player <#player>`__ can’t make an`exchange <#exchange>`__ such that the`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal would`become <#becomes>`__ higher; in that case, the`exchange <#exchange>`__ won’t happen.Similarly, if an effect <#effect>`__redistributes `lifetotals, a`player <#player>`__ can’t receive a new lifetotal such that the`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal would`become <#becomes>`__ higher. In addition, a`cost <#cost>`__ that involves having that`player <#player>`__ gain`life <#life_life_total>`__ can’t be paid, and a`replacement effect <#replacement_effect>`__that would replace a life <#life_life_total>`__gain `event affecting that`player <#player>`__ won’t do anything.

119.8. If an effect saysthat a player can’t lose`life <#life_life_total>`__, that`player <#player>`__ can’t make an`exchange <#exchange>`__ such that the`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal would`become <#becomes>`__ lower; in that case, the`exchange <#exchange>`__ won’t happen.Similarly, if an effect <#effect>`__redistributes `lifetotals, a`player <#player>`__ can’t receive a new lifetotal such that the`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal would`become <#becomes>`__ lower. In addition, a`cost <#cost>`__ that involves having that`player <#player>`__ pay <#pay>`__`life can’t be paid.

119.9. Some triggeredabilities are written,”Whenever [a player] gains`life <#life_life_total>`__, … .” Such`abilities <#ability>`__ are treated asthough they are written,”Whenever a source causes [a`player <#player>`__] to gain`life <#life_life_total>`__, … .” If a`player <#player>`__ gains 0`life <#life_life_total>`__, no`life <#life_life_total>`__ gain`event <#event>`__ has occurred, and these`abilities <#ability>`__ won’t`trigger <#trigger>`__.

119.10. Some replacementeffects are written,”If [a player] would gain`life <#life_life_total>`__, … .” Such`abilities <#ability>`__ are treated asthough they are written, „If asource would cause [a player] togain life, … .” If a`player <#player>`__ gains 0`life <#life_life_total>`__, no`life <#life_life_total>`__ gain`event <#event>`__ would occur, and these`effects <#effect>`__ won’t apply.

120. Damage

120.1. Objects can`deal <#deal>`__ damage to`creatures <#creature>`__,`planeswalkers <#planeswalker>`__, and`players <#player>`__. This is generallydetrimental to the object or`player <#player>`__ that receives that`damage <#damage>`__. An object <#object>`__that `deals damage isthe source of that damage.

120.1a. Damage can’t bedealt to an object that’s neithera creature nor a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__.

120.2. Any object can`deal <#deal>`__ damage.

120.2a. Damage may bedealt as a result of combat. Each attacking and`blocking creature <#blocking_creature>`__`deals <#deal>`__ combatdamage equal to its`power <#power>`__ during the`combat damage step <#combat_damage_step>`__.

120.2b. Damage may bedealt as an effect of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability.The spell or ability <#ability>`__will specify which `object <#object>`__`deals that damage.

120.3. Damage may haveone or more of the following results, dependingon whether the recipient of the`damage <#damage>`__ is a player <#player>`__or `permanent, the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ of the`damage <#damage>`__’s source, and the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ of the`damage <#damage>`__’s recipient (if it’s a`permanent <#permanent>`__).

120.3a. Damage dealt to a`player <#player>`__ by a source without`infect <#infect>`__ causes that`player <#player>`__ to lose that much`life <#life_life_total>`__.

120.3b. Damage dealt to a`player <#player>`__ by a source with`infect <#infect>`__ causes that source’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ to give the`player <#player>`__ that many poisoncounters.

120.3c. Damage dealt to a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ causes thatmany loyalty <#loyalty>`__`counters to be`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__from that planeswalker.

120.3d. Damage dealt to a`creature <#creature>`__ by a source with`wither <#wither>`__ and/or infect <#infect>`__causes that source’s`controller to put thatmany -1/-1 counters on that`creature <#creature>`__.

120.3e. Damage dealt to a`creature <#creature>`__ by a source withneither wither nor`infect <#infect>`__ causes that much`damage <#damage>`__ to be marked on that`creature <#creature>`__.

120.3f. Damage dealt by asource with lifelink causes thatsource’s controller togain that much life, inaddition to the damage’s otherresults.

120.4. Damage isprocessed in a four-part sequence.

120.4a. First, if an`effect <#effect>`__ that’s causing`damage <#damage>`__ to be dealt states that`excess damage <#excess_damage>`__ that would bedealt to a permanent is dealtto another permanent or`player <#player>`__ instead, the`damage <#damage>`__ event ismodified accordingly. If the first`permanent <#permanent>`__ is a`creature <#creature>`__, the excessdamage is the amount of`damage <#damage>`__ in excess of what would be`lethal damage <#lethal_damage>`__, taking intoaccount damage already marked onthe creature and`damage <#damage>`__ from other sources thatwould be dealt at the same time. (See rule`120.6 <#R1206>`__.) If the first`permanent <#permanent>`__ is a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, the excessdamage is the amount of`damage <#damage>`__ in excess of that`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__’s`loyalty <#loyalty>`__, taking into account`damage <#damage>`__ from other sources thatwould be dealt at the same time. If the first`permanent <#permanent>`__ is both a`creature <#creature>`__ and a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, the excessdamage is the greater ofthose two amounts.

120.4b. Second, damage isdealt, as modified by replacement and`prevention effects <#prevention_effect>`__ thatinteract with damage. (See rule`614 <#R614>`__, „ReplacementEffects,” and rule`615 <#R615>`__, „PreventionEffects.”)`Abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ when damage <#damage>`__is dealt `trigger now and wait tobe put on the stack.

120.4c. Third, damage <#damage>`__that’s been dealt is processed into its results,as modified by `replacementeffects that interactwith those results (such as`life <#life_life_total>`__ loss or`counters <#counter>`__).

120.4d. Finally, the`damage <#damage>`__ event occurs.*Example:A*playerwhocontrolsBoonReflection,anenchantmentthat says”Ifyouwouldgainlife,yougaintwice thatmuchlifeinstead,”attackswitha3/3creaturewithwitherandlifelink.It’s blocked by a2/2creature, andthedefendingplayercastsaspellthatpreventsthenext 2damagethat would bedealt to theblockingcreature.Thedamageeventstartsout as [3damageis dealt tothe 2/2creature,2damageis dealt to the3/3creature].Thepreventioneffectis applied, sothedamageeventbecomes[1damageisdealt to the 2/2creature,2damageis dealt to the3/3creature]. That’sprocessed into its results, sothedamageeventisnow [one -1/-1counteris puton the 2/2creature,theactive playergains1life,2damageis marked on the3/3creature]. BoonReflection’seffectisapplied, sothedamageeventbecomes[one-1/-1counteris put on the2/2creature, theactiveplayergains2life,2damageis marked on the3/3creature]. Thenthedamageeventoccurs.**Example: ThedefendingplayercontrolsacreatureandWorship,anenchantmentthat says”Ifyoucontrolacreature,damagethatwould reduceyourlifetotalto less than 1reduces it to 1instead.”Thatplayeris at2life, and is beingattacked by two unblocked5/5creatures.TheplayercastsAweStrike, which says „The nexttimetargetcreaturewoulddealdamagethisturn,preventthatdamage.Yougainlifeequalto thedamageprevented thisway,” targeting one of the attackers.Thedamageeventstartsout as [10damageis dealt tothedefendingplayer]. AweStrike’seffectis applied, sothedamageeventbecomes[5damageisdealt to thedefendingplayer,thedefendingplayergains5life]. That’sprocessed into its results, sothedamageeventisnow [thedefendingplayerloses5life,thedefendingplayergains5life].Worship’seffectsees thatthedamageeventwouldnot reducetheplayer«slifetotalto less than 1, soWorship’seffectis notapplied. Thenthedamageeventoccurs.

120.5. Damage dealt to a`creature <#creature>`__ or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ doesn’t`destroy <#destroy>`__ it. Likewise, the sourceof that damage doesn’t`destroy <#destroy>`__ it. Rather, state-basedactions may`destroy <#destroy>`__ a`creature <#creature>`__ or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, or otherwiseput it into its owner’s`graveyard <#graveyard>`__, due to the resultsof the damage dealt to that`permanent <#permanent>`__. See rule`704. <#R704>`__ Example:AplayercastsLightningBolt, aninstantthat says”LightningBoltdeals3damagetoanytarget,” targeting a2/2creature. AfterLightningBoltdeals3damagetothatcreature,thecreatureis destroyed asastate-basedaction. NeitherLightning Bolt northedamagedealt by LightningBolt destroyedthatcreature.

120.6. Damage marked on a`creature <#creature>`__ remains until the`cleanup step <#cleanup_step>`__, even if that`permanent <#permanent>`__ stops being a`creature <#creature>`__. If the total`damage <#damage>`__ marked on a`creature <#creature>`__ is greater than orequal to its toughness, that`creature <#creature>`__ has been dealt lethaldamage and is destroyed as a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__(see rule 704). All`damage <#damage>`__ marked on a`permanent <#permanent>`__ is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__when it regenerates (see rule`701.15 <#R70115>`__,”Regenerate”) and`during <#during>`__ the cleanupstep (see rule`514.2 <#R5142>`__).

120.7. The source ofdamage is the`object <#object>`__ that dealt it. If an`effect <#effect>`__ requires a`player <#player>`__ to choose a source ofdamage, they may choose a`permanent <#permanent>`__; a spell <#spell>`__on the `stack (including a`permanent spell <#permanent_spell>`__); any`object <#object>`__ referred to by an`object <#object>`__ on the stack,by a prevention or replacementeffect that’s waitingto apply, or by a delayed triggeredability that’swaiting to trigger (even if that`object <#object>`__ is no longer in the`zone <#zone>`__ it used to be in); or a face-up`object <#object>`__ in the`command <#command>`__ zone. Asource doesn’t need to be capable of dealing`damage <#damage>`__ to be a legal choice. Seerule 609.7, „Sources of`Damage <#damage>`__.”

120.8. If a source would`deal <#deal>`__ 0 damage, it doesnot deal damage atall. That means abilities that`trigger <#trigger>`__ on damage <#damage>`__being dealt won’t `trigger. Italso means that replacementeffects that wouldincrease the damage dealt by thatsource, or would have that source`deal <#deal>`__ that damage to adifferent object or`player <#player>`__, have no event <#event>`__to replace, so they have no`effect.

120.9. If an ability <#ability>`__`triggers on damage <#damage>`__being dealt by a specific source or sources, andthe `effect refers to the”damage dealt,” it refers only tothe damage dealt by the specifiedsources and not to any `damage <#damage>`__dealt at the same time by other sources.

120.10. Some triggeredabilities check whethera permanent has been dealt`excess damage <#excess_damage>`__. These`abilities <#ability>`__ check after the`permanent <#permanent>`__ has been dealt`damage <#damage>`__ by one or more sources. Ifthose sources together dealt an amount of`damage <#damage>`__ to a`creature <#creature>`__ greater than lethaldamage, excessdamage equal to thedifference was dealt to that`creature <#creature>`__. If those sourcestogether dealt an amount of damage <#damage>`__to a `planeswalker greaterthan that planeswalker’s`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ before the`damage <#damage>`__ was dealt, excessdamage equal to thedifference was dealt to that`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__. If a`permanent <#permanent>`__ is both a`creature <#creature>`__ and a`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, the excessdamage dealt to that`permanent <#permanent>`__ is the greater ofthose two amounts.

121. Drawing a Card

121.1. A player <#player>`__`draws a card by puttingthe top card of their`library <#library>`__ into their`hand <#hand>`__. This is done as a turn-basedaction <#turn-based_actions>`__`during each player’s`draw step <#draw_step>`__. It may also be doneas part of a cost or`effect <#effect>`__ of a spell or`ability <#ability>`__.

121.2. Cards may only bedrawn one at a time. If a player <#player>`__is instructed to `draw multiple`cards <#card>`__, that player <#player>`__performs that many individual `card <#card>`__`draws.

121.2a. An instruction to`draw <#draw>`__ multiple cards canbe modified by replacementeffects that refer tothe number of cards drawn. Thismodification occurs before considering any ofthe individual card <#card>`__`draws. See rule`616.1f <#R6161f>`__.

121.2b. Some effects saythat a player can’t`draw <#draw>`__ more than one card <#card>`__each turn. Such an `effect appliesto individual card <#card>`__`draws. Instructions to`draw <#draw>`__ multiple cards maystill be partially carried out. However, if an`effect <#effect>`__ offers the`player <#player>`__ a choice to`draw <#draw>`__ multiple cards, theaffected player can’t choose to doso. Similarly, the player can’t`pay <#pay>`__ a cost that includesdrawing multiple cards.

121.2c. If an effect <#effect>`__instructs more than one `player to`draw <#draw>`__ cards, the activeplayer performs all of their`draws <#draw>`__ first, then each other`player <#player>`__ in turn order does thesame.

121.2d. If a rule or`effect <#effect>`__ instructs more than one`player <#player>`__ to draw <#draw>`__`cards in a game that’s using the`shared team turnsoption <#shared_team_turns_option>`__ (such as aTwo-Headed Giant game), first each`player <#player>`__ on the activeteam, in whatever order that`team <#team>`__ likes, performs their`draws <#draw>`__, then each`player <#player>`__ on each nonactive`team <#team>`__ in turn order does the same.

121.3. If there are no`cards <#card>`__ in a player’s`library <#library>`__ and an`effect <#effect>`__ offers that`player <#player>`__ the choice to`draw <#draw>`__ a card, that`player <#player>`__ can choose to do so.However, if an effect says that a`player <#player>`__ can’t draw <#draw>`__`cards and another`effect <#effect>`__ offers that`player <#player>`__ the choice to`draw <#draw>`__ a card, that`player <#player>`__ can’t choose to do so.

121.3a. The same principles apply ifthe player who’s making the choiceis not the player who would`draw <#draw>`__ the card. If thelatter player has no`cards <#card>`__ in their`library <#library>`__, the choice can be taken.If an effect says that the latter`player <#player>`__ can’t draw a`card <#card>`__, the choice can’t be taken.

121.4. A player whoattempts to draw a card <#card>`__from a `library with no`cards <#card>`__ in it loses the game the nexttime a player would receive`priority <#priority>`__. (This is a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704.)

121.5. If an effect <#effect>`__`moves cards from a`player <#player>`__’s library tothat player’s hand <#hand>`__without using the word „`draw,” the`player <#player>`__ has not drawn those`cards <#card>`__. This makes a difference for`abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ on drawing`cards <#card>`__ and effects thatreplace card draws, aswell as if the player’s`library <#library>`__ is empty.

121.6. Some effects <#effect>`__replace `card draws.

121.6a. An effect thatreplaces a card draw isapplied even if no cards could bedrawn because there are no cards inthe affected player’s`library <#library>`__.

121.6b. If an effect <#effect>`__replaces a `draw within a sequence of`card <#card>`__ draws, the`replacement effect <#replacement_effect>`__ iscompleted before resuming the sequence.

121.6c. Some effects <#effect>`__perform additional actions on a `card <#card>`__after it’s drawn. If the `draw isreplaced, the additional action is not performedon any cards that are drawn as aresult of that replacementeffect or anysubsequent replacementeffects.

121.7. Some replacementeffects and preventioneffects result in one ormore card draws. In sucha case, if there are any parts of the original`event <#event>`__ that haven’t been replaced,those parts occur first, then the`card <#card>`__ draws happen one ata time.

121.8. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ causes a card <#card>`__to be drawn while another `spell isbeing cast, the drawn`card <#card>`__ is kept facedown until that`spell <#spell>`__ becomes <#becomes>`__`cast (see rule 601.2i)or until the casting process is reversed (seerule 723, „Handling IllegalActions”). The same is truewith relation to another ability <#ability>`__being activated. If an `effect <#effect>`__allows or instructs a `player to`reveal <#reveal>`__ the card asit’s being drawn, it’s revealed after the`spell <#spell>`__ becomes <#becomes>`__`cast or the ability <#ability>`__`becomes activated. While facedown, the drawn card <#card>`__is considered to have no`characteristics and can’tbe used to pay any part of the`cost <#cost>`__ of the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that would require the`card <#card>`__ to have specific`characteristics <#characteristics>`__.

121.9. If an effect givesa player the option <#option>`__to `reveal a card asthey draw it, that`player <#player>`__ may look at that`card <#card>`__ as they draw itbefore choosing whether to `reveal <#reveal>`__it.

122. Counters

122.1. A counter is amarker placed on an`object <#object>`__ or player <#player>`__that modifies its`characteristics and/orinteracts with a rule, ability,or effect. Counters <#counter>`__are not `objects and have no`characteristics <#characteristics>`__. Notably,a counter is not a`token <#token>`__, and a token isnot a counter.`Counters <#counter>`__ with the same`name <#name>`__ or description areinterchangeable.

122.1a. A +X/+Y <#y>`__`counter on a`creature <#creature>`__ or on a`creature <#creature>`__ card in a`zone <#zone>`__ other than the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, where X <#x>`__and `Y are numbers, adds X tothat object’s power <#power>`__and `Y to that object’s`toughness <#toughness>`__. Similarly,-X/-Y counters <#counter>`__subtract from `power and`toughness <#toughness>`__. See rule`613.4c <#R6134c>`__.

122.1b. A keywordcounter on a`permanent <#permanent>`__ or on a`card <#card>`__ in a zone otherthan the battlefield causesthat object to gain that keyword.The keywords that a keywordcounter can be are`flying <#flying>`__, firststrike, doublestrike,`deathtouch <#deathtouch>`__,`haste <#haste>`__, hexproof,`indestructible <#indestructible>`__,`lifelink <#lifelink>`__, menace,`reach <#reach>`__, trample, and`vigilance <#vigilance>`__, as well as any`variants <#variant>`__ of those keywords. Seerule 613.1f.

122.1c. The number of`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ counters <#counter>`__on a `planeswalker on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ indicates howmuch loyalty it has. A`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ with 0`loyalty <#loyalty>`__ is put into its`owner <#owner>`__’s graveyard <#graveyard>`__as a `state-basedaction. See rule`704. <#R704>`__

122.1d. If a player hasten or more poisoncounters, that`player <#player>`__ loses the game as a`state-based action <#state-based_actions>`__.See rule 704. A player <#player>`__is „`poisoned” if they have oneor more poison counters.(See rule 810 for additional rulesfor Two-Headed Giant games.)

122.2. Counters on an`object <#object>`__ are not retained if that`object <#object>`__ moves from one`zone <#zone>`__ to another. The`counters <#counter>`__ are not”removed”;they simply cease to exist. See rule`400.7 <#R4007>`__.

122.3. If a permanent <#permanent>`__has both a +1/+1 `counter and a-1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 andN -1/-1 counters are`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__from it as a state-basedaction, where N is thesmaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1`counters <#counter>`__ on it. See rule`704. <#R704>`__

122.4. If a permanent <#permanent>`__with an `ability that says itcan’t have more than N counters <#counter>`__of a certain kind on it has more than N`counters of that kind on it, allbut N of those counters are`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__from it as a state-basedaction. See rule`704. <#R704>`__

122.5. If an effect saysto „move” a counter,it means to remove that counter <#counter>`__from the `object it’s currently onand put it onto a second object.If either of these actions isn’t possible, it’snot possible to move a`counter <#counter>`__, and no`counter <#counter>`__ is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__from or put onto anything. This may occur if thefirst and second objects are thesame object; if the first`object <#object>`__ doesn’t have theappropriate kind of counter onit; if the second object can’thave counters put onto it; or ifeither object is no longer in thecorrect zone.

122.6. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ refer to`counters <#counter>`__ being put on an`object <#object>`__. This refers to putting`counters <#counter>`__ on that`object <#object>`__ while it’s on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ and also to an`object <#object>`__ that’s given`counters <#counter>`__ as it enters thebattlefield.

122.6a. If an object <#object>`__`enters thebattlefield with`counters <#counter>`__ on it, the`effect <#effect>`__ causing the`object <#object>`__ to be given`counters <#counter>`__ may specify which`player <#player>`__ puts those`counters <#counter>`__ on it. If the`effect <#effect>`__ doesn’t specify a`player <#player>`__, the object’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ puts those`counters <#counter>`__ on it.

122.7. An ability that`triggers <#trigger>`__ „When/Whenever the Nth[kind] counter” is put on an`object <#object>`__ triggers <#trigger>`__when one or more `counters of theappropriate kind are put on the`object <#object>`__ such that the`object <#object>`__ had fewer than N`counters <#counter>`__ on it before the`counters <#counter>`__ were put on it and N ormore counters on it after.

122.8. If a triggeredability instructs a`player <#player>`__ to put one`object <#object>`__’s counters <#counter>`__on another `object and that`ability <#ability>`__’s triggercondition or`effect <#effect>`__ checks that the`object <#object>`__ with those`counters <#counter>`__ left the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, the`player <#player>`__ doesn’t move <#move>`__`counters from one`object <#object>`__ to the other. Rather, the`player <#player>`__ puts the same number ofeach kind of counter the first`object <#object>`__ had onto the second`object <#object>`__.

2. Parts of a Card

200. General

200.1. The parts of a card <#card>`__are `name, manacost,`illustration <#illustration>`__, colorindicator, typeline, expansionsymbol, textbox, power and`toughness <#toughness>`__,`loyalty <#loyalty>`__, handmodifier, lifemodifier, illustrationcredit, legaltext, and collectornumber. Some`cards <#card>`__ may have more than one of anyor all of these parts.

200.2. Some parts of a card <#card>`__are also `characteristics <#characteristics>`__of the `object that has them. Seerule 109.3.

200.3. Some objects thataren’t cards (tokens,`copies <#copy>`__ of cards, and`copies <#copy>`__ of spells) havesome of the parts of a card, butonly the ones that are also`characteristics <#characteristics>`__. See rule`111 <#R111>`__ and rule 706.

201. Name

201.1. The name of a`card <#card>`__ is printed on its upper leftcorner.

201.2. A card’s`name <#name>`__ is always considered to be theEnglish version of its name,regardless of printed language.

201.2a. Two or more`objects <#object>`__ have the same`name <#name>`__ if they have at least one`name <#name>`__ in common, even if one or moreof those objects have additional`names <#name>`__. An object withno name doesn’t have the same`name <#name>`__ as any other`object <#object>`__, including another`object <#object>`__ with no name.

201.2b. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ refer to two or more`objects <#object>`__ with different`names <#name>`__. Those objects <#object>`__have different `names only if each ofthem has at least one name and notwo objects in that group have a`name <#name>`__ in common. Example:AplayercontrolsLiliana’sContract, which says, in part, „At the beginningofyourupkeep,ifyoucontrolfouror more Demons withdifferentnames,youwinthe game.”ThatplayercontrolsthreeDemons with differentnamesanda face-downcreaturewithnoname, withaneffectmaking it a Demon.Because thefourcreaturesinclude onewith noname, thosefourcreaturesdon’t countas four Demons withdifferentnames.Theabilityof Liliana’sContract won’ttrigger.

201.2c. Some spells or`abilities <#ability>`__ check if one`object <#object>`__ has a different`name <#name>`__ than a second`object <#object>`__ or group of`objects <#object>`__. The first`object <#object>`__ has a different`name <#name>`__ than those`objects <#object>`__ if the first`object <#object>`__ has at least one`name <#name>`__ and has no names incommon with any of the other`objects <#object>`__, even if one or more ofthe other objects have no`names <#name>`__. If the first`object <#object>`__ has no name, itdoes not have a different name thanany of the other objects, even ifthose other objects themselveshave names.

201.3. If an effect <#effect>`__instructs a `player to choose a`card <#card>`__ name, the`player <#player>`__ must choose the`name <#name>`__ of a card in the`Oracle <#oracle>`__ card reference.(See rule 108.1.) A`player <#player>`__ may not choose the`name <#name>`__ of a token <#token>`__`unless it’s also the`name <#name>`__ of a card.

201.3a. If a player isinstructed to choose a card <#card>`__`name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, the`player <#player>`__ must choose the`name <#name>`__ of a card whose`Oracle <#oracle>`__ text matches <#match>`__those `characteristics.(See rule 108.1.) Example:Dispossess reads, in part, „Chooseanartifactcardname.”Theplayercan choosethenameofanyartifactcard,even one that’s not legal in the format of thecurrent game. Theplayercan’tchooseIsland, even ifanIslandonthebattlefieldhas beenturned intoartifactbysomeeffect.

201.3b. If a player wantsto choose the name of a splitcard, the player <#player>`__must choose the `name of one of itshalves, but not both. (See rule`708. <#R708>`__) If a player isinstructed to choose a card <#card>`__`name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, use onlythat half’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ todetermine if this name can bechosen.

201.3c. If a player wantsto choose a flip card’salternative name, the`player <#player>`__ may do so. (See rule`709. <#R709>`__) If a player isinstructed to choose a card <#card>`__`name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, use the`card <#card>`__’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ asmodified by its alternative`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ todetermine if this name can bechosen.

201.3d. If a player wantsto choose the name of the back faceof a double-facedcard, the`player <#player>`__ may do so. (See rule`711. <#R711>`__) If a player isinstructed to choose a card <#card>`__`name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, use onlythe characteristics ofthe back face to determine if this`name <#name>`__ can be chosen.

201.3e. If a player wantsto choose the name of the combinedback face of a meld pair, the`player <#player>`__ may do so. (See rule`712. <#R712>`__) If a player isinstructed to choose a card <#card>`__`name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, use onlythe characteristics ofthe combined back face to determine if this`name <#name>`__ can be chosen.

201.3f. If a player wantsto choose an adventurercard’s alternative`name <#name>`__, the player maydo so. (See rule 715.) If a`player <#player>`__ is instructed to choose a`card <#card>`__ name with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, use the`card <#card>`__’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ asmodified by its alternative`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ todetermine if this name can bechosen.

201.4. Text that refers to the`object <#object>`__ it’s on by name <#name>`__means just that particular `object <#object>`__and not any other `objects withthat name, regardless of any`name <#name>`__ changes caused by game`effects <#effect>`__.

201.4a. If an ability’s`effect <#effect>`__ grants another`ability <#ability>`__ to an`object <#object>`__, and that second`ability <#ability>`__ refers to that first`ability <#ability>`__’s source by`name <#name>`__, the name refersonly to the specific object whichis that first ability’s source.The second ability does not referto any other object with the same`name <#name>`__ as the first`ability <#ability>`__’s source. However, if thesecond ability also moved thefirst ability’s source to adifferent public zone, the`name <#name>`__ refers to the`object <#object>`__ the source became in itsnew zone. This is also true if thesecond ability is copied onto anew object. Example: Gutter Grimehas anabilitythat reads”Whenever anontokencreatureyoucontroldies,put a slimecounteron GutterGrime, thencreatea greenOozecreaturetokenwith’Thiscreature«spowerandtoughnessareeach equal to the number ofslimecounterson GutterGrime.»” Theabilitygrantedto thetokenonly looks at theGutter Grime that createdthetoken, not at any otherGutter Grime onthebattlefield.Acopyofthattokenwould also haveanabilitythat referred onlyto the Gutter Grime that created theoriginaltoken.

201.4b. If an ability ofan object refers to that`object <#object>`__ by name, and an`object <#object>`__ with a different`name <#name>`__ gains that`ability <#ability>`__, each instance of thefirst name in the gained`ability <#ability>`__ that refers to the first`object <#object>`__ by name shouldbe treated as the second name.*Example: Quicksilver Elemental says, in part,”{U}: Quicksilver Elemental gainsall*activatedabilitiesoftargetcreatureuntilend of turn.” If it gainsanabilitythat says”{G}:RegenerateCudgelTroll,” activatingthatabilitywillregenerateQuicksilverElemental, not the Cudgel Troll it gainedtheabilityfrom. Example:Glacial Ray isaninstantwithspliceontoArcane that says „GlacialRaydeals2damagetoanytarget.” If it’s splicedonto a Kodama’sReach, thatKodama’sReachdeals2damagetothetarget. Example: DimirDoppelganger says”{1}{U}{B}:Exiletargetcreaturecardfromagraveyard. DimirDoppelgangerbecomesacopyofthatcardand gainsthisability.” DimirDoppelganger’sabilityisactivated targeting a RuneclawBearcard. TheDoppelgangerbecomesacopyofRuneclaw Bear and gainsanabilitythat should betreated as saying”{1}{U}{B}:Exiletargetcreaturecardfromagraveyard. RuneclawBearbecomesacopyofthatcardand gainsthisability.”

201.4c. Text printed on some`legendary <#legendary>`__ cards <#card>`__refers to that `card by a shortenedversion of its name. Instances of a`card <#card>`__’s shortened name <#name>`__used in this manner are treated `asthough they used the`card <#card>`__’s full name.

201.5. Some versions of Ikoria (tm):Lair of Behemoths cards and otherpromotional cards feature a`name <#name>`__ other than their own in theupper left corner, with their normal`name <#name>`__ in a secondary title bar belowit. These cards have only the`card <#card>`__ name specified inthe secondary title bar, not the`name <#name>`__ printed where a`card <#card>`__’s name wouldnormally appear. That name isconsidered flavor text andhas no effect on game`play <#play>`__.

202. Mana Cost and`Color <#color>`__

202.1. A card’s manacost is indicated by manasymbols near the top of the`card <#card>`__. (See rule 107.4.)On most cards, these symbols areprinted in the upper right corner. Some`cards <#card>`__ from the Future Sight set havealternate frames in which the manasymbols appear to the left ofthe illustration.

202.1a. The mana cost <#mana_cost>`__of an `object represents what a`player <#player>`__ must spend from their manapool to cast that`card <#card>`__. Unless an`object <#object>`__’s manacost includes Phyrexian manasymbols (see rule`107.4f <#R1074f>`__), paying that manacost requires matching the`type <#type>`__ of any colored or`colorless <#colorless>`__ manasymbols as well as paying the`generic mana <#generic_mana>`__ indicated inthe cost.

202.1b. Some objects haveno mana cost. This normallyincludes all land cards,any other cards that have no manasymbols where their manacost would appear,`tokens <#token>`__ (unless the`effect <#effect>`__ that creates <#create>`__them specifies otherwise), and `nontraditionalMagic cards.Having no mana cost representsan unpayable cost (see rule`118.6 <#R1186>`__). Note that lands <#land>`__are played without paying any `costs <#cost>`__(see rule `305, „Lands”).

202.2. An object is the`color <#color>`__ or colors of the`mana symbols <#mana_symbol>`__ in its manacost, regardless of the`color <#color>`__ of its frame.

202.2a. The five colors <#color>`__are white, blue, black, red, and green. Thewhite `mana symbol isrepresented by {W}, blue by {U}, black by {B},red by {R}, and green by {G}. Example:Anobjectwith amanacostof {2}{W} is white,anobjectwith amanacostof {2}iscolorless, and one withamana costof {2}{W}{B} isboth white and black.

202.2b. Objects with nocolored mana symbols in their`mana costs <#mana_cost>`__ are`colorless <#colorless>`__.

202.2c. An object withtwo or more different colored manasymbols in its manacost is each of the`colors <#color>`__ of those manasymbols. Most`multicolored <#multicolored>`__`cards <#card>`__ are printed with a gold frame,but this is not a requirement <#requirement>`__for a `card to be`multicolored <#multicolored>`__.

202.2d. An object withone or more hybrid manasymbols and/or`Phyrexian manasymbols <#phyrexian_mana_symbol>`__ in its manacost is all of the`colors <#color>`__ of those manasymbols, in addition to anyother colors the`object <#object>`__ might be. (Most`cards <#card>`__ with hybrid manasymbols in their manacosts are printed in a two-toneframe. See rule 107.4e.)

202.2e. An object mayhave a color indicator <#color_indicator>`__printed to the left of the `typeline. That object <#object>`__is each `color denoted by that`color indicator <#color_indicator>`__. (Seerule 204.)

202.2f. Effects maychange an object’s`color <#color>`__, give a color toa colorless <#colorless>`__`object, or make a colored`object <#object>`__ become <#becomes>`__`colorless; see rule`105.3 <#R1053>`__.

202.3. The converted manacost of an`object <#object>`__ is a number equal to thetotal amount of mana in its manacost, regardless of`color <#color>`__. Example: Amanacostof {3}{U}{U} translatesto aconverted manacostof 5.

202.3a. The converted manacost of an`object <#object>`__ with no manacost is 0, unless <#unless>`__that `object is the back face of atransforming double-faced`permanent <#permanent>`__ or is a melded`permanent <#permanent>`__.

202.3b. The converted manacost of a transformingdouble-faced permanent’s backface is calculated as though ithad the mana cost of its frontface. If a permanent is a`copy <#copy>`__ of the back face of a`transforming double-facedcard <#transforming_double-faced_cards>`__ (evenif the card representing that`copy <#copy>`__ is itself a double-facedcard), the convertedmana cost of that`permanent <#permanent>`__ is 0. Example:Huntmaster of the Fells is atransformingdouble-facedcardwithmanacost{2}{R}{G}.Itsconverted manacostis 4. Afterittransformsto its otherface (Ravager of the Fells), itsconvertedmana costremains4. Example: A Cloneenters thebattlefieldasacopyof Ravager of the Fells.Itsconverted manacostis 0.**Example: Insectile Aberration is the back faceof atransforming double-facedcardwhosefront face hasmanacost{U}.ItbecomesacopyofRavager of the Fells. Itsconverted manacostbecomes0.

202.3c. The converted manacost of a melded`permanent <#permanent>`__ is calculated asthough it had the combined manacost of the front faces of each`card <#card>`__ that represents it. If a`permanent <#permanent>`__ is a copy <#copy>`__of a melded `permanent (even ifthat copy is represented by twoother meld cards), the`converted mana cost <#converted_mana_cost>`__of the copy is 0.

202.3d. The converted manacost of a splitcard not on the`stack <#stack>`__ or of a fused splitspell on the`stack <#stack>`__ is determined from thecombined mana costs of itshalves. Otherwise, while a splitcard is on the`stack <#stack>`__, the converted manacost of the`spell <#spell>`__ is determined by the manacost of the half that was chosento be cast. See rule`708 <#R708>`__, „SplitCards.”

202.3e. When calculating the convertedmana cost of an`object <#object>`__ with an {X} in its`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__, X istreated as 0 while the object isnot on the stack, and X istreated as the number chosen for it while the`object <#object>`__ is on the`stack <#stack>`__.

202.3f. When calculating the convertedmana cost of an`object <#object>`__ with a hybrid manasymbol in its manacost, use the largest componentof each hybrid symbol. Example:Theconverted manacostofacardwithmanacost{1}{W/U}{W/U} is 3.**Example: Theconverted manacostofacardwithmanacost{2/B}{2/B}{2/B} is 6.

202.3g. Each Phyrexian manasymbol in a`card <#card>`__’s mana cost <#mana_cost>`__contributes 1 to its `converted manacost. Example:Theconverted manacostofacardwithmanacost{1}{W/P}{W/P} is 3.

202.4. Any additionalcost listed in an`object <#object>`__’s rulestext or imposed by an`effect <#effect>`__ isn’t part of the manacost. (See rule 601,”Casting Spells.”) Such`costs <#cost>`__ are paid at the same time asthe spell’s other`costs <#cost>`__.

203. Illustration

203.1. The`illustration <#illustration>`__ is printed onthe upper half of a card and has no`effect <#effect>`__ on game play.For example, a creature doesn’thave the flying <#flying>`__`ability unless <#unless>`__stated in its `rules text, evenif it’s depicted as flying.

204. ColorIndicator

204.1. The colorindicator is printed tothe left of the type line <#type_line>`__directly below the`illustration. It consists ofa circular symbol filled in with one or more`colors <#color>`__. A colorindicator is usually foundon nonland cards without a manacost.

204.2. An object with a`color indicator <#color_indicator>`__ is each`color <#color>`__ denoted by that colorindicator.

205. Type Line

205.1. The type line <#type_line>`__is printed directly below the`illustration. It containsthe card’s cardtype(s). It also contains the`card <#card>`__’s subtype(s)and supertype(s), ifapplicable.

205.1a. Some effects setan object’s cardtype. In such cases, the new`card type <#card_type>`__(s) replaces anyexisting card types.`Counters <#counter>`__, effects,and damage marked on the`object <#object>`__ remain with it, even ifthey are meaningless to the new cardtype. Similarly, when an`effect <#effect>`__ sets one or more of an`object <#object>`__’s subtypes,the new subtype(s) replaces anyexisting subtypes from theappropriate set (creaturetypes, landtypes, artifacttypes, enchantmenttypes, planeswalkertypes, or spelltypes). If an`object <#object>`__’s cardtype is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__,the subtypes correlated with that`card type <#card_type>`__ will remain if theyare also the subtypes of a cardtype the object <#object>`__currently has; otherwise, they are also`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__for the entire time the `object’s`card type <#card_type>`__ is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__.Removing an object’s`subtype <#subtype>`__ doesn’t affect its cardtypes at all.

205.1b. Some effects <#effect>`__change an `object’s cardtype,`supertype <#supertype>`__, or`subtype <#subtype>`__ but specify that the`object <#object>`__ retains a prior cardtype,`supertype <#supertype>`__, or`subtype <#subtype>`__. In such cases, all the`object <#object>`__’s prior cardtypes,`supertypes <#supertype>`__, and`subtypes <#subtype>`__ are retained. This ruleapplies to effects that use thephrase „in addition to its types” orthat state that something is „still a[type, supertype,or subtype].” Some`effects <#effect>`__ state that an`object <#object>`__ becomes an”artifact creature”;these effects also allow the`object <#object>`__ to retain all of its prior`card types <#card_type>`__ and`subtypes <#subtype>`__. Some`effects <#effect>`__ state that an`object <#object>`__ becomes a”[creature type or`types <#type>`__] artifactcreature”; these`effects <#effect>`__ also allow the`object <#object>`__ to retain all of its prior`card types <#card_type>`__ and`subtypes <#subtype>`__ other than creaturetypes, but replace anyexisting creature types.*Example: An*abilityreads,”Alllandsare1/1creaturesthat arestilllands.” Theaffectedlandsnow havetwocardtypes:creatureandland.If there were anylandsthatwere alsoartifactsbeforetheability«seffectappliedto them,thoselandswouldbecome„artifactlandcreatures,”not just „creatures,” or”landcreatures.”Theeffectallows them toretain boththeartifactandlandcardtypes. In addition,eachlandaffected bytheabilityretainsanylandtypesandsupertypesithad beforetheabilitytookeffect.**Example: Anabilityreads,”Allartifactsare1/1artifactcreatures.” Ifapermanentis bothanartifactandanenchantment, itwillbecomeanartifactenchantmentcreature.

205.2. Card Types

205.2a. The card types <#card_type>`__are `artifact,`conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__,`creature <#creature>`__,`enchantment <#enchantment>`__,`instant <#instant>`__, land,`phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__,`plane <#plane>`__,`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__,`scheme <#scheme>`__, sorcery,`tribal <#tribal>`__, and`vanguard <#vanguard>`__. See section3, „Card Types.”
