612.3. Effects that addor remove abilities don’t changethe text of the objects theyaffect, so any abilities that aregranted to an object can’t bemodified by text-changingeffects that affectthat object.

612.4. A token’s`subtypes <#subtype>`__ and rulestext are defined by the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__that created the `token. A`text-changing effect <#text-changing_effect>`__that affects a token can changethese characteristics.

612.5. One card (Volrath’sShapeshifter) states that an`object <#object>`__ has the „full text” ofanother object. This changes notjust the text that appears in the`object <#object>`__’s text box <#text_box>`__and `type line, but also changesthe text that represents its name,`mana cost <#mana_cost>`__, colorindicator,`power <#power>`__, and`toughness <#toughness>`__.

612.6. One card (Spy Kit)states that an object has „all`names <#name>`__ of nonlegendary`creature <#creature>`__ cards.”This changes the text that represents the`object <#object>`__’s name. That`object <#object>`__ has the name ofeach nonlegendary creature <#creature>`__`card in the Oracle <#oracle>`__`card reference. (See rule`108.1 <#R1081>`__.)

612.7. One card (Awakeningof Vitu-Ghazi) creates a`continuous effect <#continuous_effect>`__ thatsets the name of an`object <#object>`__. This changes the text thatrepresents the object’s`name <#name>`__. That object <#object>`__loses any `names it had and has onlythe specified name.

612.8. A splice <#splice>`__`ability changes a`spell <#spell>`__’s text by adding the rulestext of the card <#card>`__with `splice to the`spell <#spell>`__, following that`spell <#spell>`__’s own rulestext. It doesn’t modify orreplace any of that spell’s owntext. (See rule 702.46,”Splice.”)

613. Interaction of ContinuousEffects

613.1. The values of an`object <#object>`__’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ aredetermined by starting with the actual`object <#object>`__. For a card,that means the values of the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ printedon that card. For a`token <#token>`__ or a copy of a`spell <#spell>`__ or card, thatmeans the values of the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ definedby the effect that created it.Then all applicable continuouseffects are applied in aseries of layers in the followingorder:

613.1a. Layer 1: Rules and`effects <#effect>`__ that modify copiablevalues are applied.

613.1b. Layer 2:Control-changing`effects <#effect>`__ are applied.

613.1c. Layer 3:Text-changingeffects are applied.See rule 612, „Text-ChangingEffects.”

613.1d. Layer 4:Type-changingeffects are applied.These include effects that changean object’s cardtype, subtype,and/or supertype.

613.1e. Layer 5:Color-changing`effects <#effect>`__ are applied.

613.1f. Layer 6:Ability-adding`effects <#effect>`__, keywordcounters,`ability <#ability>`__-removing`effects <#effect>`__, and effects <#effect>`__that say an `object can’t have an`ability <#ability>`__ are applied.

613.1g. Layer 7:Power- and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__-changing`effects <#effect>`__ are applied.

613.2. Within layer 1,apply effects in a series ofsublayers in the order described below. Withineach sublayer, apply effects in`timestamp order <#timestamp_order>`__ (see rule`613.7 <#R6137>`__). Note that`dependency <#dependency>`__ may alter the orderin which effects are appliedwithin a sublayer. (See rule`613.8 <#R6138>`__.)

613.2a. Layer 1a: Copiable`effects <#effect>`__ are applied. This includes`copy <#copy>`__ effects (see rule`706 <#R706>`__, „Copying`Objects <#object>`__”) and changes to an`object <#object>`__’s base`characteristics <#characteristics>`__determined by merging an object <#object>`__with a `permanent (see rule`721 <#R721>`__, „Merging with`Permanents <#permanent>`__”). „As … entersthe battlefield”and „as … is turned face up”abilities generate copiable`effects <#effect>`__ if they set`power <#power>`__ and`toughness <#toughness>`__, even if they alsodefine other`characteristics <#characteristics>`__.

613.2b. Layer 1b:Face-down spells and`permanents <#permanent>`__ have their`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ modifiedas defined in rule 707.2.

613.2c. After all rules and`effects <#effect>`__ in layer 1have been applied, the object’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ are its`copiable values <#copiable_values>`__. (Seerule 706.2.)

613.3. Within layers 2-6,apply effects from`characteristic-definingabilities <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__first (see rule 604.3), then allother effects in timestamporder (see rule`613.7 <#R6137>`__). Note that`dependency <#dependency>`__ may alter the orderin which effects are appliedwithin a layer. (See rule`613.8 <#R6138>`__.)

613.4. Within layer 7,apply effects in a series ofsublayers in the order described below. Withineach sublayer, apply effects in`timestamp order <#timestamp_order>`__. (Seerule 613.7.) Note that`dependency <#dependency>`__ may alter the orderin which effects are appliedwithin a sublayer. (See rule`613.8 <#R6138>`__.)

613.4a. Layer 7a:Effects from`characteristic-definingabilities <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__that define power and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ are applied. See rule`604.3 <#R6043>`__.

613.4b. Layer 7b:Effects that set`power <#power>`__ and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ to a specific numberor value are applied. Effects thatrefer to the basepower and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ of a`creature <#creature>`__ apply in this`layer <#layer>`__.

613.4c. Layer 7c:Effects and`counters <#counter>`__ that modify`power <#power>`__ and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ (but don’t set`power <#power>`__ and/or`toughness <#toughness>`__ to a specific numberor value) are applied.

613.4d. Layer 7d:Effects that switch a`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__and `toughness are applied. Such`effects <#effect>`__ take the value of`power <#power>`__ and apply it to the`creature <#creature>`__’s`toughness <#toughness>`__, and take the valueof toughness and apply it tothe creature’s`power <#power>`__. Example: A1/3creatureis given +0/+1by aneffect. Thenanothereffectswitchesthecreature«spowerandtoughness.Itsnewpowerandtoughnessis4/1. A neweffectgivesthecreature+5/+0. Its”unswitched”powerandtoughnesswouldbe 6/4, so itsactualpowerandtoughnessis4/6. Example: A1/3creatureis given +0/+1by aneffect. Thenanothereffectswitchesthecreature«spowerandtoughness.Itsnewpowerandtoughnessis4/1. If the +0/+1effectendsbefore the switcheffectends,thecreaturebecomes3/1.**Example: A 1/3creatureisgiven +0/+1 by aneffect.Then anothereffectswitchesthecreature«spowerandtoughness.Then anothereffectswitchesitspowerandtoughnessagain.The two switches essentially cancel each other,andthecreaturebecomes1/4.

613.5. The application of continuouseffects as described bythe layer system is continually andautomatically performed by the game. Allresulting changes to an object’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ areinstantaneous. Example: Honor of the Pure isanenchantmentthat reads”Whitecreaturesyoucontrolget+1/+1.” Honor of the Pure and a 2/2blackcreatureare onthebattlefieldunderyourcontrol.If aneffectthen turnsthecreaturewhite(layer5), it gets +1/+1 fromHonor of the Pure (layer7c),becoming 3/3. Ifthecreature«scolorislater changed to red(layer5), Honor of thePure’seffectstops applyingto it, and it will return to being 2/2.**Example: Gray Ogre, a2/2creature, is onthebattlefield.Aneffectputs a+1/+1counteron it(layer7d), making it 3/3.Aspelltargeting it that says”Targetcreaturegets+4/+4 until end ofturn”resolves(layer7c),making it 7/7.Anenchantmentthat says”Creaturesyoucontrolget+0/+2”enters thebattlefield(layer7c),making it 7/9. Aneffectthatsays”Targetcreaturebecomes0/1until end of turn” is applied to it(layer7b), making it 5/8(0/1, with +4/+4 from theresolvedspell, +0/+2 fromtheenchantment, and+1/+1 from thecounter).

613.6. If an effect <#effect>`__should be applied in different`layers and/or sublayers, the partsof the effect each apply in theirappropriate ones. If an effect <#effect>`__starts to apply in one `layer and/orsublayer, it will continue to be applied to thesame set of objects in each otherapplicable layer and/or sublayer,even if the ability generatingthe effect is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__`during <#during>`__ this process. Example:Aneffectthat reads „WildMongrel gets +1/+1andbecomesthecolorofyourchoiceuntil end of turn” is bothapower-andtoughness-changingeffectandacolor-changingeffect.The”becomesthecolorofyourchoice”part is applied inlayer5, andthen the „gets +1/+1” part is appliedinlayer7c. Example: Act ofTreason has aneffectthatreads”Gaincontroloftargetcreatureuntilend ofturn.Untapthatcreature.It gainshasteuntil end ofturn.” This is bothacontrol-changingeffectandaneffectthat addsanabilitytoanobject. The”gaincontrol„part is applied inlayer2, andthen the „it gainshaste” partis applied inlayer6.**Example: Aneffectthat reads”Allnoncreatureartifactsbecome2/2artifactcreaturesuntil end ofturn” is both atype-changingeffectandapower-andtoughness-settingeffect.Thetype-changingeffectis appliedto allnoncreatureartifactsinlayer4and thepower-andtoughness-settingeffectisapplied to thosesamepermanentsinlayer7b,even thoughthosepermanentsaren’tnoncreatureartifactsbythen. Example: Svogthos, the Restless Tomb, ison thebattlefield.Aneffectthat says „Until endofturn,targetlandbecomesa3/3creaturethat’s stillaland” is applied to it(layers4 and 7b).Aneffectthat says”Targetcreaturegets+1/+1 until end of turn” is applied to it(layer7c), making it a4/4landcreature.Then whileyouhavetencreaturecardsinyourgraveyard,youactivateSvogthos’sability:”Until end of turn, Svogthos, the RestlessTombbecomesa black andgreen PlantZombiecreaturewith’Thiscreature«spowerandtoughnessareeach equal to the numberofcreaturecardsinyourgraveyard.»It’s still aland.”(layers4, 5, and 7b).Itbecomesan11/11landcreature.Ifacreaturecardentersorleavesyourgraveyard,Svogthos’spowerandtoughnesswillbe modified accordingly. If thefirsteffectis applied to itagain, it willbecomea4/4landcreatureagain.

613.7. Within a layer orsublayer, determining which order`effects <#effect>`__ are applied in is usuallydone using a timestamp system. An`effect <#effect>`__ with an earlier timestampis applied before an effect with alater timestamp.

613.7a. A continuouseffect generated by a`static ability <#static_ability>`__ has thesame timestamp as the object the`static ability <#static_ability>`__ is on, orthe timestamp of the effect thatcreated the ability, whichever islater.

613.7b. A continuouseffect generated by theresolution of a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ receives a timestamp atthe time it’s created.

613.7c. Each counter <#counter>`__receives a timestamp as it’s put on an`object or player. Ifthat object or`player <#player>`__ already has a`counter <#counter>`__ of that kind on it, each`counter <#counter>`__ of that kind receives anew timestamp identical to that of the new`counter <#counter>`__.

613.7d. An object <#object>`__receives a timestamp at the time it enters a`zone.

613.7e. An Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ receives anew timestamp each time it`becomes <#becomes>`__ attached to an`object <#object>`__ or player.

613.7f. A permanent <#permanent>`__receives a new timestamp each time it turns`face up or facedown.

613.7g. A transforming double-faced`permanent <#permanent>`__ receives a newtimestamp each time it`transforms <#transform>`__.

613.7h. A face-up plane <#plane>`__`card, phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__`card, or scheme <#scheme>`__`card receives a timestamp at thetime it’s turned face up.

613.7i. A face-up`vanguard <#vanguard>`__ `card <#card>`__receives a timestamp at the beginning of thegame.

613.7j. A conspiracy <#conspiracy>`__`card receives a timestamp at thebeginning of the game. If it’s facedown, it receives a newtimestamp at the time it turns faceup.

613.7k. If two or more`objects <#object>`__ would receive a timestampsimultaneously, such as by entering a`zone <#zone>`__ simultaneously or becomingattached simultaneously, their relativetimestamps are determined in APNAPorder (see rule`101.4 <#R1014>`__). Objects <#object>`__controlled by the `activeplayer (or owned by the`active player <#active_player>`__, if they haveno controller) have anearlier relative timestamp in the order of that`player <#player>`__’s choice, followed by eachother player in turn order.

613.8. Within a layer orsublayer, determining which order`effects <#effect>`__ are applied in issometimes done using a`dependency <#dependency>`__ system. If a`dependency <#dependency>`__ exists, it willoverride the timestamp system.

613.8a. An effect is saidto „depend on” another if (a) it’s applied inthe same layer (and, if applicable,sublayer) as the other effect; (b)applying the other would change the text or theexistence of the first effect,what it applies to, or what it does to any ofthe things it applies to; and (c) neither`effect <#effect>`__ is from a`characteristic-definingability <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__ orboth effects are from`characteristic-definingabilities <#characteristic-defining_ability>`__.Otherwise, the effect isconsidered to be independent <#independent>`__of the other `effect.

613.8b. An effect <#effect>`__dependent on one or more other`effects waits to apply until justafter all of those effects havebeen applied. If multiple dependent`effects <#effect>`__ would apply simultaneouslyin this way, they’re applied in timestamporder relative to eachother. If several dependent`effects <#effect>`__ form a`dependency <#dependency>`__ loop,then this rule is ignored and the`effects <#effect>`__ in the`dependency <#dependency>`__ loop <#loop>`__are applied in `timestamporder.

613.8c. After each effect <#effect>`__is applied, the order of remaining`effects is reevaluated and maychange if an effect that has notyet been applied becomes <#becomes>`__dependent on or `independent <#independent>`__of one or more other `effects thathave not yet been applied.

613.9. One continuouseffect can overrideanother. Sometimes the results of one`effect <#effect>`__ determine whether another`effect <#effect>`__ applies or what another`effect <#effect>`__ does. Example:Twoeffectsare affecting thesamecreature: one fromanAurathat says”Enchantedcreaturehasflying„and one from anAurathat says”Enchantedcreaturelosesflying.”Neither of these depends on the other, sincenothing changes what they affect or what they’redoing to it. Applying them intimestampordermeans the one thatwas generated last „wins.” The same processwould be followed, and the same result reached,if either of theeffectshad aduration (such as”Targetcreaturelosesflyinguntilend of turn”) or came from anon-Aurasource (such as”Allcreaturesloseflying„).**Example: Oneeffectreads,”Whitecreaturesget +1/+1,”and another reads,”Enchantedcreatureiswhite.” Theenchantedcreaturegets+1/+1 from the firsteffect,regardless of itspreviouscolor.

613.10. Some continuouseffects affect`players <#player>`__ rather than`objects <#object>`__. For example, an`effect <#effect>`__ might give a`player <#player>`__`protection <#protection>`__ from red. All such`effects <#effect>`__ are applied in timestamporder after thedetermination of objects»characteristics. See alsothe rules for timestamporder and`dependency <#dependency>`__ (rules`613.7 <#R6137>`__ and 613.8).

613.11. Some continuouseffects affect gamerules rather than objects. Forexample, effects may modify a`player <#player>`__’s maximum handsize, or say that a`creature <#creature>`__ must`attack <#attack>`__ this turn if able. These`effects <#effect>`__ are applied after allother continuouseffects have beenapplied. Continuouseffects that affect the`costs <#cost>`__ of spells or`abilities <#ability>`__ are applied accordingto the order specified in rule`601.2f <#R6012f>`__. All other such`effects <#effect>`__ are applied in timestamporder. See also the rulesfor timestamp order and`dependency <#dependency>`__ (rules`613.7 <#R6137>`__ and 613.8).

614. ReplacementEffects

614.1. Some continuouseffects are replacementeffects. Like`prevention effects <#prevention_effect>`__ (seerule 615), replacementeffects applycontinuously as events happen–theyaren’t locked in ahead of time. Such`effects <#effect>`__ watch for a particular`event <#event>`__ that would happen andcompletely or partially replace that`event <#event>`__ with a different`event <#event>`__. They act like „shields”around whatever they’re affecting.

614.1a. Effects that usethe word „instead” are`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__.Most replacementeffects use the word”instead” to indicate what`events <#event>`__ will be replaced with other`events <#event>`__.

614.1b. Effects that usethe word „skip” are replacementeffects. These`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__use the word „skip” to indicate what`events <#event>`__, steps,`phases <#phase>`__, or turns will be replacedwith nothing.

614.1c. Effects that read”[This permanent] enters thebattlefield with .. . ,” „As [this permanent]`enters thebattlefield <#enters_the_battlefield>`__ …,” or „[This permanent] entersthe battlefield as… ” are replacementeffects.

614.1d. Continuouseffects that read „[This`permanent <#permanent>`__] enters thebattlefield …”or „[Objects] enter the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ …” are`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__.

614.1e. Effects that read”As [this permanent] is turned`face up <#face_up>`__ … ,” are replacementeffects.

614.2. Some replacementeffects apply to`damage <#damage>`__ from a source. See rule`609.7 <#R6097>`__.

614.3. There are no special`restrictions <#restriction>`__ on casting a`spell <#spell>`__ or activating an`ability <#ability>`__ that generates a`replacement effect <#replacement_effect>`__.Such effects last until they’reused up or their duration has expired.

614.4. Replacementeffects must existbefore the appropriate event <#event>`__occurs–they can’t „go back in time” and changesomething that’s already happened.`Spells or abilities <#ability>`__that generate these `effects areoften cast or activated in responseto whatever would producethe event and thus`resolve <#resolve>`__ before that`event <#event>`__ would occur. Example:Aplayercanactivateanabilitytoregenerateacreatureinresponsetoaspellthatwoulddestroyit. Oncethespellresolves,though, it’s too latetoregeneratethecreature.

614.5. A replacementeffect doesn’t invokeitself repeatedly; it gets only one opportunityto affect an event or any modified`events <#event>`__ that may replace that`event <#event>`__. Example:Aplayercontrolstwopermanents,each with anabilitythatreads „Ifacreatureyoucontrolwoulddealdamagetoapermanentorplayer,itdealsdoublethatdamagetothatpermanentorplayerinstead.”Acreaturethatnormallydeals2damagewilldeal8damage–notjust 4, and not an infinite amount.

614.6. If an event isreplaced, it never happens. A modified`event <#event>`__ occurs`instead <#instead>`__, which may in turn`trigger <#trigger>`__ abilities.Note that the modified event maycontain instructions that can’t be carried out,in which case the impossible instruction issimply ignored.

614.7. If a replacementeffect would replace an`event <#event>`__, but that event <#event>`__never happens, the `replacementeffect simply doesn’tdo anything.

614.7a. If a source would`deal <#deal>`__ 0 damage, it doesnot deal damage atall. Replacementeffects that wouldincrease the damage dealt by thatsource, or would have that source`deal <#deal>`__ that damage to adifferent object or`player <#player>`__, have no event <#event>`__to replace, so they have no`effect.

614.8. Regeneration is adestruction-replacementeffect. The word”instead” doesn’t appear on the`card <#card>`__ but is implicit in thedefinition of regeneration.”Regenerate <#regenerate>`__[`permanent]” means „The nexttime [permanent] would bedestroyed this turn, instead <#instead>`__remove all `damage marked on it and`tap <#tap>`__ it. If it’s an attacking or`blocking creature <#blocking_creature>`__,remove it from combat.” Abilities <#ability>`__that `trigger from`damage <#damage>`__ being dealt still`trigger <#trigger>`__ even if the`permanent <#permanent>`__`regenerates <#regenerate>`__. See rule`701.15 <#R70115>`__.

614.9. Some effects <#effect>`__replace `damage dealt to one`creature <#creature>`__,`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, or`player <#player>`__ with the same`damage <#damage>`__ dealt to another`creature <#creature>`__,`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__, or`player <#player>`__; such effects <#effect>`__are called `redirectioneffects. If either`creature <#creature>`__ or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ is no longer onthe battlefield when the`damage <#damage>`__ would be redirected, or isno longer a creature or`planeswalker <#planeswalker>`__ when the`damage <#damage>`__ would be redirected, the`effect <#effect>`__ does nothing. If`damage <#damage>`__ would be redirected to orfrom a player who has left thegame, the effect does nothing.

614.10. An effect thatcauses a player to`skip <#skip>`__ an event,`step <#step>`__, phase, or turn isa replacement effect.”Skip [something]” is the same as”Instead of doing [something], donothing.” Once a step,`phase <#phase>`__, or turn has started, it canno longer be skipped–any skip <#skip>`__`effects will wait until the nextoccurrence.

614.10a. Anything scheduled for askipped step, phase, orturn won’t happen. Anything scheduled for the”next” occurrence of something waits for thefirst occurrence that isn’t skipped. If two`effects <#effect>`__ each cause a`player <#player>`__ to skip theirnext occurrence, that player must`skip <#skip>`__ the next two; one`effect <#effect>`__ will be satisfied inskipping the first occurrence, while the otherwill remain until another occurrence can beskipped.

614.10b. Some effects <#effect>`__cause a `player to skip <#skip>`__a `step, phase, or turn,then take another action. That action isconsidered to be the first thing that happens`during <#during>`__ the next step,`phase <#phase>`__, or turn to actually occur.

614.11. Some effects <#effect>`__replace `card draws.These effects are applied even ifno cards could be drawn becausethere are no cards in the affected`player <#player>`__’s library.

614.11a. If an effect <#effect>`__replaces a `draw within a sequence of`card <#card>`__ draws, all actionsrequired by the replacement are completed, ifpossible, before resuming the sequence.

614.11b. If an effect <#effect>`__would have a `player both`draw <#draw>`__ a card and performan additional action on that card,and the draw is replaced, theadditional action is not performed on any`cards <#card>`__ that are drawn as a result ofthat replacementeffect.

614.12. Some replacementeffects modify how a`permanent <#permanent>`__ enters thebattlefield. (Seerules 614.1c-d.) Such`effects <#effect>`__ may come from the`permanent <#permanent>`__ itself if they affectonly that permanent (as opposedto a general subset of`permanents <#permanent>`__ that includes it).They may also come from other sources. Todetermine which replacementeffects apply and howthey apply, check the`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ of the`permanent <#permanent>`__ as it would exist onthe battlefield, taking intoaccount replacementeffects that havealready modified how it enters thebattlefield (seerule 616.1), continuouseffects from the`permanent <#permanent>`__’s own staticabilities that would applyto it once it’s on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, and continuouseffects that alreadyexist and would apply to the`permanent <#permanent>`__. Example: Voice ofAll says „As Voice of Allenters thebattlefield,choose acolor” and „Voice ofAll hasprotectionfromthe chosencolor.”Aneffectcreatesatokenthat’sacopyof Voice of All. Asthattokenis created,thetoken«scontrollerchoosesacolorfor it. Example:Yixlid Jailer says”Cardsingraveyardsloseallabilities.” ScarwoodTreefolk says „Scarwood Treefolkenters thebattlefieldtapped.”A Scarwood Treefolk that’s put ontothebattlefieldfromagraveyardenters thebattlefieldtapped.**Example: Orb of Dreams isanartifactthat says”Permanentsenterthebattlefieldtapped.”It won’t affect itself, so Orb ofDreamsenters thebattlefielduntapped.

614.12a. If a replacementeffect that modifieshow a permanent enters thebattlefield <#enters_the_battlefield>`__requires a choice, that choice is made beforethe `permanent enters thebattlefield.

614.12b. Some replacementeffects cause a`permanent <#permanent>`__ to enter the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ with its`controller <#control_controller>`__’s choice ofone of two abilities, each markedwith an anchor word andpreceded by a bullet point. „[Anchorword] –[ability]” means „As long as[anchor word] was chosen asthis permanent entered the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, this`permanent <#permanent>`__ has[ability].” The`abilities <#ability>`__ preceded by anchorwords are each linked to the`ability <#ability>`__ that causes a`player <#player>`__ to choose between them. Seerule 607, „LinkedAbilities.”

614.13. An effect thatmodifies how a permanent <#permanent>`__`enters thebattlefield maycause other objects to change`zones <#zone>`__.

614.13a. While applying an`effect <#effect>`__ that modifies how a`permanent <#permanent>`__ enters thebattlefield,`you <#you_your>`__ may have to choose a numberof objects that will also change`zones <#zone>`__. You can’tchoose the object that will`become <#becomes>`__ that`permanent <#permanent>`__ or any other`object <#object>`__ entering the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ at the same timeas that object. Example: SuturedGhoul says, in part, „As Sutured Ghoulentersthebattlefield,exileanynumberofcreaturecardsfromyourgraveyard.”If Sutured Ghoul and Runeclaw Bear enterthebattlefieldfromyourgraveyardatthe same time,youcan’tchoose toexileeither of themwhen applying Sutured Ghoul’sreplacementeffect.

614.13b. The same object <#object>`__can’t be chosen to change `zones morethan once when applying replacementeffects that modify howa single permanent enters thebattlefield.*Example: Jund(a*planecard)says, „Wheneveraplayercastsablack, red, orgreencreaturespell,it gainsdevour5.”AplayercontrolsRuneclawBear andcastsThunder-ThrashElder, aredcreaturespellwithdevour3.As Thunder-Thrash Elderenters thebattlefield,itscontrollercanchoosetosacrificeRuneclaw Bearwhen applyingthedevour3effectorwhen applyingthedevour5effect,but not both. Thunder-Thrash Elder will enterthebattlefieldwithzero, three, or five+1/+1counters, depending onthis choice.

614.14. An object mayhave one ability printed on itthat generates a replacementeffect which causes oneor more cards to be exiled, andanother ability that referseither to „the exiled cards” or to`cards <#card>`__ „exiled with [this`object <#object>`__].” These`abilities <#ability>`__ are linked: the secondrefers only to cards in the`exile <#exile>`__ zone that wereput there as a direct result of the replacement`event <#event>`__ caused by the first. Ifanother object gains a pair of`linked abilities <#linked_abilities>`__, the`abilities <#ability>`__ will be similarlylinked on that object. They can’tbe linked to any other ability,regardless of what other`abilities <#ability>`__ the`object <#object>`__ may currently have or mayhave had in the past. See rule 607,”Linked Abilities.”

614.15. Some replacementeffects are not`continuous effects <#continuous_effect>`__.Rather, they are an effect of aresolving spell or`ability <#ability>`__ that replace part or allof that spell or`ability <#ability>`__’s own`effect <#effect>`__(s). Such`effects <#effect>`__ are calledself-replacementeffects. The textcreating a self-replacementeffect is usually partof the ability whose`effect <#effect>`__ is being replaced, but thetext can be a separate ability,particularly when preceded by an abilityword. When applying`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__ toan event, self-replacementeffects are appliedbefore other replacementeffects.

614.16. Some replacementeffects apply „if an`effect <#effect>`__ would create <#create>`__one or more `tokens” or „if an`effect <#effect>`__ would put one or more`counters <#counter>`__ on a`permanent <#permanent>`__.” These replacementeffects apply if the`effect <#effect>`__ of a resolving`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__`creates a token orputs a counter on a`permanent <#permanent>`__, and they also applyif another replacement or preventioneffect does so, even ifthe original event being modifiedwasn’t itself an effect.

614.17. Some effects <#effect>`__state that something can’t happen. These`effects aren’t replacementeffects, but followsimilar rules.

614.17a. „Can’t” effects <#effect>`__must exist before the appropriate`event occurs–they can’t „go backin time” and change something that’s alreadyhappened.

614.17b. If an event can’thappen, a player can’t choose to`pay <#pay>`__ a cost that includesthat event.

614.17c. If an event can’thappen, it can only be replaced by aself-replacementeffect (see rule`614.15 <#R61415>`__). Other replacement and/or`prevention effects <#prevention_effect>`__can’t modify or replace it.

614.17d. Some „can’t”effects modify how a`permanent <#permanent>`__ enters thebattlefield orwhether it can enter the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__. Such`effects <#effect>`__ may come from the`permanent <#permanent>`__ itself if they affectonly that permanent (as opposedto a general subset of`permanents <#permanent>`__ that includes it).They may also come from other sources. Todetermine which „can’t” effects <#effect>`__apply, check the`characteristics of the`permanent <#permanent>`__ as it would exist onthe battlefield, taking intoaccount replacementeffects that havealready modified how it enters thebattlefield (seerule 616.1), continuouseffects from the`permanent <#permanent>`__’s own staticabilities that would applyto it once it’s on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, and continuouseffects that alreadyexist and would apply to the`permanent <#permanent>`__.

615. PreventionEffects

615.1. Some continuouseffects are preventioneffects. Like`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__(see rule 614), preventioneffects applycontinuously as events happen–theyaren’t locked in ahead of time. Such`effects <#effect>`__ watch for a`damage <#damage>`__ event thatwould happen and completely or partially`prevent <#prevent>`__ the `damage <#damage>`__that would be dealt. They act like „shields”around whatever they’re affecting.

615.1a. Effects that usethe word „prevent” are`prevention effects <#prevention_effect>`__.`Prevention effects <#prevention_effect>`__ use”prevent” to indicate what`damage <#damage>`__ will not be dealt.

615.2. Many preventioneffects apply to`damage <#damage>`__ from a source. See rule`609.7 <#R6097>`__.

615.3. There are no special`restrictions <#restriction>`__ on casting a`spell <#spell>`__ or activating an`ability <#ability>`__ that generates a`prevention effect <#prevention_effect>`__. Such`effects <#effect>`__ last until they’re used upor their duration has expired.

615.4. Preventioneffects must existbefore the appropriate damage <#damage>`__`event occurs–they can’t „go backin time” and change something that’s alreadyhappened. Spells or`abilities <#ability>`__ that generate these`effects <#effect>`__ are often cast <#cast>`__or activated `in responseto whatever would producethe event and thus`resolve <#resolve>`__ before that`event <#event>`__ would occur. Example:Aplayercanactivateanabilitythatpreventsdamageinresponsetoaspellthatwoulddealdamage.Oncethespellresolves,though, it’s too latetopreventthedamage.

615.5. Some preventioneffects also include anadditional effect, which may referto the amount of damage that wasprevented. The prevention takes place at thetime the original event would havehappened; the rest of the `effect <#effect>`__takes place immediately afterward.

615.6. If damage thatwould be dealt is prevented, it never happens. Amodified event may occur`instead <#instead>`__, which may in turn`trigger <#trigger>`__ abilities.Note that the modified event maycontain instructions that can’t be carried out,in which case the impossible instruction issimply ignored.

615.7. Some preventioneffects generated by theresolution of a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ refer to a specificamount of damage–for example,”Prevent the next 3`damage <#damage>`__ that would be dealt to anytarget this turn.” These worklike shields. Each 1 damage thatwould be dealt to the „shielded”permanent or`player <#player>`__ is prevented. Preventing 1`damage <#damage>`__ reduces the remainingshield by 1. If damage would bedealt to the shielded permanent <#permanent>`__or `player by two or moreapplicable sources at the same time, the`player <#player>`__ or the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`permanent <#permanent>`__ chooses which`damage <#damage>`__ the shield`prevents <#prevent>`__. Once the shield hasbeen reduced to 0, any remaining`damage <#damage>`__ is dealt normally. Such`effects <#effect>`__ count only the amount of`damage <#damage>`__; the number of`events <#event>`__ or sources dealing itdoesn’t matter.

615.8. Some preventioneffects generated by theresolution of a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ refer to the next time aspecific source would deal <#deal>`__`damage. These`effects <#effect>`__ prevent thenext instance of damage from thatsource, regardless of how much`damage <#damage>`__ that is. Once an instanceof damage from that source hasbeen prevented, any subsequent instances of`damage <#damage>`__ that would be dealt by thatsource are dealt normally.

615.9. Some effects <#effect>`__generated by the resolution of a`spell or ability <#ability>`__`prevent damage froma source of a player’s choice withcertain properties. When the source would`deal <#deal>`__ damage, theshield rechecks the source’s properties. If theproperties no longer match, the`damage <#damage>`__ isn’t prevented or replacedand the shield isn’t used up. See rule`609.7b <#R6097b>`__.

615.10. Some preventioneffects generated by`static abilities <#static_ability>`__ refer toa specific amount of damage–forexample, „If a source would deal <#deal>`__`damage to you,`prevent <#prevent>`__ 1 of that`damage <#damage>`__.” Such an`effect <#effect>`__ prevents <#prevent>`__only the indicated amount of`damage in any applicable`damage <#damage>`__ event at anygiven time. It will apply separately to`damage <#damage>`__ from other applicable`events <#event>`__ that would happen at thesame time, or at a different time. Example:DauntingDefendersays „If asourcewoulddealdamagetoaClericcreatureyoucontrol,prevent1of thatdamage.” Pyroclasmsays”Pyroclasmdeals2damagetoeachcreature.” Pyroclasmwilldeal1damagetoeachClericcreaturecontrolledbyDauntingDefender«scontroller.Itwilldeal2damagetoeach othercreature.

615.11. Some preventioneffects <#prevention_effect>`__`prevent the next N`damage <#damage>`__ that would be dealt to eachof a number of untargeted`creatures <#creature>`__. Such an`effect <#effect>`__ creates aprevention shield for each applicable`creature <#creature>`__ when the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__that generates that `effect <#effect>`__`resolves. Example: WojekApothecary hasanabilitythat says”{T}:Preventthe next1damagethat would be dealttotargetcreatureandeach othercreaturethatshares acolorwith it thisturn.” Whentheabilityresolves,it givesthetargetcreatureandeach othercreatureonthebattlefieldthatshares acolorwith it at thattime a shield preventing the next1damagethat would be dealtto it.Changingcreatures«colorsaftertheabilityresolvesdoesn’tadd or remove shields,andcreaturesthat enterthebattlefieldlater inthe turn don’t get the shield.

615.12. Some effects <#effect>`__state that `damage „can’t beprevented.” If unpreventable`damage <#damage>`__ would be dealt, anyapplicable preventioneffects are stillapplied to it. Those effects won’t`prevent <#prevent>`__ any damage,but any additional effects theyhave will take place. Existing`damage <#damage>`__ prevention shields won’t bereduced by damage that can’t beprevented.

615.12a. A preventioneffect is applied to anyparticular unpreventable damage <#damage>`__`event just once. It won’t invokeitself repeatedly trying to`prevent <#prevent>`__ that`damage <#damage>`__.

615.13. Some triggeredabilities <#triggered_ability>`__`trigger when damage <#damage>`__that would be dealt is prevented. Such an`ability triggers <#trigger>`__each time a `preventioneffect is applied to oneor more simultaneous damage <#damage>`__`events and prevents <#prevent>`__some or all of that `damage.

616. Interaction of Replacement and/or`Prevention Effects <#prevention_effect>`__

616.1. If two or more replacementand/or preventioneffects are attemptingto modify the way an event affectsan object or player,the affected object’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ (or its`owner <#owner>`__ if it has no`controller <#control_controller>`__) or theaffected player chooses one toapply, following the steps listedbelow. If two or more players haveto make these choices at the same time, choicesare made in APNAP order (seerule 101.4).

616.1a. If any of the replacementand/or preventioneffects areself-replacementeffects (see rule`614.15 <#R61415>`__), one of them must bechosen. If not, proceed to rule`616.1b <#R6161b>`__.

616.1b. If any of the replacementand/or preventioneffects would modifyunder whose control an`object <#object>`__ would enter the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, one of them mustbe chosen. If not, proceed to rule`616.1c <#R6161c>`__.

616.1c. If any of the replacementand/or preventioneffects would cause an`object <#object>`__ to become a`copy <#copy>`__ of another object <#object>`__as it `enters thebattlefield, one ofthem must be chosen. If not, proceed to rule`616.1d <#R6161d>`__.

616.1d. Any of the applicablereplacement and/or preventioneffects may be chosen.

616.1e. Once the chosen`effect <#effect>`__ has been applied, thisprocess is repeated (taking into account onlyreplacement or preventioneffects that would nowbe applicable) until there are no more left toapply. Example:Twopermanentsare onthebattlefield. One isanenchantmentthat reads”If acardwould be put intoagraveyardfromanywhere,insteadexileit,”and the other isacreaturethat reads „If[thiscreature]woulddie,insteadshuffleitintoitsowner«slibrary.”If thecreatureisdestroyed,itscontrollerdecideswhich replacement to apply first; the other doesnothing. Example: Essence of the Wild reads”Creaturesyoucontrolenterthebattlefieldasacopyof Essence of the Wild.”AplayerwhocontrolsEssenceof the WildcastsRustedSentinel, which normallyenters thebattlefieldtapped.As itenters thebattlefield,thecopyeffectfromEssence of the Wild is applied first. As aresult, it no longer hastheabilitythat causes it toenterthebattlefieldtapped.Rusted Sentinel will enterthebattlefieldasanuntappedcopyofEssence of the Wild.

616.1f. While following the`steps <#step>`__ in 616.1a-d, onereplacement or preventioneffect may apply to an`event <#event>`__, and another may apply to an`event <#event>`__ contained within the first`event <#event>`__. In this case, the second`effect <#effect>`__ can’t be chosen until afterthe first effect has been chosen.*Example: A*playerisinstructedtocreateatokenthat’sacopyof Voice of All, whichhas theability„As Voice ofAllenters thebattlefield,choose acolor.” DoublingSeason has anabilitythatreads „Ifaneffectwouldcreateoneormoretokensunderyourcontrol,itcreatestwice that many ofthosetokensinstead.”Because enteringthebattlefieldisaneventcontained withintheeventof creatingatoken,theeffectof Doubling Seasonmust be applied first, and thentheeffectsof the two Voiceof Alltokensmay be applied ineither order.

616.2. A replacement or preventioneffect can`become <#becomes>`__ applicable to an`event <#event>`__ as the result of anotherreplacement or preventioneffect that modifies the`event <#event>`__. Example:Oneeffectreads”Ifyouwouldgainlife,drawthatmanycardsinstead,”and another reads”Ifyouwoulddrawacard,returnacardfromyourgraveyardtoyourhandinstead.”Botheffectscombine(regardless of the order they came intoexistence):Insteadofgaining 1life,theplayerputsacardfromtheirgraveyardintotheirhand.

7. Additional Rules

700. General

700.1. Anything that happens in a gameis an event. Multiple`events <#event>`__ may take place`during <#during>`__ the resolution of a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability.The text of triggeredabilities and`replacement effects <#replacement_effect>`__defines the event they’re lookingfor. One „happening” may be treated as a single`event <#event>`__ by one ability <#ability>`__and as multiple `events by another.*Example: If an*attackingcreatureis blockedby twocreatures, this isoneeventfor atriggeredabilitythat reads”Whenever[thiscreature]becomesblocked”but twoeventsforatriggeredabilitythat reads”Whenever[thiscreature]becomesblockedby acreature.”

700.2. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is`modal <#modal_mode>`__ if it has two or more`options <#option>`__ in a bulleted listpreceded by instructions for a`player <#player>`__ to choose a number of those`options <#option>`__, such as „Choose one –.”Each of those options is a`mode <#modal_mode>`__. Modal <#modal_mode>`__`cards printed prior to the Khans ofTarkir(r) set didn’t use bulleted lists for the`modes <#modal_mode>`__; these cards <#card>`__have received errata in the `Oracle <#oracle>`__`card reference so the`modes <#modal_mode>`__ do appear in a bulletedlist.

700.2a. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ spell or`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__chooses the mode(s) as partof casting that spell or activatingthat ability. If one of the`modes <#modal_mode>`__ would be illegal (due toan inability to choose legal`targets <#target>`__, for example), that`mode <#modal_mode>`__ can’t be chosen. (Seerule 601.2b.)

700.2b. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ triggeredability chooses the`mode <#modal_mode>`__(s) as part of puttingthat ability on the`stack <#stack>`__. If one of the`modes <#modal_mode>`__ would be illegal (due toan inability to choose legal`targets <#target>`__, for example), that`mode <#modal_mode>`__ can’t be chosen. If no`mode <#modal_mode>`__ is chosen, the`ability <#ability>`__ is`removed <#remove_from_the_game_removed_removed-from-the-game_zone>`__from the stack. (See rule`603.3c <#R6033c>`__.)

700.2c. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ targets oneor more targets only if aparticular mode is chosen forit, its controller <#control_controller>`__will need to choose those `targets <#target>`__only if they chose that `mode.Otherwise, the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is treated asthough it did not have those`targets <#target>`__. (See rule`601.2c <#R6012c>`__.)

700.2d. If a player isallowed to choose more than one`mode <#modal_mode>`__ for a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ spell or`ability <#ability>`__, that`player <#player>`__ normally can’t choose thesame mode more than once.However, a few modal <#modal_mode>`__`spells include the instruction”You may choose the same`mode <#modal_mode>`__ more than once.” If aparticular mode is chosenmultiple times, the spell istreated as if that mode <#modal_mode>`__appeared that many times in sequence. If that`mode requires a`target <#target>`__, the same`player <#player>`__ or object maybe chosen as the target for eachof those modes, or different`targets <#target>`__ may be chosen.

700.2e. Some spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ specify that a`player <#player>`__ other than their`controller <#control_controller>`__ chooses a`mode <#modal_mode>`__ for it. In that case, theother player does so when the`spell <#spell>`__ or ability’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ normallywould do so. If there is more than one other`player <#player>`__ who could make such achoice, the spell or`ability <#ability>`__’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ decideswhich of those players will makethe choice.

700.2f. Modal <#modal_mode>`__`spells and abilities <#ability>`__may have different targeting`requirements for each`mode <#modal_mode>`__. Changing a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability’s`target <#target>`__ can’t change its`mode <#modal_mode>`__.

700.2g. A copy of a`modal <#modal_mode>`__ spell or`ability <#ability>`__ copies the`mode <#modal_mode>`__(s) chosen for it. The`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`copy <#copy>`__ can’t choose a different`mode <#modal_mode>`__. (See rule`706.10 <#R70610>`__.)

700.3. Some effects cause`objects <#object>`__ to be temporarily groupedinto piles.

700.3a. Each of the affected`objects <#object>`__ must be put into exactlyone of those piles,`unless <#unless>`__ the `effect <#effect>`__specifies otherwise.

700.3b. Each object in a`pile <#pile>`__ is still an individual`object <#object>`__. The pile isnot an object.

700.3c. Objects groupedinto piles don’t leave the`zone <#zone>`__ they’re currently in. If`cards <#card>`__ in a`graveyard <#graveyard>`__ are split into`piles <#pile>`__, the order of the`graveyard <#graveyard>`__ must be maintained.*Example: Fact or Fiction reads,”`Reveal <#reveal>`__*the topfivecardsofyourlibrary.Anopponentseparatesthosecardsintotwopiles. Putonepileintoyourhandandthe otherintoyourgraveyard.”While anopponentisseparating therevealedcardsintopiles,they’re still intheirowner«slibrary.They don’t leavethelibraryuntil they’re putintotheirowner«shandorgraveyard.

700.3d. A pile can containzero or more objects.

700.4. The term dies means”is put into a graveyard fromthe battlefield.”

700.5. A player’s`devotion <#devotion>`__ to [color]is equal to the number of manasymbols of that`color <#color>`__ among the manacosts of`permanents <#permanent>`__ that`player <#player>`__`controls <#control_controller>`__. A`player <#player>`__’s devotion <#devotion>`__to [`color 1] and[color 2] is equal to the number of`mana symbols <#mana_symbol>`__ among the manacosts of`permanents <#permanent>`__ that`player <#player>`__`controls <#control_controller>`__ that are[color 1], [color 2],or both colors.

700.6. The term`historic <#historic>`__ refers to an`object <#object>`__ that has the`legendary <#legendary>`__`supertype <#supertype>`__, the`artifact <#artifact>`__ cardtype, or the Saga <#saga>`__`subtype.

700.7. If an ability ofan object uses a phrase such as”this [something]” to identify an`object <#object>`__, where [something] is a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__, it isreferring to that particular`object <#object>`__, even if it isn’t theappropriate`characteristic <#characteristics>`__ at thetime. Example:Anabilityreads”Targetcreaturegets+2/+2 until end ofturn.Destroythatcreatureatthe beginning of the nextendstep.”Theabilitywilldestroytheobjectitgave +2/+2 to even ifthatobjectisn’tacreatureat the beginningof the nextend step.

700.8. Some cards refer tothe number of creatures in a`player <#player>`__’s party. A`player <#player>`__’s party <#party>`__consists of up to one `creature <#creature>`__that `player <#player>`__`controls for each ofthe following four creaturetypes: Cleric, Rogue,Warrior, and Wizard.

700.8a. The calculation of the numberof creatures in a`player <#player>`__’s party isperformed automatically by the game and resultsin a number between zero and four.`Players <#player>`__ don’t declare whichspecific creatures they`control <#control_controller>`__ are in their`party <#party>`__.

700.8b. If a creature <#creature>`__has multiple `creature types <#creature_type>`__for which it could be the `party <#party>`__member, it is counted as the `party <#party>`__member for only one of those `types.If there are different ways to count such a`creature <#creature>`__ that results indifferent numbers of creatures <#creature>`__in a `player’s party,it is counted in such a way to get the highestresult.

700.8c. A player has a`full party <#full_party>`__ if there are four`creatures <#creature>`__ in that`player <#player>`__’s party.

701. KeywordActions

701.1. Most actions described in a`card <#card>`__’s rules text <#rules_text>`__use the standard English definitions of theverbs within, but some specialized verbs areused whose meanings may not be clear. These”keywords” are game terms; sometimes `remindertext summarizes theirmeanings.

701.2. Activate

701.2a. To activate an`activated ability <#activated_ability>`__ is toput it onto the stack and`pay <#pay>`__ its costs, so that itwill eventually resolve and haveits effect. Only an`object <#object>`__’s`controller <#control_controller>`__ (or its`owner <#owner>`__, if it doesn’t have a`controller <#control_controller>`__) can`activate <#activate>`__ its activatedability <#activated_ability>`__`unless the object <#object>`__specifically says otherwise. A`player may`activate <#activate>`__ an`ability <#ability>`__ if they have`priority <#priority>`__. See rule`602 <#R602>`__, „Activating ActivatedAbilities.”

701.3. Attach

701.3a. To attach an`Aura <#aura>`__, Equipment, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ to an`object <#object>`__ or player <#player>`__means to take it from where it currently is andput it onto that `object or`player <#player>`__. If something is attachedto a permanent on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, it’s customaryto place it so that it’s physically touching the`permanent <#permanent>`__. An Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ can’t beattached to an object or`player <#player>`__ it couldn’t`enchant <#enchant>`__, equip, or`fortify <#fortify>`__, respectively.

701.3b. If an effect <#effect>`__tries to `attach an`Aura <#aura>`__, Equipment, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ to an`object <#object>`__ or player itcan’t be attached to, the Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ doesn’t`move <#move>`__. If an effect <#effect>`__tries to `attach an`Aura <#aura>`__, Equipment, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ to the`object <#object>`__ or player <#player>`__it’s already attached to, the`effect does nothing. If an`effect <#effect>`__ tries to`attach <#attach>`__ an object <#object>`__that isn’t an `Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ to another`object <#object>`__ or player,the effect does nothing and thefirst object doesn’t`move <#move>`__.

701.3c. Attaching an Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ to a different`object <#object>`__ or player <#player>`__causes the `Aura,`Equipment <#equipment>`__, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ to receive anew timestamp.

701.3d. To „unattach”an Equipment from a`creature <#creature>`__ means to`move <#move>`__ it away from that`creature <#creature>`__ so the`Equipment <#equipment>`__ is on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ but is notequipping anything. It should no longer bephysically touching any`creature <#creature>`__. If an`Aura <#aura>`__, Equipment, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ that wasattached to an object or`player <#player>`__ ceases to be attached toit, that counts as „becomingunattached [from that object or`player <#player>`__]”; this includes if that`Aura <#aura>`__, Equipment, or`Fortification <#fortification>`__ leaves thebattlefield, the`object <#object>`__ leaves the zone <#zone>`__it was in, or that `player leavesthe game.

701.4. Cast

701.4a. To cast a`spell <#spell>`__ is to take it from the`zone <#zone>`__ it’s in (usually the`hand <#hand>`__), put it on the`stack <#stack>`__, and pay its`costs <#cost>`__, so that it will eventually`resolve <#resolve>`__ and have its`effect <#effect>`__. A player may`cast <#cast>`__ a spell if theyhave priority. See rule`601 <#R601>`__, „Casting Spells.”

701.4b. To cast a`card <#card>`__ is to cast it as a`spell <#spell>`__.

701.5. Counter

701.5a. To counter a`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__means to cancel it, removing it from the`stack. It doesn’t`resolve <#resolve>`__ and none of its`effects <#effect>`__ occur. A countered`spell <#spell>`__ is put into its`owner <#owner>`__’s graveyard.

701.5b. The player who`cast <#cast>`__ a countered `spell <#spell>`__or activated a countered `ability <#ability>`__doesn’t get a „refund” of any `costs <#cost>`__that were paid.

701.6. Create

701.6a. To create one ormore tokens with certain`characteristics <#characteristics>`__, put thespecified number of tokens with thespecified characteristics <#characteristics>`__onto the `battlefield.

701.6b. If a replacementeffect applies to a`token <#token>`__ being created, that`effect <#effect>`__ applies before consideringany continuous effects <#continuous_effect>`__that will modify the`characteristics of that`token <#token>`__. If a replacementeffect applies to a`token <#token>`__ entering the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__, that`effect <#effect>`__ applies after consideringany continuous effects <#continuous_effect>`__that will modify the`characteristics of that`token <#token>`__.

701.6c. Previously, an`effect <#effect>`__ that created`tokens <#token>`__ instructed a`player <#player>`__ to „put [those`tokens <#token>`__] onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__.”Cards that were printed with thattext have received errata in the`Oracle <#oracle>`__ card referenceso they now „create” those`tokens <#token>`__.

701.7. Destroy

701.7a. To destroy a`permanent <#permanent>`__, move itfrom the battlefield to its`owner <#owner>`__’s graveyard.

701.7b. The only ways a`permanent <#permanent>`__ can be destroyed areas a result of an effect that usesthe word „destroy” or as a resultof the state-basedactions that check for`lethal damage <#lethal_damage>`__ (see rule`704.5g <#R7045g>`__) or damage <#damage>`__from a source with `deathtouch <#deathtouch>`__(see rule `704.5h). If a`permanent <#permanent>`__ is put into its`owner <#owner>`__’s `graveyard <#graveyard>`__for any other reason, it hasn’t been”destroyed.”

701.7c. A regeneration`effect <#effect>`__ replaces a destruction`event <#event>`__. See rule`701.15 <#R70115>`__,”Regenerate.”

701.8. Discard

701.8a. To discard a`card <#card>`__, move it from its`owner <#owner>`__’s hand to that`player <#player>`__’s`graveyard <#graveyard>`__.

701.8b. By default,`effects <#effect>`__ that cause a`player <#player>`__ to discard a`card <#card>`__ allow the affected`player <#player>`__ to choose which`card <#card>`__ to discard. Some`effects <#effect>`__, however, require a random`discard <#discard>`__ or allow another`player <#player>`__ to choose which`card <#card>`__ is discarded.

701.8c. If a card isdiscarded, but an effect causes itto be put into a hidden zone <#hidden_zone>`__`instead of into its`owner <#owner>`__’s graveyard <#graveyard>`__without being revealed, all values of that`card’s`characteristics <#characteristics>`__ areconsidered to be undefined. If a`card <#card>`__ is discarded this way to`pay <#pay>`__ a cost that specifiesa characteristic aboutthe discarded card, that`cost <#cost>`__ payment is illegal; the gamereturns to the moment before the`cost <#cost>`__ was paid (see rule`723 <#R723>`__, „Handling IllegalActions”).

701.9. Double

701.9a. Doubling a`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__and/or `toughness <#toughness>`__`creates a continuouseffect. This`effect <#effect>`__ modifies that`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__and/or `toughness but doesn’tset those characteristics <#characteristics>`__to a specific value. See rule`613.4c.

701.9b. To double a`creature <#creature>`__’s power,that creature gets+X/+0, where X is that`creature <#creature>`__’s power asthe spell or ability <#ability>`__that doubles its `power <#power>`__`resolves. Similarly, an`effect <#effect>`__ that doubles a`creature <#creature>`__’s`toughness <#toughness>`__ gives it+0/+X, where X is that`creature <#creature>`__’s`toughness <#toughness>`__. Doubling a`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__and `toughness gives it+X/+Y, where X isits power and Y is its`toughness <#toughness>`__.

701.9c. If a creature’s`power <#power>`__ is less than 0 when it’sdoubled, doubling that`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__`instead means that the`creature <#creature>`__ gets -X/-0,where X is the difference between 0 andits power. Similarly, if its`toughness <#toughness>`__ is less than 0 whendoubled, it gets -0/-X. If one`characteristic <#characteristics>`__’s value isnegative but the other isn’t when both aredoubled, it gets -X/+Y or+X/-Y, as appropriate.

701.9d. To double a`player <#player>`__’s lifetotal, the`player <#player>`__ gains or loses an amount of`life <#life_life_total>`__ such that their new`life total <#life_life_total>`__ is twice itscurrent value.

701.9e. To double the number of a kindof counters on a`player <#player>`__ or`permanent <#permanent>`__, give that`player <#player>`__ or`permanent <#permanent>`__ as many of those`counters <#counter>`__ as that`player <#player>`__ or`permanent <#permanent>`__ already has.

701.9f. To double the amount of a`type <#type>`__ of mana in a`player <#player>`__’s manapool, that player <#player>`__adds an amount of `mana of that`type <#type>`__ equal to the amount theyalready have.

701.10. Exchange

701.10a. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ may instruct`players <#player>`__ to`exchange <#exchange>`__ something (for example,`life totals <#life_life_total>`__ or`control <#control_controller>`__ of two`permanents <#permanent>`__) as part of itsresolution. When such a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ resolves,if the entire exchange can’t becompleted, no part of the`exchange <#exchange>`__ occurs. Example: Ifaspellattemptstoexchangecontroloftwotargetcreaturesbutone of thosecreaturesisdestroyed beforethespellresolves,thespelldoes nothing to theothercreature.

701.10b. When`control <#control_controller>`__ of two`permanents <#permanent>`__ is exchanged, ifthose permanents are controlledby different players, each ofthose players simultaneously gains`control <#control_controller>`__ of the`permanent <#permanent>`__ that was controlledby the other player. If, on theother hand, those`permanents <#permanent>`__ are controlled bythe same player, the`exchange <#exchange>`__ `effect <#effect>`__does nothing.

701.10c. When lifetotals are exchanged, each`player <#player>`__ gains or loses the amountof life necessary toequal the other player’s previous`life total <#life_life_total>`__. Replacementeffects may modifythese gains and losses, and triggeredabilities may`trigger <#trigger>`__ on them. A`player <#player>`__ who can’t gain`life <#life_life_total>`__ can’t be given ahigher life total thisway, and a player who can’t lose`life <#life_life_total>`__ can’t be given alower life total this way(see rules 119.7-8).

701.10d. Some spells or`abilities <#ability>`__ may instruct a`player <#player>`__ to exchange <#exchange>`__`cards in one zone with`cards <#card>`__ in a different`zone <#zone>`__ (for example, exiled`cards <#card>`__ and cards in a`player <#player>`__’s hand). These`spells <#spell>`__ and abilities <#ability>`__work the same as other”`exchange” spells <#spell>`__and `abilities, except they can`exchange <#exchange>`__ the cards <#card>`__only if all the `cards are owned bythe same player, and they can`exchange <#exchange>`__ the cards <#card>`__even if one `zone is empty.

701.10e. If a card in one`zone <#zone>`__ is exchanged with a`card <#card>`__ in a different`zone <#zone>`__, and either of them is attachedto an object, that`card <#card>`__ stops being attached to that`object <#object>`__ and the other`card <#card>`__ becomes attachedto that object.

701.10f. If a spell or`ability <#ability>`__ instructs a`player <#player>`__ to simply`exchange <#exchange>`__ two zones,and one of the zones is empty, the`cards <#card>`__ in the zones arestill exchanged.

701.10g. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ may instruct a`player <#player>`__ to exchange <#exchange>`__two numerical values. In such an`exchange, each value`becomes <#becomes>`__ equal to the previousvalue of the other. If either of those values isa life total, theaffected player gains or loses theamount of life necessaryto equal the other value. Replacementeffects may modify thisgain or loss, and triggeredabilities may`trigger <#trigger>`__ on it. A`player <#player>`__ who can’t gain`life <#life_life_total>`__ can’t be given ahigher life total thisway, and a player who can’t lose`life <#life_life_total>`__ can’t be given alower life total this way(see rules 119.7-8). If either ofthose values is a power or`toughness <#toughness>`__, a continuouseffect is createdsetting that power or`toughness <#toughness>`__ to the other value(see rule 613.4b). This rule doesnot apply to spells and`abilities <#ability>`__ that switch a`creature <#creature>`__’s power <#power>`__and `toughness.

701.11. Exile

701.11a. To exile an`object <#object>`__, move it to the`exile <#exile>`__ zone fromwherever it is. See rule 406,”Exile.”

701.12. Fight

701.12a. A spell or`ability <#ability>`__ may instruct a`creature <#creature>`__ to fight <#fight>`__another `creature or it mayinstruct two creatures to`fight <#fight>`__ each other. Each of those`creatures <#creature>`__ deals <#deal>`__`damage equal to its`power <#power>`__ to the other`creature <#creature>`__.

701.12b. If one or both`creatures <#creature>`__ instructed to`fight <#fight>`__ are no longer on the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ or are no longer`creatures <#creature>`__, neither of them`fights <#fight>`__ or deals <#deal>`__`damage. If one or both`creatures <#creature>`__ are illegaltargets for a resolving`spell <#spell>`__ or ability <#ability>`__that instructs them to `fight,neither of them fights or`deals <#deal>`__ damage.

701.12c. If a creature <#creature>`__`fights itself, it deals <#deal>`__`damage to itself equal to twiceits power.

701.12d. The damage dealtwhen a creature <#creature>`__`fights isn’t combatdamage.

701.13. Mill

701.13a. For a player to`mill <#mill>`__ a number of cards,that player puts that many`cards <#card>`__ from the top of their`library <#library>`__ into their`graveyard <#graveyard>`__.

701.13b. A player can’t`mill <#mill>`__ a number of cards <#card>`__greater than the number of `cards intheir library. If given thechoice to do so, they can’t choose to take thataction. If instructed to do so, they`mill <#mill>`__ as many as possible. Similarly,the player can’t pay a`cost <#cost>`__ that includes milling a numberof cards greater than the number of`cards <#card>`__ in their`library <#library>`__.

701.13c. An effect thatrefers to the „milled card” can findthat card in the zone itmoved to from the library, aslong as that zone is a publiczone.

701.13d. If an ability <#ability>`__checks information about a single milled`card but more than one`card <#card>`__ was milled, that`ability <#ability>`__ refers to each of themilled cards. If that`ability <#ability>`__ asks for any informationabout the milled card, such as a`characteristic <#characteristics>`__ or`converted mana cost <#converted_mana_cost>`__,it gets multiple answers. If these answers areused to determine the value of a variable, thesum of the answers is used. If that`ability <#ability>`__ performs any actions on”the” card, it performs that actionon each milled card. If that`ability <#ability>`__ performs any actions on”a” card, the`controller <#control_controller>`__ of the`ability <#ability>`__ chooses which`card <#card>`__ is affected.

701.14. Play

701.14a. To play a`land <#land>`__ means to put it onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ from the`zone <#zone>`__ it’s in (usually the`hand <#hand>`__). A player may`play <#play>`__ a land if they have`priority <#priority>`__, it’s the mainphase of their turn, the`stack <#stack>`__ is empty, and they haven’tplayed a land this turn. Playing a`land <#land>`__ is a specialaction (see rule`116 <#R116>`__), so it doesn’t use the`stack <#stack>`__; it simply happens. Putting a`land <#land>`__ onto the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ as the result ofa spell or ability <#ability>`__isn’t the same as playing a `land.See rule 305, „Lands.”

701.14b. To play a`card <#card>`__ means to play that`card <#card>`__ as a land or to`cast <#cast>`__ that card as a`spell <#spell>`__, whichever is appropriate.

701.14c. Some effects <#effect>`__instruct a `player to”play” with a certain aspect of thegame changed, such as „Play with thetop card of your <#you_your>`__`library revealed.””Play” in this sense means to`play <#play>`__ the Magic game.

701.14d. Previously, the action ofcasting a spell, or casting a`card <#card>`__ as a spell, wasreferred to on cards as „playing”that spell or that`card <#card>`__. Cards that wereprinted with that text have received errata inthe Oracle card <#card>`__reference so they now refer to „casting” that`spell or that card.

701.14e. Previously, the action ofusing an activatedability was referred toon cards as „playing” that`ability <#ability>`__. Cards thatwere printed with that text have received erratain the Oracle card <#card>`__reference so they now refer to „activating” that`ability.

701.15. Regenerate

701.15a. If the effect ofa resolving spell or`ability <#ability>`__`regenerates <#regenerate>`__ a`permanent <#permanent>`__, it`creates <#create>`__ a replacementeffect that protectsthe permanent the next time itwould be destroyed this turn. In this case,”Regenerate <#regenerate>`__[`permanent]” means „The nexttime [permanent] would bedestroyed this turn, instead <#instead>`__remove all `damage marked on it and`tap <#tap>`__ it. If it’s an attacking or`blocking creature <#blocking_creature>`__,remove it from combat.”

701.15b. If the effect ofa static ability <#static_ability>`__`regenerates a`permanent <#permanent>`__, it replacesdestruction with an alternate`effect <#effect>`__ each time that`permanent <#permanent>`__ would be destroyed.In this case, „Regenerate <#regenerate>`__[`permanent]” means”Instead remove all`damage <#damage>`__ marked on[permanent] and tap <#tap>`__it. If it’s an attacking or `blockingcreature, remove it fromcombat.”

701.15c. Neither activating an`ability <#ability>`__ that`creates <#create>`__ a regeneration shield norcasting a spell that`creates <#create>`__ a regeneration shield isthe same as regenerating a`permanent <#permanent>`__.`Effects <#effect>`__ that say that a`permanent <#permanent>`__ can’t be regenerateddon’t preclude such abilities <#ability>`__from being activated or such `spells <#spell>`__from being `cast; rather, they causeregeneration shields to not be applied.

701.16. Reveal

701.16a. To reveal a`card <#card>`__, show that card toall players for a brief time. Ifan effect causes a`card <#card>`__ to be revealed, it remainsrevealed for as long as necessary to completethe parts of the effect that`card <#card>`__ is relevant to. If the`cost <#cost>`__ to cast a`spell <#spell>`__ or activate <#activate>`__an `ability includes revealing a`card <#card>`__, the card remainsrevealed from the time the spell or`ability <#ability>`__ is announced until thetime it leaves the stack. Ifrevealing a card causes a triggeredability to`trigger <#trigger>`__, the card <#card>`__remains revealed until that `triggeredability leaves the`stack <#stack>`__. If that`ability <#ability>`__ isn’t put onto the`stack <#stack>`__ the next time a`player <#player>`__ would receive`priority <#priority>`__, the `card <#card>`__ceases to be revealed.

701.16b. Revealing a `card <#card>`__doesn’t cause it to leave the `zone <#zone>`__it’s in.

701.16c. If cards in a`player <#player>`__’s library <#library>`__are shuffled or otherwise reordered, anyrevealed `cards that are reorderedstop being revealed and become <#becomes>`__new `objects.

701.16d. Some effects <#effect>`__instruct a `player to look at oneor more cards. Looking at a`card <#card>`__ follows the same rules asrevealing a card, except that the`card <#card>`__ is shown only to the specified`player <#player>`__.

701.17. Sacrifice

701.17a. To sacrifice <#sacrifice>`__a `permanent, its`controller <#control_controller>`__`moves <#move>`__ it from the`battlefield <#battlefield>`__ directly to its`owner <#owner>`__’s graveyard.A player can’t`sacrifice <#sacrifice>`__ something that isn’ta permanent, or somethingthat’s a permanent they don’t`control <#control_controller>`__. Sacrificing a`permanent <#permanent>`__ doesn’t`destroy <#destroy>`__ it, so regeneration orother effects that replacedestruction can’t affect this action.

701.18. Scry

701.18a. To „scry N” meansto look at the top N cards of`your <#you_your>`__ library,then put any number of them on the bottom of`your <#you_your>`__ library inany order and the rest on top of`your <#you_your>`__ library inany order.

701.18b. If a player isinstructed to scry 0, no`scry <#scry>`__ event occurs.`Abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ whenever a`player <#player>`__ scries won’t`trigger <#trigger>`__.

701.18c. If multiple`players <#player>`__ scry at once,each of those players looks at thetop cards of their`library <#library>`__ at the same time. Those`players <#player>`__ decide in APNAPorder (see rule`101.4 <#R1014>`__) where to put those`cards <#card>`__, then those cards <#card>`__`move at the same time.

701.19. Search

701.19a. To search for a`card <#card>`__ in a zone, look atall cards in that zone <#zone>`__(even if it’s a `hidden zone)and find a card that`matches <#match>`__ the given description.

701.19b. If a player issearching a hidden zone for`cards <#card>`__ with a stated quality, such asa card with a certain cardtype or color, that`player <#player>`__ isn’t required to find someor all of those cards even ifthey’re present in that zone.*Example: Splinter says”`Exile <#exile>`__`target <#target>`__`artifact <#artifact>`__*.Searchitscontroller«sgraveyard,hand,andlibraryforallcardswith thesamenameasthatartifactandexilethem.Thenthatplayershufflestheirlibrary.”AplayercastsSplintertargeting Howling Mine(anartifact). HowlingMine’scontrollerhasanother Howling Mine inhergraveyardand two morein herlibrary.Splinter’scontrollermustfind the Howling Mine inthegraveyard, but maychoose to find zero, one, or two of the HowlingMines in thelibrary.

701.19c. If a player isinstructed to search a hiddenzone for cards <#card>`__that `match an undefined quality,that player may still`search <#search>`__ that zone butcan’t find any cards. Example:Lobotomy says”Targetplayerrevealstheirhand,thenyouchooseacardother thanabasiclandcardfromit.Searchthatplayer«sgraveyard,hand,andlibraryforallcardswith thesamenameas thechosencardandexilethem.Thenthatplayershufflestheirlibrary.”IfthetargetplayerhasnocardsintheirhandwhenLobotomyresolves,theplayerwhocastLobotomysearchesthespecifiedzonesbutdoesn’texileanycards.

701.19d. If a player issearching a hidden zone <#hidden_zone>`__simply for a quantity of `cards, suchas „a card” or „three`cards <#card>`__,” that player <#player>`__must find that many `cards (or asmany as possible, if the zone <#zone>`__doesn’t contain enough `cards).

701.19e. If the effect <#effect>`__that contains the `search <#search>`__instruction doesn’t also contain instructions to`reveal the found`card <#card>`__(s), then they’re notrevealed.

701.19f. If searching a`zone <#zone>`__ is replaced with searching aportion of that zone, any otherinstructions that refer to searching the`zone <#zone>`__ still apply. Any`abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ on a`library <#library>`__ being searched will`trigger <#trigger>`__. Example: AvenMindcensor says, in part, „Ifanopponentwouldsearchalibrary,thatplayersearchesthetop fourcardsofthatlibraryinstead.”Veteran Explorer says „When VeteranExplorerdies,eachplayermaysearchtheirlibraryforup totwobasiclandcardsandput them ontothebattlefield. Theneachplayerwho searchedtheirlibrarythiswayshufflesit.”Anopponentwho searched thetop fourcardsoftheirlibrarybecause ofVeteranExplorer’sabilitywouldshuffletheentirelibrary.

701.19g. If an effect <#effect>`__offers a `player a choice to`search <#search>`__ a zone and takeadditional actions with the cards <#card>`__found, that `player may choose to`search <#search>`__ even if the additionalactions are illegal or impossible.

701.19h. An effect mayinstruct a player to`search <#search>`__ a library <#library>`__for one or more `cards more than oncebefore instructing a player to`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ that`library <#library>`__. This is the same as asingle instruction for that player <#player>`__to `search that`library <#library>`__ for all those`cards <#card>`__. The player <#player>`__`searches that`library <#library>`__ only once.

701.19i. If multiple`players <#player>`__ search atonce, each of those players looksat the appropriate cards at the sametime, then those players decide in`APNAP order <#apnap_order>`__ (see rule`101.4 <#R1014>`__) which card tofind.

701.20. Shuffle

701.20a. To shuffle a`library <#library>`__ or a face-down`pile <#pile>`__ of cards, randomizethe cards within it so that no`player <#player>`__ knows their order.

701.20b. Some effects <#effect>`__cause a `player to`search <#search>`__ a library <#library>`__for a `card or cards,`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ that`library <#library>`__, then put the found`card <#card>`__ or cards in acertain position in that library.Even though the found card or`cards <#card>`__ never leave that`library <#library>`__, they aren’t included inthe shuffle. Rather, all the`cards <#card>`__ in that library <#library>`__except those are shuffled.`Abilities that`trigger <#trigger>`__ when a`library <#library>`__ is shuffled will still`trigger <#trigger>`__. See also rule`401 <#R401>`__, „Library.”

701.20c. If an effect <#effect>`__would cause a `player to`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ one or more specific`objects <#object>`__ into a`library <#library>`__, that`library <#library>`__ is shuffled even if noneof those objects are in the`zone <#zone>`__ they’re expected to be in or an`effect <#effect>`__ causes all of those`objects <#object>`__ to be moved to another`zone <#zone>`__ or remain in their current`zone <#zone>`__. Example: Guile says, in part,”When Guile is put intoagraveyardfromanywhere,shuffleit intoitsowner«slibrary.”It’s put intoagraveyardanditsabilitytriggers,thenaplayerexilesitfrom thatgraveyardinresponse. Whentheabilityresolves,thelibraryis shuffled.**Example: Black Sun’s Zenith says, in part,”ShuffleBlack Sun’s Zenithintoitsowner«slibrary.”Black Sun’s Zenith is inagraveyard, hasgainedflashback(due toRecoup, perhaps), andiscastfromthatgraveyard. BlackSun’s Zenith will be exiled, anditsowner«slibrarywillbe shuffled.

701.20d. If an effect <#effect>`__would cause a `player to`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ a set of`objects <#object>`__ into a`library <#library>`__, that`library <#library>`__ is shuffled even if thereare no objects in that set.*Example: Loaming Shaman says „When LoamingShaman*enters thebattlefield,targetplayershufflesanynumberoftargetcardsfromtheirgraveyardintotheirlibrary.” Itentersthe battlefield,itsabilitytriggers,and nocardsare targeted. Whentheabilityresolves,the targetedplayerwill stillhavetoshuffletheirlibrary.

701.20e. If an effect <#effect>`__causes a `player to`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ a library <#library>`__containing zero or one `cards,`abilities <#ability>`__ that`trigger <#trigger>`__ when a`library <#library>`__ is shuffled will still`trigger <#trigger>`__.

701.20f. If two or more`effects <#effect>`__ cause a`library <#library>`__ to be shuffled multipletimes simultaneously, abilities <#ability>`__that `trigger when that`library <#library>`__ is shuffled will`trigger <#trigger>`__ that many times.

701.20g. If an effect <#effect>`__would cause a `player to`shuffle <#shuffle>`__ a library <#library>`__at the same time that an `object <#object>`__would be put into a certain position in that`library, the result is a shuffled`library <#library>`__ that’s randomized exceptthat the object is in thespecified position. Example: Darksteel Colossusand Gravebane Zombie are put intoaplayer«sgraveyardfromthebattlefieldat thesame time. Darksteel Colossus says in part „IfDarksteel Colossus would be put intoagraveyardfromanywhere,revealDarksteelColossus andshuffleit intoitsowner«slibraryinstead.”Gravebane Zombie says „If Gravebane Zombiewoulddie, put Gravebane Zombieon top ofitsowner«slibraryinstead.”TheplayershufflesDarksteelColossus intotheirlibraryand putsGravebane Zombie on top ofthatlibrary.

701.21. Tap and`Untap <#untap>`__

701.21a. To tap a`permanent <#permanent>`__, turn it sidewaysfrom an upright position. Only`untapped <#untapped>`__`permanents <#permanent>`__ can be`tapped <#tapped>`__.

701.21b. To untap a`permanent <#permanent>`__, rotate it back tothe upright position from a sideways position.Only tapped <#tapped>`__`permanents can be`untapped <#untapped>`__.

701.22. Fateseal

701.22a. To „fateseal <#fateseal>`__N” means to look at the top N `cards <#card>`__of an `opponent’s`library <#library>`__, then put any number ofthem on the bottom of that`library <#library>`__ in any order and the reston top of that library in anyorder.

701.23. Clash

701.23a. To clash, a`player <#player>`__ reveals thetop card of their`library <#library>`__. That`player <#player>`__ may then put that`card <#card>`__ on the bottom of their`library <#library>`__.

701.23b. „Clash with an`opponent <#opponent>`__” means „Choose an`opponent <#opponent>`__. You <#you_your>`__and that `opponent each`clash <#clash>`__.”

701.23c. Each clashing`player <#player>`__ reveals thetop card of their`library <#library>`__ at the same time. Thenthose players decide in APNAPorder (see rule`101.4 <#R1014>`__) where to put those`cards <#card>`__, then those cards <#card>`__`move at the same time.

701.23d. A player wins a`clash <#clash>`__ if that player <#player>`__revealed a `card with a higher`converted mana cost <#converted_mana_cost>`__than all other cards revealed inthat clash.

701.24. Planeswalk

701.24a. A player may`planeswalk <#planeswalk>`__ only`during <#during>`__ a`Planechase <#planechase>`__ game. Only theplanar controller may`planeswalk <#planeswalk>`__. See rule`901 <#R901>`__, „Planechase.”

701.24b. To`planeswalk <#planeswalk>`__ is to put eachface-up plane card and`phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__ card onthe bottom of its owner’s planardeck facedown, then move thetop card of your <#you_your>`__`planar deck off that planardeck and turn it faceup.

701.24c. A player may`planeswalk <#planeswalk>`__ as the result ofthe „planeswalking ability” (seerule 901.8), because the`owner <#owner>`__ of a face-up`plane <#plane>`__ card or`phenomenon <#phenomenon>`__ card <#card>`__leaves the game (see rule `901.10),or because a phenomenon’s`triggered ability <#triggered_ability>`__leaves the stack (see rule`704.6f <#R7046f>`__). Abilities <#ability>`__may also instruct a `player to`planeswalk <#planeswalk>`__.

701.24d. The plane <#plane>`__`card that’s turned faceup is the plane the`player <#player>`__`planeswalks <#planeswalk>`__ to. The`plane <#plane>`__ card that’sturned face down or that leavesthe game is the plane the`player <#player>`__`planeswalks <#planeswalk>`__ away from. Thesame is true with respect to phenomena.

701.25. Set inMotion

701.25a. Only a scheme <#scheme>`__`card may be set inmotion, and only`during <#during>`__ an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game. Only the`archenemy <#archenemy>`__ may set a`scheme <#scheme>`__ card in motion.See rule 312,”Schemes,” and rule`904 <#R904>`__, „Archenemy.”

701.25b. To set a scheme <#scheme>`__in motion, `move it off the top of`your <#you_your>`__ scheme <#scheme>`__`deck if it’s on top of`your <#you_your>`__ scheme <#scheme>`__`deck and turn it faceup if it isn’t faceup. That scheme isconsidered to have been set inmotion even if neither ofthese actions was performed on it.

701.25c. Schemes may onlybe set in motion one at atime. If a player is instructed toset multiple schemes in motion,that player sets a`scheme <#scheme>`__ in motion that many times.

701.26. Abandon

701.26a. Only a face-up`ongoing <#ongoing>`__ scheme <#scheme>`__`card may be abandoned, and only`during <#during>`__ an`Archenemy <#archenemy>`__ game. See rule`312 <#R312>`__, „Schemes,” andrule 904,”Archenemy.”
